<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="medical-microbiology">Medical Microbiology<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#medical-microbiology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Part One: Bacteriology</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-c7b45514.jpeg" alt="img-1.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="chapter-1">Chapter 1<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chapter-1" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="introduction">Introduction<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#introduction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Microbiology is the study of microorganisms which are organisms so small that they cannot be seen with the naked eye. They can be observed only with the aid of a microscope. The ordinary brightfield microscope is mostly employed for routine microbiological work, though others like phase-contrast, darkfield, fluorescence and electron microscopes are also used.</p>
<p>Microorganisms are found almost everywhere in nature. They are in constant interaction with human and other life cycles. Some bacteria, for example, are normal constituents of the human intestine. These microorganisms and their host benefit from such co-existence: The organisms derive food materials from the host, and some of the host's essential vitamins for existence are synthesised by the organisms. There are however certain microorganisms that are harmful to their hosts, that is, they can cause diseases. These microorganisms are known as pathogens. Those organisms that do not cause any harm are called commensals. This broad classification of microorganisms is not definitive because some commensals under certain conditions can become harmful to the host. The role of the medical microbiologist is to isolate and identify pathogens and develop effective ways to eliminate or control them.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="taxonomy-and-classification-of-microorganisms">TAXONOMY AND CLASSIFICATION OF MICROORGANISMS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#taxonomy-and-classification-of-microorganisms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Before the discovery of microorganisms, all living things were thought to belong to either the animal or the plant kingdom. In 1675, Anthony von Leeuwenhoek, a Dutch draper, described little animals (animalcules) which he saw with the aid of his simple home-made microscope while examining stagnant rain water. He described many kinds of cells which included protozoa, algae, yeasts and bacteria. He was the first on record to observe microorganisms. Many workers in different parts of the world did a lot of pioneering work in the study of microorganisms. But Louis Pasteur, a French chemist, was by far the most outstanding figure in this regard. As a result of his brilliant researches between 1860 and 1869, he was able to show that microorganisms caused diseases. The contributions of numerous other scientists of the time led to an increase in the knowledge of microbiology.</p>
<p>This increased knowledge also led to the discovery of many varieties of microorganisms and brought about some confusion as to where to place micro-organisms within the two kingdom of living things. Furthermore, these many varieties of micro-organisms needed to be differentiated from each other. Taxonomy is the process of dividing organ</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Bacteriology</p>
<p>isms into ordered groups based on biological relationship between them. Labelling of groups and of individual members within groups is known as nomenclature. The whole process of classifying microorganisms is highly complicated and many workers have chosen to approach the topic from different perspectives. Classification based on evolutionary (ancestry) origins is called phylogenetic classification, and that based on easily recognisable characteristics or features is called 'artificial' classification. Numerical taxonomy is a mathematical approach in which all features are given equal value. This is the original Adansonian concept. The advent of computers has made this approach to taxonomy easier to apply. Another concept that has found favour with many workers is the determination of the DNA base composition: members of the same species will have identical cellular DNA.</p>
<p>In 1866, Haeckel proposed the establishment of a third and separate kingdom of living organisms, the Protista, which was defined to include algae, protozoa, fungi, viruses and bacteria. In 1957, Stanier divided the Protista into the eukaryotic (higher) and prokaryotic (lower) groups based on cell types. The eukaryotic cells which are found in protozoa, fungi, and algae, contain a nucleus bound by a nuclear membrane and undergo true mitosis. The prokaryotic organisms possess a nuclear structure of a single deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) ring with no nuclear membrane. Table 1.1 shows the classification of the Protista.</p>
<p>Biological classification methods provide the medical microbiologist with relatively simple ways for placing microbes into categories according to their morphological and biochemical properties. The word species is commonly used in this system of classification. It is the basic unit in the hierarchy of microbial world. The basis of this category is that members of the same species are able to reproduce others of their kind.</p>
<p>The next higher classification is the genus. The same genus comprises several species which may differ in several aspects. The genus of the microbe is usually abbreviated and the species written in full; it must start with a capital letter while the species starts with a small letter, e.g., Staphylococcus aureus is written as S. aureus. Further up the ladder of classification, micro-organisms with similar features are placed in successive larger categories. Thus similar genera are grouped into families, similar families are categorised as order; similar order make up class; similar classes make up the phylum (Fig. 1.1).</p>
<p>The wide and ever expanding variety of microorganisms has resulted in the break up of Microbiology into separate specialised sections of Bacteriology (the study of bacteria), Virology (the study of viruses), Mycology (the study of fungi), Parasitology (the study of parasites) and lately serology - immunology (the study of antigen/antibody reaction and immunity).</p>
<p>This fragmentation has sufficiently lessened the initial confusion in the general classification of microorganisms. The problems faced by the early</p>

<p>pioneers in the field of Microbiology with regards to taxonomy and nomenclature are far from being over today. There is constant arranging and re-arranging and renaming of microbes as new information is being discovered. The reader is referred to Bergey's Manual of Determinative Bacteriology and the reports and publications of the International subcommittee on Taxonomy and Nomenclature for more and detailed information on this topic.</p>

<p>Chapter 2 Morphology and Anatomy of Bacteria</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="morphology-and-structure-of-bacteria">MORPHOLOGY AND STRUCTURE OF BACTERIA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#morphology-and-structure-of-bacteria" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The classification of bacteria in routine use is 'artificial' and is based on some recognisable features and characteristics which have been arbitrarily selected. These features include:</p>
<ul>
<li>Morphology</li>
<li>Staining reaction</li>
<li>Cultural requirements</li>
<li>Biochemical reactions</li>
<li>Antigenic structure</li>
<li>DNA base composition i.e. guanine: Cytosine ratio</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="morphology">Morphology<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#morphology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Bacteria are microscopic unicellular organisms. The unit of measurement of bacteria is the micrometre <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>μ</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(\mu \mathrm{m})</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathnormal">μ</span><span class="mord mathrm">m</span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span> and it is 1/1000 of a millimetre <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>.001</mn><mi>μ</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(.001\mu \mathrm{m})</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord">.001</span><span class="mord mathnormal">μ</span><span class="mord mathrm">m</span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span>. Morphological classification of bacteria is based on the following types of shapes of cells:</p>
<ol>
<li>The spheroid or ovoid or coccus. These groups of bacteria are popularly called cocci (plural of coccus). They measure about <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>0.5</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn><mi>μ</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">0.5 - 1\mu \mathrm{m}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">0.5</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8389em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord mathnormal">μ</span><span class="mord mathrm">m</span></span></span></span></span> in diameter. Sometimes these cells are flattened or distorted to give a change in shape.</li>
</ol>
<p>The bacteria multiply by binary fission. During multiplication, the daughter cell is attached to the parent cell but it gets detached before fission occurs again. The pairs of cocci seen are referred to as diplococci. If the fission continues while they remain attached, chains of cocci are formed, and are referred to as streptococci. If the division is not in one plain and clusters of cocci are formed randomly, they are known as staphylococci. Tetrads (or tetracoci) are formed when the cocci remain in pairs for two consecutive divisions and form regular aggregates of four cocci. When the terms Staphylococcus and Streptococcus are used as generic names, the first letter is a capital letter.</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>Bacillus. This is a 'rod' shaped cell measuring about <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>10</mn><mi>μ</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1 - 10\mu \mathrm{m}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8389em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">10</span><span class="mord mathnormal">μ</span><span class="mord mathrm">m</span></span></span></span></span> in length and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>0.3</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>1.0</mn><mi>μ</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">0.3 - 1.0\mu \mathrm{m}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">0.3</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8389em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">1.0</span><span class="mord mathnormal">μ</span><span class="mord mathrm">m</span></span></span></span></span> in width. The bacilli (plural) or rods may remain attached after division and they are called streptobacilli; or they may be arranged at varying angles to one another due to incomplete separation after cell division, thus giving the appearance of Chinese lettering. This is characteristic of the genus Corynebacterium.</li>
</ol>
<p>The morphology of some of these bacilli may be affected as a result of the formation of spores during unfavourable conditions. Some species contain these spores in the centre with or without bulging and others may have them at terminal ends or towards one end.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Morphology and Anatomy of Bacteria 531</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>
<p>Vibrio The vibrio is a short, comma shaped rigid bacillus. It measures about <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>4</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>5</mn><mi>μ</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">4 \times 5 \mu \mathrm{m}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">4</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8389em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">5</span><span class="mord mathnormal">μ</span><span class="mord mathrm">m</span></span></span></span></span>.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Spirillum The spirillum is a rigid spiral organism and it is variable in size, measuring approximately <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>4</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>0.2</mn><mi>μ</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">4 \times 0.2 \mu \mathrm{m}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">4</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8389em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">0.2</span><span class="mord mathnormal">μ</span><span class="mord mathrm">m</span></span></span></span></span>. It has a corkscrew (helical) shape.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Spirochaete This is a flexible spiral shaped organism. It possesses an axial fibre around which the body is twisted in a helical fashion. It measures about <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>10</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>20</mn><mi>μ</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">10 - 20 \mu \mathrm{m}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">10</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8389em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">20</span><span class="mord mathnormal">μ</span><span class="mord mathrm">m</span></span></span></span></span> in length and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>0.2</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>0.4</mn><mi>μ</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">0.2 - 0.4 \mu \mathrm{m}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">0.2</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8389em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">0.4</span><span class="mord mathnormal">μ</span><span class="mord mathrm">m</span></span></span></span></span> in thickness.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>Figure 2.1 shows the various bacterial shapes and arrangements.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="bacterial-anatomy">BACTERIAL ANATOMY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bacterial-anatomy" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Figure 2.2 shows a diagram of a typical but composite bacterial cell showing some of the essential constituents. The bacterial cell has a rigid cell wall which surrounds the protoplast. The cell can be divided into the external structures and the internal structures.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="external-structures">EXTERNAL STRUCTURES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#external-structures" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The external structures are those structures which protrude from the cell into the surrounding environment. They include:</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-79709d56.jpeg" alt="img-3.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 2.1 Bacterial morphology</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Bacteriology</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-ad36c799.jpeg" alt="img-4.jpeg">
Fig. 2.2 Bacterial anatomy</p>
<ol>
<li>Flagella These are slender filaments that originate from the cytoplasm. They function as organs of motility. They are therefore seen only in organisms that are motile. They are proteins; and have characteristic patterns of arrangement on the bacterial cell (Fig. 2.3). They are too thin to be seen in ordinary stained preparations, but become visible only in silver impregnation preparation or in electron microscopy.</li>
<li>Pili Extruding from the cytoplasmic membrane are shorter and finer filaments than the flagella. These are the pili. Some of them are referred to as sex pili because of their role during conjugation when genes are transferred from one cell to another. Majority of them are referred to as common pili or fimbriae. These are thought to be the organs of adhesion that help bacteria to attach to the host cells.</li>
<li>Capsule This is a layer of loose slimy material which surrounds some bacterial cells. The capsules are composed mainly of polymers of polysaccharides or peptides. They resist phygocytosis and so their presence on a bacterium is associated with virulence. They are identified by negative staining due to their low affinity for simple stains.</li>
</ol>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-35efd8bd.jpeg" alt="img-5.jpeg">
Fig. 2.3 Distribution of flagella</p>
<ol start="4">
<li>Cell Wall The cell wall is a prominent distinguishing feature of the bacterial cell with a rigidity and strength that protects the cellular contents. Chemically, the cell wall consists of peptidoglycan, a mucopeptide that is composed of alternating strands of N-acetyl-glucosamine and N-acetylmuramic acid residues, cross-linked with peptide subunits. The peptidoglycan gives rigidity and shape to the organism. Structurally, the cell wall of a Gram positive bacterium differs from that of a Gram negative bacterium (Fig. 2.4). The Gram positive cell wall is much more sturdy than the Gram negative one due to its high content of peptidoglycan. It has neither an outer membrane that contains specific proteins nor a periplasmic space, both of which are present in the Gram negative cell. Teichoic acids are also part of the cell wall of Gram positive bacteria. The Gram negative cell wall has a thin peptidoglycan layer with no teichoic acids. It has an outer membrane which</li>
</ol>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Morphology and Anatomy of Bacteria 533</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-3703369c.jpeg" alt="img-6.jpeg">
Fig. 2.4 Bacterial cell wall</p>
<p>consists of lipopolysaccharides. The lipopolysaccharide is toxic to humans. It is called endotoxin.</p>
<ol start="5">
<li>Cytoplasmic membrane This is a double layered structure within the cell wall. It is composed of lipid and protein and acts as a semipermeable membrane through which nutrients pass into and out of the cell.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="internal-structures">INTERNAL STRUCTURES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#internal-structures" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>Mesosomes These are convoluted invaginations within the cytoplasmic membrane. They play an important role during cell division and in the secretion of certain enzymes.</li>
<li>Nuclear material Within the cytoplasmic membrane, the cell itself has the 'nucleus' which has no nuclear membrane and lacks a definite shape. It is a single circular strand of deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) which acts as a 'nucleus' (chromosome).</li>
<li>Ribosomes Ribosomes are located throughout the cytoplasm and are the sites of protein synthesis. They are important for conveying the genetic code of the nucleus into instructions in the manufacture of cellular components. They are composed of ribonucleic acid (RNA) and proteins.</li>
<li>Cytoplasmic inclusions These are seen in some bacteria and appear to be sources of reserved food for energy. For example, volutin (polymetaphosphate) granules associated with Corynebacteria.</li>
<li>Spores These are dense structures produced by the bacteria, e.g., the Bacillus and Clostridium groups, that enable them to survive adverse environmental conditions. They develop within and at the expense of the vegetative cell. The spore comprises the chromosomal material surrounded by several layers of walls. The location and shape of the spore in the cell may be of diagnostic assistance, e.g., the spores of Clostridium tetani are terminal, and the diameter is greater than that of the parent cell, so that they are characteristically of drum stick appearance. The positions of spores are described as terminal, subterminal or central. Spores are resistant to heat, stains, desiccation and disinfectants. Each spore germinates to produce a vegetative cell during favourable growth conditions.</li>
</ol>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Chapter 3
Microscopic Examination of Bacteria</p>
<p>Microscopic examination of stained or unstained preparation of bacteria is usually one of the essential steps in the long process of isolating and identifying bacteria. Microscopy of stained smears helps to differentiate cellular constituents and render them more visible. Staining also helps to classify organisms by placing them in their separate groups, based on the staining reaction of the organism.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="wire-loops">WIRE LOOPS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#wire-loops" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The microbiological wire loops are used to make smears. They are made of platinum or nichrome wires. The platinum wire used is actually a mixture of platinum (90%) and iridium (10%). Platinum on its own is too soft to be of any use. The nichrome wire is cheaper and more flexible. Disposable plastic loops are also available. Wire loops are made in various sizes of between 1.5 mm and 3 mm in diameter with the handle or holder about 6–8 cm long (Fig. 3.1a).</p>
<p>The wire loops may be purchased commercially though making a wire loop is not very difficult (Fig. 3.1b):</p>
<ol>
<li>Wind the wire once round a rod of appropriate diameter.</li>
<li>With a pair of scissors, cut one arm of the wire wound around the rod, forming a loop.</li>
<li>Bend back the loop with a pair of forceps to centre it.</li>
<li>Insert into a metal wire loop holder.</li>
</ol>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-93aecb1d.jpeg" alt="img-7.jpeg">
Fig. 3.1(a) Wire loop</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-f8dad971.jpeg" alt="img-8.jpeg">
Fig. 3.1(b) Making a wire loop</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Microscopic Examination of Bacteria 535</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="making-a-wet-preparation-for-microscopy">Making a Wet Preparation for Microscopy<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#making-a-wet-preparation-for-microscopy" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>On a clean microscope slide, place a drop of the material to be examined, e.g., urine, or mix a small portion of the specimen such as vaginal secretion in a drop of saline.</li>
<li>Carefully place a cover-slip over the preparation, making sure that there are no air bubbles trapped under the cover-slip.</li>
<li>Examine immediately. If there is going to be a delay in examining the preparation, it is recommended to seal the edges of the cover-slip with nail varnish or petroleum jelly.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="hanging-drop-preparation">Hanging Drop Preparation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hanging-drop-preparation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The hanging drop is a microscopic technique used to determine the motility of bacteria when suspended in fluid. True motility is when bacteria actively move from one position to another in a haphazard manner. It should not be confused with Brownian movement which is the vibration caused by molecular bombardment, or the one directional movement caused by convectional currents.</p>
<ol>
<li>Make a ring of plasticine or vaseline about 2 cm in diameter on a clean slide.</li>
<li>Place a loopful of culture in the centre of a clean 22 mm square cover-slip.</li>
<li>Carefully press the ring of plasticine on to the cover-slip with the drop of culture in the centre of the ring and not touching the slide.</li>
<li>With a quick movement invert the slide so that the cover-slip is uppermost (Fig. 3.2).</li>
</ol>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-fb308e79.jpeg" alt="img-9.jpeg">
Fig. 3.2 Hanging drop preparation</p>
<ol start="5">
<li>Examine under the microscope, first using the low power objective (16 mm) to focus on the edge of the 'drop', then observe motility with high-power (4 mm) objective.</li>
<li>At the end of the examination, discard the whole preparation into a jar of disinfectant and allow to soak to kill the microorganisms.</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>Note</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>A 'well-slide' with a depression in the centre can be used in place of the slide with a ring of plasticine. Remember to seal the cover-slip with vaseline or nail varnish.</li>
<li>With experience, one can use the ordinary wet preparation to determine motility microscopically.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="7602b6ba">♦ PREPARATION OF SMEARS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#7602b6ba" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Stained preparations are needed to examine micro-organisms microscopically in order to study their morphology and observe their cellular constituents. Smears (or tissue sections) are made and stained by any one of the recognised staining methods. Smears can be made from liquid or solid cultures or from clinical specimens.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="smears-from-solid-media">Smears from Solid Media<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#smears-from-solid-media" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>Sterilise the wire loop in bunsen flame.</li>
<li>Place one drop of sterile saline on a clean slide with the sterilised loop.</li>
<li>Re-sterilise the loop.</li>
<li>With the wire loop, pick a small portion of bacterial growth and emulsify it in the drop of saline and spread to give a thin homogeneous film or smear on the slide (Fig. 3.3). Sterilise the loop.</li>
<li>Allow the smear to dry in air, fix and stain.</li>
</ol>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-ac79e04e.jpeg" alt="img-10.jpeg">
Fig. 3.3 Bacterial smear</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>536 Bacteriology</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="smears-from-liquid-media">Smears from Liquid Media<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#smears-from-liquid-media" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Sterilise wire loop in the bunsen flame.</li>
<li>Using aseptic technique, remove a loopful of the culture.</li>
<li>Place the culture on a clean slide and spread it with the loop to give a fairly thick film of culture. Sterilise the loop.</li>
<li>Allow the film to dry, fix and stain.</li>
</ol>
<p>&gt; <strong>Note</strong>
&gt; 1. Always allow the film to dry on its own in air without heating before fixing it. This is to prevent the smear from being washed off during staining.
&gt; 2. From solid media the smear should be thin and from liquid media, it should be thick.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="smears-from-clinical-specimens">Smears From Clinical Specimens<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#smears-from-clinical-specimens" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Smears are made from original clinical specimens directly on the slide if it is a swab or with a loop if it is fluid.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="fixation-of-bacterial-smears">Fixation of Bacterial Smears<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fixation-of-bacterial-smears" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The smear having been made and allowed to dry, is fixed by quickly passing it two or three times over a bunsen flame to a temperature of about 55 to 60 °C. This is to coagulate the bacterial proteins which makes them adhere to the slide. Fixation should be such that the bacterial morphology remains intact, preventing the smear from being washed off during staining. Overheating will lead to distortion of morphology.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="da1a933">♦ STAINING OF BACTERIA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#da1a933" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Dyes from which stains are made, are either natural or synthetic products. Most of the dyes used for bacterial smears are synthetic. The natural dyes are mostly used in histopathology. The synthetic dyes are all derivatives of benzene and are usually referred to as aniline dyes.</p>
<p>Stains are mostly salts, comprising a base and an acid. They are classified into acid, basic and neutral stains. Basic stains are those in which the colouring substances are contained in the basic radical with the acid radical being colourless, while those stains in which the colouring substances are in the acidic radical and base components being colourless, are Acid stains. An aqueous mixture of some acid and basic dyes results in Neutral stains, with the colouring substances contained in both acid and base components.</p>
<p>The theory of staining reaction is not fully understood but it is generally believed to be a combination of chemical and physical reactions. The bacterial cell which is rich in nucleic acid, has affinity for basic stains and so is stained by the basic stain. The acid stain is useful for basic components and as a background stain to give a good contrast.</p>
<p><strong>Mordant</strong> Some organisms (or tissues) do not take up the stain except in the presence of a mordant—a substance that forms a link between the organism and the stain to bring about a staining reaction. The mordant forms a ‘lake’ with the dye which is capable of attaching itself firmly to the organism. A popular mordant in bacteriology is the Lugol’s iodine. The mordant should not be confused with an accentuator which is a substance that greatly increases the staining power and selectivity of a stain. It does not combine or form a lake with the dye.</p>
<p><strong>Examination of stained smears</strong> All stained smears are examined with oil immersion objective (≥ 100).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="92e6a54b">♦ TYPES OF STAINING<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#92e6a54b" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Indirect staining</strong> This is when an organism is stained only in the presence of a mordant, e.g., Gram’s stain.</p>
<p><strong>Direct staining</strong> This is a simple one-step staining procedure in which the presence and morphology of bacteria are demonstrated. Some of the stains used for this technique are also used as counterstains in some other staining procedures, e.g., methylene blue.</p>
<p><strong>Negative staining</strong> This is when the organism remains unstained against a stained background.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Microscopic Examination of Bacteria 537</p>
<p>This is one of the few methods where acid stains such as nigrosin, are used.</p>
<p>Metachromatic staining  In this staining method the organism or part of the organism is stained a different shade of colour from that of the stain.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="commonly-used-staining-methods">Commonly Used Staining Methods<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#commonly-used-staining-methods" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>In Bacteriology, staining methods are divided into three categories:</p>
<p>(i) Simple stains  This makes use of the direct staining method.
(ii) Differential stains  This staining method divides bacteria into two groups
(iii) Special stains  These are specialised staining methods to demonstrate certain bacterial components., e.g., spore.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="d30ab025">♦ SIMPLE STAINING METHODS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#d30ab025" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Simple staining methods are used to demonstrate the presence and the morphology of bacteria and cells. They employ simple stains most of which are also used as counterstains. Few of these methods may contain a mordant, e.g., phenol in carbol thionin.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="methylene-blue-stains">Methylene Blue Stains<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#methylene-blue-stains" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Neutral methylene blue, Loeffler’s alkaline methylene blue and polychrome methylene blue solutions are all used in like manner and with almost similar results. The polychrome methylene blue is particularly useful for the identification of anthrax bacilli by Mcfadyean reaction.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="methylene-blue-preparation">Methylene blue: Preparation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#methylene-blue-preparation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<table><thead><tr><th>Loeffler’s alkaline methylene blue</th><th></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Saturated solution:</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>methylene blue</td><td>1.5 g.</td></tr><tr><td>95% alcohol</td><td>100 ml</td></tr><tr><td>Staining solution</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Sat. methylene blue</td><td>30 ml</td></tr><tr><td>Pot. hydroxide</td><td>1 ml</td></tr><tr><td>Dist. water</td><td>90</td></tr><tr><td>Filter before use.</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="staining-procedure">Staining Procedure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#staining-procedure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Stain the heat-fixed smear for one minute.</li>
<li>Wash with water.</li>
<li>Blot carefully and dry.</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>Results</strong>  Bacteria and cells: blue</p>
<p>&gt; <strong>Note</strong>  Loeffler’s alkaline methylene blue stains more intensely than the neutral solution of methylene blue and may show metachromatic effect as well.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="carbol-thionin-staining-method">Carbol Thionin Staining Method<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#carbol-thionin-staining-method" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Solution</strong></p>
<p>Thionin: 1 g
Phenol (2.5 % aqueous solution): 100 ml
For use, dilute 1 in 4 with distilled water, and filter.</p>
<p><strong>Procedure</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Heat fix the smear.</li>
<li>Flood slide with diluted carbol-thionin solution.</li>
<li>Heat until steam just begins to rise and leave for five minutes.</li>
<li>Wash in running tap water.</li>
<li>Blot and dry.</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>Result</strong></p>
<p>Bacteria: blue
Others: light blue.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="4a85011c">♦ DIFFERENTIAL STAINING METHODS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#4a85011c" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="c6763ca0">1. Gram’s Stain<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#c6763ca0" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>In 1884, Christian Gram, a Danish bacteriologist, described this staining method which is the most important stain in routine bacteriology. It divides bacteria into two groups: the Gram positive and Gram negative bacteria.</p>
<p>The Gram positive organism must have an intact cell wall. A damaged cell wall inevitably results in Gram negative reaction. This shows the importance of cell wall in Gram stain reaction. The</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>538 Bacteriology</p>
<p>Gram’s stain reaction is based on the ability of the organism to resist decolourisation with acetone, alcohol or aniline oil after the initial staining with one of the rosaniline basic dyes and then treating with a mordant. The rosaniline dyes commonly used are crystal violet, methyl violet and gentian violet. Iodine is the mordant used.</p>
<p>Grams staining method involves four steps:</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Primary staining A primary stain such as crystal violet stains all the bacteria in the smear.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Mordanting Application of a mordant such as Lugol’s iodine results in the formation of a complex with the primary stain.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Decolourisation Some bacteria resist removal of the dye-iodine complex with the decolourising agent and retain the primary stain. These are called Gram positive bacteria. On the other hand, Gram negative bacteria get decolourised with the decolourising agent.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Counterstaining A counterstain, contrasting in colour with the primary stain, is used to stain Gram negative bacteria which are decolourised in the third step.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>Gram positive bacteria In a Gram stained smear, Gram positive bacteria which retain the primary stain, appear violet or deep purple in colour. The Gram positive reaction is due to the presence of tecnoic acid in the cell wall. The tecnoic acid forms a mesh which prevents the primary stain-mordant complex from being washed away by the decolouring agent.</p>
<p>Gram negative bacteria These appear red. Gram negative bacteria have a high lipid content which dissolves in the decolourising agent. This allows the primary stain-mordant complex to be washed off. The red counterstain makes the decolourised Gram negative bacteria visible in a contrast colour.</p>
<p>Table 3.1 shows Gram stain reaction of common pathogenic bacteria.</p>
<p><strong>Note</strong> (i) Most Gram positive organisms lose their Gram positivity with age and tend to become Gram negative.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-61283317.jpeg" alt="img-11.jpeg"></p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Microscopic Examination of Bacteria 539</p>
