<p>Because anaerobes lack catalase, they are destroyed by the <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{H}_2\mathrm{O}_2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">H</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">O</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>. And since <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{H}_2\mathrm{O}_2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> is not produced in the absence of <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{O}_2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">O</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>, the anaerobes are able to grow in an atmosphere devoid of <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{O}_2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">O</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>. The growth is dependent on the oxidation reduction (redox) potential of the environment. To determine this, immerse an electrode in the solution and measure the electrical potential set up between the electrode and the solution. The potential is known as Eh and is expressed in millivolts. The level of Eh depends on how much oxidation is taking place. When the Eh is below a certain level, the strict anaerobes are able to grow in the medium. Chemical indicators such as methylene blue can be used as an alternative method to the electrical measurement of Eh. Complete decolourisation of the indicator means low Eh and optimum anaerobiasis for growth.</p>
<p>Anaerobiasis can also be achieved by using anaerobic jar system (Fig. 5.11).</p>

Fig. 5.11 Anaerobic system</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="bacterial-division">BACTERIAL DIVISION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bacterial-division" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Bacterial growth is the consequence of balanced or orderly increase in size and number of bacteria. This increase is fuelled by energy, usually in the form of ATP derived during metabolic activity. When a newly formed bacterium gradually increases in size to a certain stage, it begins to form a septum by binary fission, which begins the process of dividing into two daughter cells. This process is known as mitosis. The mitotic division is an asexual reproduction.</p>
<p>The mitotic cell division is a form of nuclear division in which the cell's entire set of chromosomes is duplicated and two new sets separate to form two identical daughter cells. The whole process of mitosis is a continuous orderly sequence of steps with each phase merging into the next phase. Figure 5.12 shows mitosis by bacteria. The mitotic division occurs in five steps:</p>
<ol>
<li>Interphase Between mitosis, the cells are said to be in the 'resting' stage. It is also the period that the organism is 'settling' down in the medium.</li>
<li>Prophase At this stage, the chromosomes condense into thread like structures and become visible later on as two chromosomes joined at the centre by a ring of protein called the centromere. At the same time, the centrioles migrate to opposite sides of the cell, and mitotic spindle begins to form between them.</li>
<li>Metaphase Here, the chromosomes appear to be attached by their centromeres to the spindle fibres. They are completely condensed and lined up in the equatorial region of the spindle which now stretches from one pole of the cell to the other. A division of the centromere of each chromosome occurs and makes the two daughter chromosomes in each set become completely separate.</li>
<li>Anaphase The anaphase is a short phase during which the daughter chromosomes move to either side of the cell, using the spindle fibres as guide rails.</li>
<li>Telophase At this stage, the two sets of chromosomes arrive at the two poles of the spindle. Now, there are two daughter cells from a single cell.</li>
</ol>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Nutrition, Growth and Metabolism of Bacteria 567</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-8b9c291d.jpeg" alt="img-29.jpeg">
Fig. 5.12 Mitosis</p>
<p>gle parent cell, and the daughter cells have the same number and kind of chromosomes and genes as their parent cell. The two cells eventually separate completely.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="bacterial-growth-cycle">BACTERIAL GROWTH CYCLE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bacterial-growth-cycle" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>If a single bacterium is transferred into a fresh medium, then by binary fission, the increase in number of bacteria in the medium is as follows: <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">2</span><span style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">4</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: cells, two cells divide to yield 4 and so on.</p>
<p>This may be expressed as a geometric progression:</p>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>→</mo><msup><mn>2</mn><mn>1</mn></msup><mo>→</mo><msup><mn>2</mn><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>→</mo><msup><mn>2</mn><mn>3</mn></msup><mo>→</mo><msup><mn>2</mn><mn>4</mn></msup><mo>→</mo><msup><mn>2</mn><mn>5</mn></msup><mo>−</mo><mo>→</mo><msup><mn>2</mn><mi>n</mi></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1 \rightarrow 2^{1} \rightarrow 2^{2} \rightarrow 2^{3} \rightarrow 2^{4} \rightarrow 2^{5} - \rightarrow 2^{n}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8641em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">2</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8641em;"><span style="top: -3.113em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">2</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8641em;"><span style="top: -3.113em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">5</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7144em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">2</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7144em;"><span style="top: -3.113em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">n</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<p>where the exponent <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>n</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">n</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">n</span></span></span></span></span> refers to the number of generation. The <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>2</mn><mi>n</mi></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">2^{n}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6644em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">2</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6644em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">n</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> is an algebraic expression for the final number of cells produced in a given culture medium. Thus the total number of cells in the medium after active growth is represented by <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>2</mn><mi>n</mi></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">2^{n}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6644em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">2</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6644em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">n</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>. Active growth is when there is no cell death and the bacterial populations grow exponentially.</p>
<p><strong>Generation time</strong> The length of time it takes for a single bacterial cell to divide or for the population in a culture medium to double is called the generation time. Different organisms have different generation times. The generation time for <em>Escherichia coli</em> in a rich medium is as short as 12.5 minutes, and for <em>Mycobacterium tuberculosis</em> it is 13 to 15 hours. Generation times are seriously affected by the quality and quantity of the culture medium and also by the physical conditions of incubation.</p>
<p>Over a period of incubation, it is easy to calculate the number of generations, the generation and the growth rate (i.e. number of generations per hour). With this knowledge, the growth of bacteria can be quantified and expressed mathematically. Figure 5.13 shows growth rate of bacterial population plotted on arithmetic scale.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Bacteriology</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-02758a06.jpeg" alt="img-30.jpeg">
Fig. 5.13 Arithmetic curve of growth rate of bacteria</p>
<p>All combined, the various phases of bacterial growth in a culture medium gives a typical growth curve. The curve is obtained if a medium is inoculated with a known number of bacterial cells and the population of bacteria determined at time intervals. There are four phases in a bacterial growth cycle (Fig. 5.14).</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Lag phase In this phase, the organism takes time to adjust to the new environment. Though not dividing, the organism is metabolically active, repairing damaged components and synthesising enzymes.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Logarithmic or exponential growth phase This is a period of balanced growth that follows the lag phase. It is usually referred to as log phase which is a period of multiplication by geometric progression. The bacteria are dividing at a constant and maximum rate. The number of bacteria growing and dividing is more than those dying.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Stationary phase After a time, maximum population occurs, resulting in crowding, nutrient exhaustion and toxicity of waste products. Eventually, the bacteria begin to die and there is a balance between dead and living bacteria. This means that the number of bacteria multiplying is equal to those dying. The growth rate of the population is zero.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Decline phase Within a short time, the number of cells dying becomes higher than those multiplying. Although the population as a whole may be dying, many individual cells may still be viable and so can grow again when subcultured onto a fresh medium.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="bacterial-colony-formation-on-a-solid-medium">Bacterial Colony Formation on a Solid Medium<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bacterial-colony-formation-on-a-solid-medium" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The sequential cell divisions of a single bacterium on a solid medium give rise to a colony. The same</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Nutrition, Growth and Metabolism of Bacteria 569</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-0624efe3.jpeg" alt="img-31.jpeg">
Fig. 5.14 Bacterial growth curve</p>
<p>growth cycle is followed as in a liquid medium (Fig. 5.14). However, the bacterial cells clump together forming a discrete mass called colony (Fig. 5.15).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="bacterial-metabolism">BACTERIAL METABOLISM<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bacterial-metabolism" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Metabolism, generally speaking, describes all the chemical reactions that take place in the cell. It is divided into two parts:</p>
<p>Anabolism (biosynthesis) This involves the assimilation of nutrients and construction of new cell material. Important biological molecules or polymers are made of building blocks that are joined together by chemical bonds to form the polymers. Polysaccharides are formed from simple sugars, nucleic acids from nucleotides and proteins from amino acids (Fig. 5.16). The assemblage of these complex molecules from the small molecules is the anabolic activity. This activity requires energy.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-20f6da88.jpeg" alt="img-32.jpeg">
Fig. 5.15 Bacterial colony formation on agar medium</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Bacteriology</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-bf573942.jpeg" alt="img-33.jpeg">
Fig. 5.16 Chemical composition of important biological polymers</p>
<p>Catabolism (dissimilation) This includes all the chemical reactions of the cell that result in the break down of nutrients (organic molecules) into simpler molecules. During the break down of many organic molecules, e.g., glucose to lactic acid, energy is released. Some of the energy can be stored in the nucleotides until when needed, e.g., adenosine triphosphate (ATP). The energy is used to fuel anabolic reactions.</p>
<p>There are several ways in which bacteria conserve energy in the form of ATP molecules and how these molecules are used to fuel biosynthetic reactions.</p>
<p>Metabolism of a nutrient by bacteria is in four stages (Fig. 5.17).</p>
<p>Stage 1 This is the breakdown of large molecules into small ones. This breakdown is by hydrolysis.</p>
<p>Stage 2 This involves the transport of small molecules into the cell. It may require cellular energy for the action (active transport system).</p>
<p>Stage 3 This is the stage of partial oxidation of the small molecules with the production of chemical energy (ATP). The resulting protons and electrons from the oxidation are donated to coenzymes such as nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD) or flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD). Also, the energy generated from the break down of glucose is conserved in molecules of ATP.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Nutrition, Growth and Metabolism of Bacteria 571</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-ff4b320c.jpeg" alt="img-34.jpeg">
Fig. 5.17 Stages of metabolism of nutrients</p>
<p>Stage 4 This involves the complete oxidation of food molecules with subsequent production of more ATP.</p>
<p>All cellular reactions are coordinated and catalysed by enzymes. Nutrients found in the environment are used by the bacteria as a source of energy and building blocks for growth and reproduction. Enzymes regulate the rate of all chemical reactions by reducing the amount of energy known as activation energy. The enzymes that promote the transportation of nutrients into the cell are collectively known as permeases. The energy required for cellular activities may be obtained from light (phototrophy) or from chemical bonds (chemotrophy). The hydrolysis of ATP results in the net output of energy. This is the energy that is obtained from the metabolism and oxidation of fuel molecules.</p>
<p>Many bacteria dissimilate monosaccharides especially the 6 carbon sugar glucose. There are different kinds of metabolic pathways for glucose degradation but the most common is the glycosis or the Embden-Meyerhof-Parnas pathway: A molecule of glucose is broken down to two molecules of pyruvic acid.</p>
<p>Ten different reactions, such as catalysed by different enzymes, occur along the glycolytic pathway. These enzymes are cytochrome enzymes found in the cytoplasm. In the first three reactions there is no oxidation, i.e. removal of electrons or protons and 2ATP molecules are used.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Bacteriology</p>
<p>During the rest of the reactions, oxidation takes place. One molecule of the coenzyme nicotinamide adenosine dinucleotide (NAD) is used in the oxidation to form reduced NAD(NADH₂). The oxidation results in the formation of four ATP molecules. Therefore, since two ATP molecules were used to initiate the process, there is a net gain of two ATP molecules.</p>
<p>Fermentation Fermentation is a process free of oxygen during which the reduced NAD (NADH₂) produced during glycolysis or any other pathway is used to reduce an organic electron acceptor. Bacteria produce various end products during fermentation in order to dispose off their excess electrons. Figure 5.18 shows the outline of some fermentation pathways. It also shows that no single</p>
<p>bacterium has all the enzymes required for all the pathways. The by-products of fermentation are often characteristics of the bacteria and can be used as their identification markers.</p>
<p>Respiration The process of regenerating NAD by using NADH₂ as the electron donor for an electron transport system is known as respiration. If oxygen is the final electron acceptor for the electron transport system, the process is called aerobic respiration. In some bacteria, electrons are donated to acceptors other than oxygen such as nitrates, sulphates or iron. This process is the anaerobic respiration.</p>
<p>Figure 5.19 shows the relationship between oxidation, fermentation and anaerobic respiration.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-ab5768c3.jpeg" alt="img-35.jpeg"></p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Nutrition, Growth and Metabolism of Bacteria 573</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-8927bc31.jpeg" alt="img-36.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 5.19 Bacterial metabolic systems and their relationship</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Chapter 6</p>
<p>Bacterial Genetics</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-8e32f250.jpeg" alt="img-37.jpeg"></p>
<p>Genetics is the study of inheritance and variation. The concept of inheritance refers to those processes responsible for the high degree of similarity between parent and offspring. All inherited characteristics exhibited by the microorganisms are encoded in the deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA). With the typical prokaryotic (bacterial) cell, the DNA (which is the chromosome) lacks the nuclear membrane and because its length is about 1200 times that of the entire cell, it is twisted, coiled, double-stranded and packaged into a highly compact form. In addition to the chromosome, the bacterial cell has another DNA structure called plasmid. Plasmids are also double stranded DNA molecules which are smaller than the chromosomes and can replicate independently of the chromosomes. The hereditary information (i.e. genetic code) of a cell is the result of ordered arrangement of purine and pyrimidine nucleotides. DNA replication is therefore the process that copies the nucleotide sequence of a double-stranded parent DNA molecule into two double stranded daughter DNA molecules, each of which will end up in a daughter cell. This process is known as semi-conservative replication. This is because each strand of DNA is conserved intact during replication and becomes one of the two strands of the new daughter cell while the other strand is synthesised. The enzyme, DNA polymerase, is the major enzyme involved in DNA replication. It promotes complimentary activity between nucleotide base of the new DNA strand and a corresponding nucleotide base on the parental DNA strand.</p>
<p>Each strand of DNA functions as a template or pattern that specifies the sequence of bases in the newly formed complementary strand. DNA replication in bacteria starts at a specific site on the DNA strand called the origin.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="transcription-and-translation-of-genetic-information">TRANSCRIPTION AND TRANSLATION OF GENETIC INFORMATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#transcription-and-translation-of-genetic-information" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Genetic messages prompt the production of ribonucleic acid (RNA) and proteins, which are essential components of all living cells. A gene is the unit of the DNA that contains the nucleotide sequence for making the RNA and a particular protein. A DNA molecule contains thousands of genes, one for each protein. The DNA controls its own replication, synthesis of RNA and eventual formation of protein.</p>
<p>Transcription Transcription involves the synthesis of DNA. It is the process whereby the genetic information in DNA is sent to a molecule of messenger ribonucleic acid (mRNA). This transcription involves only one of the two DNA strands. The enzyme responsible for the transcribing of this genetic message is the DNA dependent RNA polymerase. Transcription begins at promoter sites and ends at termination sites on the DNA (Fig. 6.1).</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Bacterial Genetics 575</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-1997d09d.jpeg" alt="img-38.jpeg">
Fig. 6.1 Transcription</p>
<p>Translation It is the function of the ribosomes which are made up of proteins and ribosomal RNA (rRNA) to translate the coded message in the mRNA to produce a particular protein from amino acids. A bacterial ribosome consists of a 50-S subunit and a 30-S subunit which combine during protein synthesis to form a complete 70-S ribosome. The amino acids are first of all energised (activated) with ATP and then linked to the end of special RNA molecules, the transfer RNA (tRNA) which carry the amino acids to the ribosomes. There is a specific tRNA for each of 20 amino acids which, after activation, are carried to the ribosome which links the amino acids together to form a protein. There may be several ribosomes actively involved in translating a single mRNA molecule at the same time. (Fig. 6.2). The actions</p>
<p>that take place in the two processes of transcription and translation can be summarised as:</p>
<ol>
<li>The information in the gene (DNA) is copied to a molecule of mRNA by transcription.</li>
<li>The mRNA carries the transcribed information from the nuclear area of the cell to the ribosomes in the cytoplasm.</li>
<li>The ribosomes then carry out the process of translation whereby the information in the mRNA is used to synthesise the corresponding protein from amino acids.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="genetic-variations-in-bacteria">GENETIC VARIATIONS IN BACTERIA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#genetic-variations-in-bacteria" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Genetic variation is a common occurrence in the bacterial world. It is associated with two funda</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Bacteriology</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-48dbcf1e.jpeg" alt="img-39.jpeg">
Fig. 6.2 Schematic drawing of several ribosomes</p>
<p>mental properties of an organism—its genotype and phenotype. Genotype involves the entire genetic capability of an organism as found in its DNA. This includes the chromosomal DNA and plasmid DNA in the bacterial cell. The genotype represents the inheritable total potential of a cell. The phenotype on the other hand, represents the portion of the genetic potential that is actually expressed by the cell under a given set of conditions, e.g., colour or size of bacterial colony.</p>
<p>Phenotypic changes are influenced by the genotype and the environment of the organism. For instance, bacteria of the genus Proteus when grown in the presence of an electrolyte will swarm all over the medium but will not swarm in the absence of an electrolyte. This shows that some phenotypic changes are caused by changes in the environment rather than by the genetic information in the cell.</p>
<p>Genotypic changes are the result of changes in the DNA. It can be as a result of:</p>
<ol>
<li>Mutation—a change in the nucleotide sequence of a gene or</li>
<li>Recombination—a process that leads to new combinations of genes on a chromosome.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="mutation">Mutation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#mutation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Any gene can undergo chemical alteration in DNA in which one or more bases are changed. This</p>
<p>change is called mutation and is heritable. A cell or an organism having a mutated gene is a mutant, and the parent cell with a normal (non-mutated) gene is called the wild type. The gene defect may lead to:</p>
<ol>
<li>Alteration in the process of transcription.</li>
<li>Alteration in the amino acid sequence of the protein which is the gene product.</li>
</ol>
<p>There are various types of mutation and some are never detected because detection depends on the mutation affecting a recognisable function. Others are lethal and are not detected too. The two common types of mutation are:</p>
<ol>
<li>Point mutation This is the mutation that results from the substitution of one nucleotide for another in a gene.</li>
<li>Frameshift mutation This mutation occurs with either the addition or loss of one or more nucleotides in a gene, and is called insertion mutation or deletion mutation respectively. Figure 6.3 shows the effect of insertion and deletion of a single base on the amino acid sequence of the gene product.</li>
</ol>
<p>Mutation may occur spontaneously without any obvious cause, or as a result of exposure to a mutagen. A mutagen is any agent, physical or chemical, that causes the mutation rate (number of</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Bacterial Genetics 577</p>
<p>mutation per gene per generation) to exceed the normal spontaneous rate. Mutagens affect the DNA by altering its structure and that of its components. Physical mutagens include ultraviolet (UV) light and X-rays, while well known chemical mutagens include nitrous oxide, acridine orange dye and ethyl methane sulphonate. Table 6.1 shows some mutagens and their mode of action.</p>
<p>Some mutagens are also carcinogenic. That is why it is believed that cancer is under some genetic influences. The mutations caused by mutagens are similar to those caused spontaneously. The only difference is in the frequency of occurrence. UV light is often used in the laboratory to induce mutation of cells for research purposes. Cells, however, contain certain specific enzymes that can repair much of the damage done to DNA by mutagens. It is possible therefore for some cells to escape the adverse effects of mutations and are able to continue normal functions. The repairs carried out by enzymes may be the removal of damaged base pairs or of mispaired bases.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-1cf3fe69.jpeg" alt="img-40.jpeg">
Fig. 6.3 Frame shift mutation</p>
<p>Table 6.1 Mutagens and their mode of action</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Mutagen</th><th>Mode of action</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Heat</td><td>Causes chemical changes in the structure of bases</td></tr><tr><td>Chemicals</td><td>Interact directly with the DNA and cause disruptive changes</td></tr><tr><td>Ultraviolet light</td><td>Chemically alters the DNA and stimulates excessive repair</td></tr><tr><td>X-rays, Gamma rays (electromagnetic waves)</td><td>Chemically alter the DNA by ionization and cause disruptive changes and excessive repair</td></tr><tr><td>Radioactive atoms</td><td>Chemically alter the DNA by ionization and cause disruptive changes and excessive repair</td></tr><tr><td>Beta particles</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Alpha particles (subatomic particles)</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>578 Bacteriology</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="recombination">RECOMBINATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#recombination" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Recombination is a process in which there is a genetic transfer between two homologous chromosomes. Homologous chromosomes have similar genes at corresponding sites. Though the genes may be similar, they are not necessarily identical. Such corresponding genes with differing identity are called <em>alleles</em>. But because the bacterial cell contains a single chromosome, a homologous chromosome (usually a portion of it) must first be transferred from a donor bacterium to the recipient bacterium. Since the chromosomes must be similar, therefore the donor and recipient bacteria are usually of the same species or closely related.</p>
<p>There are three ways of gene transfer that can alter DNA gene content and lead to recombination:</p>
<ul>
<li>Transformation</li>
<li>Transduction</li>
<li>Conjugation</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="transformation">Transformation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#transformation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Transformation is when fragments of exogenous or 'free floating' bacterial DNA molecules are taken up and absorbed into recipient cell. It is the similar</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-c30f3b76.jpeg" alt="img-41.jpeg"></p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Bacterial Genetics 579</p>
<p>plest form of gene transfer. Sometimes, the transferring DNA may come from dead cells that lyse and release their DNA into the surrounding medium. It is extracted in the laboratory by chemical methods from a suspension of donor bacteria which is then mixed with the culture of recipient bacteria.</p>
<p>Transformation occurs in bacteria which are competent enough to take up the light molecular weight DNA. It occurs in three stages:</p>
<ol>
<li>Binding of light-molecular-weight DNA to cell surface.</li>
<li>Uptake of the bound DNA through the cell membrane.</li>
<li>Integration of the donor DNA into the recipient cell's chromosomes (Fig. 6.4). It occurs both in Gram positive and Gram negative bacteria.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="transduction">Transduction<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#transduction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>When a fragment of donor chromosome is transferred to the recipient by a bacteriophage (bacterial virus), the process is known as transduction. The bacteriophage (or simply phage) consists of a nucleic acid (usually DNA), surrounded by a protein coat to form a head, and a tail. The tail is used to attach the phage to the surface of a susceptible bacterium. It takes place in both Gram positive and Gram negative organisms. The phage injects its DNA into the host cell and the injected DNA begins to replicate rapidly while the host DNA is degraded. From there on, the phage DNA directs the synthesis of new phage proteins by the host cell (Fig. 6.5). During replication of a bacteriophage, a fragment of bacterial DNA may accidentally become enclosed within a phage particle instead of the normal phage DNA. When this phage particle infects a second bacterial host cell, the DNA from the first bacterium is released and becomes recombined into the chromosome of the second bacterium. This leads to a new combination of genes on the chromosome.</p>
<p>It is also possible to transfer plasmid DNA via transduction. The transduced plasmid can then function and replicate independently, that is without having to recombine into the chromosome of the bacterial cell.</p>
<p>Transduction can either be generalised, when the phage has roughly equal chance of carrying</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-627237f1.jpeg" alt="img-42.jpeg">
Fig. 6.5 Transduction</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Bacteriology</p>
<p>any segment of the donor's chromosomes; or restricted, when the transducing particles carry only those fragments that are immediately adjacent to the site of phage attachment.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="conjugation">Conjugation<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#conjugation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Conjugation is a process of gene transfer involving cell to cell contact. This characteristic distinguishes it from transduction and transformation. In conjugation, DNA may be transferred directly from one bacterium to another, the DNA may be chromosomal or plasmid. The plasmid transfer takes place via a hollow tube formed by a sex pilus (Fig. 6.6). Plasmid <em>tra</em> genes encode the formation of the pilus.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-8df9e4bb.jpeg" alt="img-43.jpeg">
Fig. 6.6 Transfer of DNA during conjugation of bacteria</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="plasmids">PLASMIDS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#plasmids" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Plasmids are small extra chromosomal genetic elements hosted by many bacteria. They are not usually necessary for host survival but they assume some measure of importance when the genes they carry confer new properties on the host. Plasmids are circular double-stranded DNA molecules. Their molecular weights range from <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>3</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mn>10</mn><mn>6</mn></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">3 \times 10^{6}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">3</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">0</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">6</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> to <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mn>10</mn><mn>8</mn></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1 \times 10^{8}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">0</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">8</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>. They replicate independently. They are generally named according to the functions they perform or the properties they impart to the host.</p>
<p>Conjugative plasmids are those transmitted by conjugation from bacteria to bacteria. Such a plasmid is the <em>E. coli</em> F (F for fertility) plasmid described below. Non conjugative plasmids are not transferred by conjugation but by transduction, or by transformation. These plasmids can be transferred to a recipient cell by the co-operation of conjugative plasmids which may be co-existing with them in the same cell.</p>
<p>Some specific functions of the plasmids are:</p>
<ol>
<li><strong>Sex factors</strong> The donor cell carries a plasmid called F plasmid which contains about 40 genes that control the plasmid replication. It also controls the synthesis of the sex pilus. The most widely studied is the F sex factor of <em>E. coli</em> K 12.</li>
</ol>
<p>Cells containing F plasmid (donors cells) are called F⁺ cells, while the cells (recipient cells) that lack the F plasmid are the F⁻ cells. In a mixture of F⁺ and F⁻ cells, the end of the F⁺ sex pilus binds to a nearby F⁻ cell and then retracts, thereby pulling the F⁻ and F⁺ cells into close contact (Fig. 6.7). A bridge, sex pilus, is formed between the two cells through which one DNA strand from the donor cell's F plasmid is transferred to the F⁻ (recipient) cell. Once this is accomplished, the DNA strand serves as a template for the synthesis of a second, complementary DNA strand. The ends of the double-stranded DNA molecule then join to form the typical circular F plasmid, thus the recipient cell now becomes an F⁺ (donor) cell capable of donating DNA. In this way, the process of conjugation (recombination) continues until all the F⁻ cells are converted to F⁺ cells.</p>
<p>Usually, it is only the donor's F plasmid that moves to the F⁻ cell in an F⁺ × F⁻ cross. It is not common for chromosomal genes to be transferred along with F plasmid, it occurs only in about 1 in 10 million recombinations. There are however cells that can transfer chromosomal genes at a much faster rate—about 1000 times greater than those transferred by the usual F⁺ cells. These cells in which these fast rates take place are called high-frequency recombination (Hfr) cells. They are F⁺ cells whose F plasmid has become integrated into the bacterial chromosome (Fig. 6.8). This means that the plasmid is no longer capable of independent replication. In an Hfr and F⁻ mixture, the frequency of gene recombination is high while the transfer of the F plasmid is low.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Bacterial Genetics 581</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-5f65e13b.jpeg" alt="img-44.jpeg">
Fig. 6.7 Transfer of DNA during conjugation of bacteria from F⁺ to F⁻ cell</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>
<p>Col factors or bacteriocinogenic plasmid
The genes carried by these plasmids direct the host bacterium to produce certain protein that kills bacteria belonging to the same or closely related species and lacking the plasmid. This protein is called colicin or bacteriocin. The bacterium producing a particular bacteriocin is not killed by the bacteriocin though it can be killed by any other bacteriocin. They are used to type the different subgroups of bacteria such as <em>E. coli</em> and <em>Pseudomonas</em> species. They are thus useful in determining the source of infection during an outbreak.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>R (resistance) factor or R plasmid
This plasmid carries the gene that confers on the host bacterium resistance to antibiotics. Such antibiotic resistance genes code for an enzyme that destroys or inactivates a particular antibiotic. For example, most strains of <em>Staphylococcus aureus</em> isolated in hospitals contain an R plasmid containing a gene that codes for β lactamase which is an enzyme that inactivates penicillin and many of its derivatives. Some of the R plasmids are conjugative plasmids which readily transfer antibiotic resistance genes directly to other bacteria by conjugation. This is of great medical importance because it renders the treatment of infections very difficult.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Dissimilation or degradative plasmids
These carry sets of genes that code for enzymes of catabolic pathway. These enzymes are responsible for the ability of certain <em>Pseudomonas</em> species to break down difficult or degrade complex hydrocarbons and industrial solvents such as toluene, oc</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Bacteriology</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-cd3afe2a.jpeg" alt="img-45.jpeg">
Fig. 6.8 Integration and reversion of <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mi>F</mi><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">F^{+}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7713em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.13889em;">F</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7713em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> plasmid</p>
<p>tane or xylene. Some of these bacteria are also capable of degrading certain compounds present in crude oil. These so called 'oil eating' bacteria can be employed for treatment of an environment contaminated by oil spills.</p>
<ol start="5">
<li>
<p>Replication With some plasmids, replication can only occur in a few species of closely related bacteria. Others may have a much wider host range. Plasmid DNA replicates while still maintaining its physical shape.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Incompatibility There are some plasmids that cannot coexist in the same cell with certain other plasmids. They are so selective that they are classified into a number of incompatibility groups. Two members of different groups cannot coexist in the same cell even though they may be closely related.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="transposons">Transposons<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#transposons" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>These are also referred to as 'jumping genes'. They are segments of DNA that can transpose or move very readily from plasmid to plasmid or from plasmid to chromosome and vice versa. Transferring to a new site does not affect the original transposon which remains in situ. It is a copy of the transposon that actually moves.</p>
<p>Transposon is a member of the group of transposable elements. These elements are flanked on both sides by DNA sequences that consist of inverted or direct repeat sequences that are able to translocate and insert into DNA. Figure 6.6 is the diagram of gene transfer by conjugation, Fig. 6.9 shows the movement of transposon DNA. Transposons have no existence in the free state, but</p>
<p>only exist in integrated form within the plasmid or chromosomes. They cannot mediate gene transfer between bacterial cells.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="polymerase-chain-reaction-pcr">Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#polymerase-chain-reaction-pcr" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The laboratory procedure called polymerase chain reaction (PCR) is one of the most significant achievements in molecular biology. With this procedure, it is possible to make several copies of one or more genes from very tiny initial amounts of DNA. Large quantities of DNA can be made from very small amounts present in substances such as water, food, blood, hairs and a host of clinical samples. This phenomenon has a great application in microbiology, e.g., for making clinical diagnosis and for solving medico-legal problems. The PCR</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-ce7a23e5.jpeg" alt="img-46.jpeg"></p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Bacterial Genetics 583</p>
<p>is a wonderful tool in the diagnosis of genetic disorder, such as sickle cell diseases, in a foetus. It is particularly useful in detecting infection by the AIDS virus when other methods have failed.</p>
<p>The technique is based on the amplification of trace amount of DNA to very large amounts. The first material for a PCR is a part of the double-stranded DNA containing a nucleotide sequence with the target gene. The procedure roughly follows the following stages:</p>
<ol>
<li>The DNA is heated to separate the two strands. This DNA contains the target genes.</li>
<li>Short synthetic pieces of DNA (primers) are added. Each primer has a nucleotide sequence that is complementary to a particular part at the end of the gene to be amplified.</li>
<li>The primer/DNA mixture is cooled to allow the primers bind to the gene (annealing).</li>
<li>The enzyme DNA polymerase adds the energised nucleotides one at a time to one end of each primer and synthesises a long strand of complementary DNA.</li>
<li>Two copies of the gene are formed at the end of the cycle from each initial copy.</li>
</ol>
<p>Subsequent cycles are carried out in a similar way. The number of copies of the target gene increases exponentially with each cycle; 2, 4, 8, 16, 32 and so on. Within a short space of time millions of copies can be made, and that will be enough to be easily analysed in the laboratory (Fig. 6.10). PCR is yet to become a routine laboratory procedure. But its potential as a tool for detection and diagnosis of infections is enormous.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-c4bc55f7.jpeg" alt="img-47.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 6.10 Gene amplification by PCR</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Chapter 7 Principles of Culture Media</p>
<p>To study and identify micro-organisms, they have to be cultivated and isolated in pure culture. Most bacteria can be cultured in artificial media if the media meet the nutritional and physical growth requirements of the bacteria.</p>
<p>The media used for growing bacteria are either liquid or solid media. They must contain water and sources of nitrogen, carbon, mineral salts and essential vitamins. Some bacteria may require additional specific substances which may be added to the medium. There are two categories of culture media. They are the chemically defined or simple medium and the chemically undefined or complex medium.</p>
<p>Chemically defined media are those in which the concentration of each ingredient is known. The ingredients are usually highly purified inorganic salts and simple organic compounds such as glucose or purified amino acids. These media are valuable in that there is little or no variation in composition from batch to batch. They are however very expensive and not meant for routine use. They are used to determine specific growth requirements of bacteria.</p>
<p>Complex media are those prepared using natural products such as meat extract or vegetable infusions. The natural products contain essential bacterial nutrients but the exact concentration of nutrient is unknown. Complex culture media are used routinely because they are easy to prepare, relatively cheap and able to support the growth of many bacteria.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="composition-of-culture-media">COMPOSITION OF CULTURE MEDIA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#composition-of-culture-media" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="water">Water<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#water" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Water is the main solvent for most of the ingredients used in the preparation of culture media. It must not contain substances that may inhibit the growth of bacteria. Preferably deionised or distilled water should be used to prepare culture media.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="peptone">Peptone<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#peptone" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Peptone is the water soluble product of protein hydrolysis. Proteins in meat, milk, and soya bean are hydrolysed by acids or by the enzymatic actions of enzymes such as pepsin, trypsin, and papain. All forms of peptone are heat stable. Peptone from animal protein is the source of nitrogen in the medium, the soya bean (plant) protein is a source of carbohydrates.</p>
<p>A good brand of peptone must have the following qualities:</p>
<ol>
<li>Must have a neutral pH</li>
<li>Must be light in colour</li>
<li>Must be hygroscopic</li>
<li>Must contain large amount of tryptophan for indole production.</li>
</ol>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Principles of Culture Media 585</p>
<p>Certain forms of peptone are used for specific purposes, e.g., protease peptone is used in media for toxin production; and tryptone is used to enrich media with amino acids.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="meat-extracts">Meat Extracts<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#meat-extracts" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Lab Lemco is a commercially available meat extract and is incorporated into culture media as a source of amino acids and other essential vitamins and elements. Infused or enzyme-digested meat extracts are also used for the same purpose.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="yeast-extract">Yeast Extract<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#yeast-extract" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Yeast extract acts as a stimulant for bacterial growth in the culture media. This function is amply performed in thiosulphate citrate bile salt sucrose (TCBS) medium.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="mineral-salts">Mineral Salts<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#mineral-salts" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Many trace elements are required by bacteria for their enzyme activity. These elements are derived from some salts: sulphates are the sources of sulphur; and phosphates as sources of phosphorus. Many culture media also contain traces of magnesium, potassium, iron, calcium and other elements which are utilised for enzyme activity. Sodium chloride is also an important constituent of many media; it helps to maintain the isotonicity of the medium.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="carbohydrates">Carbohydrates<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#carbohydrates" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Carbohydrates serve as sources of carbon and energy in culture media. They may also be added to the culture media to perform some specific functions. For example, lactose is added to CLED (Cystine lactose electrolyte deficient) medium and MacConkey agar to differentiate the lactose-fermenting organisms from the non-lactose fermenting ones.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="types-of-media">TYPES OF MEDIA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#types-of-media" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>There are several types and forms of culture media.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="liquid-media-or-broth">Liquid Media or Broth<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#liquid-media-or-broth" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>In liquid media, bacteria can freely move about. The growth and multiplication of bacteria in liquid media is described in Chapter 5. Growth in liquid medium is shown by turbidity, though some organisms show surface growth.</p>
<p>Liquid media are used mainly for biochemical testing, blood culture, testing for motility and as enrichment media. The major disadvantage is that purity of the growth cannot be guaranteed.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="solid-media">Solid Media<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#solid-media" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>When organisms are grown on solid media, they grow and multiply at the site of inoculation and form visible colonies. Colonial appearance and any changes in the surrounding medium help in the identification of the bacterial species.</p>
<p>A liquid medium is made solid by the incorporation of a solidifying agent which does not alter the nutritional content of the medium. The most widely used solidifying agent is the agar (formerly called agar-agar). Agar is an inert carbohydrate extract obtained from a type of seaweed found in Japan, New Zealand, and California (USA). It is available in powder form.</p>
<p>A good brand of agar must:</p>
<ol>
<li>gel at a concentration of 1%</li>
<li>melt at 98°C</li>
<li>set on cooling at 42°C</li>
<li>be easily soluble and maintain clarity in solution.</li>
</ol>
<p>Another solidifying agent that can be used is gelatin. This is a protein derived from collagen of skin and bone. It gels at a concentration of 12–15% in nutrient broth; melts at 22°C and is denatured by prolonged exposure to 100°C. Some bacteria are able to liquefy gelatin at 37°C, and this property is used to identify such bacteria.</p>
<p>Agar has the following advantages over gelatin:</p>
<ol>
<li>It is solid at 37°C</li>
<li>Once solidified, it can be remelted</li>
</ol>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>586 Bacteriology</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>It is bacteriologically inert and so is not attacked by most bacteria</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="basal-media">Basal Media<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#basal-media" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Basal media are simple media that will support the growth of most micro organisms that do not need special nutritional requirements. They contain the basic nutrients: peptone, mineral salts and water. They are generally referred to as nutrient broths. Nutrient broths may be in the following forms:</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="infusion-broth">Infusion Broth<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#infusion-broth" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is a watery extract of fat-free minced meat which has been infused overnight at 4°C. The extract is filtered, peptone and salt added and pH adjusted to 8.0. The filtrate is boiled to remove phosphates and pH readjusted to 7.4. The medium is then bottled and sterilised.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="digest-broth">Digest Broth<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#digest-broth" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is an enzyme-digested meat broth: Fresh fat-free minced meat is placed in sodium carbonate which neutralises any sarcolactic acid in the meat. The mixture is heated and cooled to 45°C. Trypsin is added to digest the meat. The digestion may last between 4–6 hours. Chloroform is added as a preservative to prevent putrefaction; and is easily removed at a later stage with heat. Trypsin digests the meat protein to peptone; and concentrated hydrochloric acid is added to stop the digestion when the end point of digestion is reached. The broth is then boiled and filtered; the pH adjusted to 7.4. The medium is bottled and sterilised.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="enriched-media">Enriched Media<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#enriched-media" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Enriched media are culture media that are enriched with whole or lysed blood, serum, special extracts or nutrients to support the growth of those bacteria that cannot grow on the basal media. Examples are blood agar, serum agar, chocolate agar:</p>
<p>Nutrient broth + agar = Nutrient agar</p>
<p>Nutrient agar + blood = Blood agar</p>
<p>Blood agar + heat = Chocolate agar</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="selective-media">Selective Media<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#selective-media" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Selective media are solid media which contain substances that prevent, slow down or inhibit the growth of micro-organisms other than those for which the media are devised. Examples of selective media are:</p>
<ol>
<li>Tellurite medium for diphtheria organism</li>
<li>Deoxycholate citrate agar (DCA) for Salmonella and Shigella groups.</li>
</ol>
<p>Antibiotics are also widely used to make a medium selective.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="enrichment-media">Enrichment Media<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#enrichment-media" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These are liquid media that are similar in function to the selective media. The only difference is that selective media are solid. Example of enrichment medium is selenite F broth which is used for the isolation of Salmonella group of bacteria.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="differential-media">Differential Media<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#differential-media" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These media contain substances or indicators that will differentiate one organism from another. Examples are:</p>
<ol>
<li>MacConkey agar will differentiate lactose fermenting bacteria from non-lactose fermenting ones.</li>
<li>Blood agar will differentiate haemolytic bacteria from non-haemolytic ones.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="auxanographic-media">Auxanographic Media<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#auxanographic-media" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These media are deficient in certain nutritional requirements. The auxanographic media will require special growth factors in order to support the growth of some bacteria. When the medium is inoculated with an organism, and certain growth factors are spotted on the surface of the medium, the growth of the organism occurs only in or around the factors. This indicates that the organism relies on the factors for growth. For example,</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Principles of Culture Media 587</p>
<p>Haemophilus influenzae will only grow on nutrient agar in the vicinity of X+V factors.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="transport-media">Transport Media<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#transport-media" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Transport media as the name indicates, are meant for the transportation of clinical specimens containing delicate micro-organisms from the ward or clinic to the laboratory if there is to be a delay in their delivery to the laboratory or in processing. They contain substances that can prevent the overgrowth of commensals and prevent bacteria from dying as a result of change of pH or enzyme action. They are generally semisolid. Examples are:</p>
<ol>
<li>Amies transport medium for Neisseria gonorrhoeae.</li>
<li>Stuart’s transport medium for delicate organisms including anaerobes.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ff17f9d1">♦ PREPARATION OF CULTURE MEDIA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ff17f9d1" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Almost all laboratories prepare their culture media from either dried or dehydrated products or use ready-made media which are available commercially. The preparation of media from raw materials is no longer practised in routine laboratories. There are many advantages using dehydrated products or the ready-to-use culture media:</p>
<ol>
<li>They are easy to prepare</li>
<li>They give good performance</li>
<li>They are highly standardised</li>
<li>They ensure reproducibility</li>
<li>They are cheaper.</li>
</ol>
