<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="1-growth-in-anaerobic-media">1. Growth in Anaerobic Media<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-growth-in-anaerobic-media" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>There is a good number of culture media which are either specifically designed for anaerobic cultivation or made 'anaerobic' prior to inoculating. Some of the well known anaerobic media are:</p>
<p>(a) Thioglycollate broth (Brewer's medium) (Chapter 25).
(b) Robertson's cooked meat medium (Chapter 25).
(c) Smith-Noguchi medium (Chapter 25).
(d) Glucose broth: Long thin tubes are filled with glucose broth, boiled for 5 minutes to remove trapped oxygen; and the surface of the medium is covered with sterile molten vaseline. This prevents air from going in, and inoculation is made through the layer of the vaseline.
(e) Iron strips: Iron strips, when heated to redness, cooled and added to liquid media, will oxidise in the medium using up all the oxygen and so create an anaerobic condition.
(f) Fortner's plates: Two culture plates are inoculated, one with a strict aerobic organism and the other with a strict anaerobic organism. With the lids off, the two plates are taped facing each other. The principle is that the aerobic organism will use up all oxygen in the atmosphere, thereby creating an anaerobic situation that will enable the anaerobic organism to grow. This method is obsolete.
(g) Buchner's tube: A special container in which is placed a culture plate inoculated with an anaerobic organism and a tube of pyrogallic acid. The bottom of the container contains sodium hydroxide (NaOH). The container is tilted to spill the acid on the NaOH. The reaction that follows uses up all the oxygen in the tube and creates an anaerobic situation to allow the growth of the anaerobe. Like the Fortner's plate, the method is no longer in use.
(h) Pre-reduced anaerobically sterilised (PRAS) media: These media which are available commercially, are made by adding the media constituents, boiling off the dissolved air and then replacing the remaining air in the tube with an oxygen free gas.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="the-anaerobic-jar">The Anaerobic Jar<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-anaerobic-jar" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The best general method for plate anaerobic cultivation is the use of the anaerobic jar. For many years, the McIntosh and Filde's Jar was the best available. The jar is a seamless metal or plastic vessel, big enough to contain petri dishes and culture tubes (Fig. 8.3). It is fitted with an air tight lid which has an inlet and an outlet valve. The lid is fitted with a clamp for tightening the lid. The lid also has on its inner surface, a room-temperature catalyst enclosed within a wire gauze envelope. The catalyst is composed of pellets of aluminia coated with 0.5% pallidium. It catalyses the reaction of oxygen in the jar with hydrogen to form water.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="method-of-use">Method of use<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#method-of-use" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>Place the plate or tube cultures in the jar. It is important to loosen the screw-valves. Tighten the clamp on the lid.</li>
<li>Close the inlet valve and connect the outlet valve to a vacuum pump and evacuate to about 10 mm of mercury (monitored on the attached gauge).</li>
</ol>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-6eb6cf3e.jpeg" alt="img-57.jpeg">
Fig. 8.3 McIntosh and Filde's Jar</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>608 Bacteriology</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>
<p>Disconnect the vacuum pump and observe the gauge for three minutes. If the reading falls, then there is probably a leakage and so check the lid washer and valve sealings. After evacuation, the clamp of the jar lid becomes loose. Close the valve.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Connect the inlet valve to an external source of hydrogen or preferably a mixture of carbon dioxide, hydrogen and nitrogen. A simple way of doing this is to fill a football bladder with the gas. A wash bottle may be connected so that the flow of gas can be observed by bubbling of water in the wash bottle.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Open the inlet valve to let in the gas. The residual oxygen in the jar after the evacuation combines with the hydrogen to form water. The loose clamp becomes firm again after the introduction of the gas.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>After about three minutes, close the inlet valve and remove the football bladder. Incubate the jar at the appropriate temperature.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>Note</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>The older form of anaerobic jar used pallidinised asbestos and was heated with electric current. There was a great risk of explosion.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The McIntosh and Filde's jar also has the risk of explosion due to the use of hydrogen gas. Keep the bladder when filled with hydrogen away from fire.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>The process of evacuation of the McIntosh and Filde's jar causes oxygen dissolved in liquid media to be displaced by reduced pressure, thus creating anaerobiasis within the tubes.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>An indicator, chemical or biological, must always be included in the jar to test the efficiency of the jar.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Some workers prefer to place the inoculated plates inverted in the jar.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="gaspak-system">GasPak System<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#gaspak-system" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This system of anaerobic cultivation uses a gas generating kit. This version of the anaerobic jar is a specially designed clean polycarbonate resin with a palladium catalyst that is active at low (room) temperature in its lid (Fig. 8.4). Prepacked chemicals in a foil envelope are activated by the addition of water to generate the hydrogen required to combine with the free oxygen in the jar. There is also a disposable chemical indicator supplied along with the kit to check the efficiency of the system. The indicator is colourless in the absence of oxygen but turns greenish blue if oxygen is present. This gas generating kit is simple to use, and there is no need for a vacuum pump or gas cylinder.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="how-to-use-the-gaspak-system">How to use the GasPak system<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#how-to-use-the-gaspak-system" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Place the culture plates or tubes in the jar.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Add 10 ml of tap or distilled water to the gas generating envelope through a cut made in the cor.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-0347d4d0.jpeg" alt="img-58.jpeg">
Fig. 8.4 GasPak system</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Principles and Procedures of Diagnostic Bacteriology 609</p>
<p>ner of the envelope. Place it in the jar. Peel back the indicator strip to reveal a colourless indicator and place in the jar.</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>
<p>Screw the lid on firmly. Within seconds, the indicator turns greenish-blue.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>After the gases are produced, water will form and the lid becomes warm due to the reaction of the mixture of gases.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>The indicator returns to colourless as evidence of anaerobiasis. Another indication of good anaerobic condition is the formation of water of condensation. If it does not occur, the catalyst should be replaced (A replacement is readily available and it is easily screwed into place).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="testing-the-efficiency-of-the-anaerobic-jar">Testing the efficiency of the anaerobic jar<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#testing-the-efficiency-of-the-anaerobic-jar" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The anaerobic jar is constantly checked to ensure that anaerobic conditions are maintained during incubation. Chemical or biological indicators are enclosed in the jar along with the inoculated culture media. If the jar fails to produce anaerobic condition, it is likely that either there is a leakage or the capsule is not working. Heat the capsule to reactivate its catalyst activity. The heating is to remove moisture which might be interfering with its activity.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="testing-for-a-leakage">Testing for a leakage<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#testing-for-a-leakage" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Place a piece of cotton wool soaked in ether in the jar.</p>
<p>Clamp down the lid and close all the valves.</p>
<p>Immerse the jar in a bucket of warm water.</p>
<p>The ether will expand in the jar. If there is a leakage, the ether will force air out of the jar and thus produce bubbles at the site of leakage.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="anaerobic-work-station">Anaerobic Work Station<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#anaerobic-work-station" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Another method of achieving anaerobiasis is the use of anaerobic work station or cabinets. Hydrogen and nitrogen gases are introduced into the work station from cylinders. These anaerobic cabinets are available in different sizes and they are mostly single or double chambered in design.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="anaerobic-indicators">Anaerobic Indicators<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#anaerobic-indicators" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="a-chemical-indicators">(a) Chemical Indicators<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-chemical-indicators" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>The various chemical indicators used in the anaerobic jar are all redox indicators which in the absence of oxygen are colourless but become coloured in the presence of oxygen. The indicator may be in liquid or semi-solid form. It may also be in the form of soaked or moistened pad in an air tight envelope.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="i-allkaline-methylene-blue-glucose-solution-indicator">(i) Allkaline methylene blue-glucose solution indicator<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-allkaline-methylene-blue-glucose-solution-indicator" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<table><thead><tr><th>Solution 1</th><th>0.1M sodium hydroxide</th><th>6 ml</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td></td><td>Distilled water</td><td>94 ml</td></tr><tr><td>Solution 2</td><td>0.5% methylene blue</td><td>3 ml</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>Distilled water</td><td>97 ml</td></tr><tr><td>Solution 3</td><td>Glucose</td><td>6 g</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>Distilled water</td><td>100 ml</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Add a small crystal of thymol as a preservative.</p>
<p>For use: Equal volumes of solutions 1, 2 and 3 are mixed, boiled till colourless and then placed in the jar which is then immediately tightly closed.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="ii-glucose-broth-methylene-blue-mixture-indicator">(ii) Glucose broth-methylene blue mixture indicator<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-glucose-broth-methylene-blue-mixture-indicator" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>A mixture of glucose broth of pH 8.6 and methylene blue treated as above is also a useful redox indicator.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="iii-semi-solid-indicator">(iii) Semi-solid indicator<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-semi-solid-indicator" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>The Macintosh and Filde’s jars have a side arm to which a tube of indicator is attached with a short piece of rubber tubing. The indicator is made up of:</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Sodium thioglycollate</th><th>0.1 g</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Borax</td><td>1.0 g</td></tr><tr><td>Methylene blue</td><td>0.02 g</td></tr><tr><td>Agar</td><td>0.5 g</td></tr><tr><td>Distilled water</td><td>100 ml</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Dissolve by boiling, cool to about <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>50</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∘</mo></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">50^{\circ}\mathrm{C}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">5</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">0</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6741em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∘</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm">C</span></span></span></span></span>, and distribute in slender <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>6.5</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>100</mn><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">6.5 \times 100 \mathrm{~mm}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">6.5</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">100</span><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm">mm</span></span></span></span></span></span> tubes. Boil again till colourless and seal the tubes immediately. For use, break off the neck of the tube and attach one tube of indicator to the side arm of the jar. The indicator is colourless in the absence of oxygen.</p>
<p>The GasPak system uses indicators based on the same principle as above which are prepared as soaked pads sealed in special envelopes.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="b-biological-indicators">(b) Biological indicators<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-biological-indicators" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>A culture medium inoculated with a strict anaerobe, e.g., Clostridium</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Bacteriology</p>
<p>tetani, can be included in the jar and examined after incubation for growth. If it grows, then the jar is working well. Alternatively, an inoculated plate of a strict aerobe, e.g., <em>Pseudomonas aeruginosa</em> can be included in the jar. If there is growth, then the jar is faulty.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="13559f8d">Incubation In Carbon Dioxide (CO₂)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#13559f8d" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Some bacteria require a carbon dioxide enriched atmosphere to grow. In some cases, the CO₂ enhances good growth of certain organisms. Usually 5–10% CO₂ is needed for bacterial growth.</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>The Candle jar The simplest and cheapest way of providing a CO₂ enriched atmosphere is to enclose a lighted candle in an air tight jar or tin (Fig. 8.5). The burning candle depletes the oxygen content of the jar, leaving about 5% CO₂ in the jar when the light is extinguished.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Using marble chips A small marble chip (0.5 to 1 g) and 8 ml of hydrochloric acid contained in a large test tube are placed in an air tight container with the inoculated plate. Carbon dioxide is released from the mixture to provide required growth atmosphere.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>CO₂ incubators There are incubators designed to allow in an adjustable amount of carbon dioxide and air to enter the chamber. The atmosphere in the incubator is circulated by a fan; and the humidity is also controlled.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Pre-packed CO₂ generating kits These are special envelopes containing chemicals that yield CO₂ with the addition of water. The kits are convenient and are used in the same way as the GasPak anaerobic kits without the catalyst.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>&gt; <strong>Note!</strong> The candle jar is a suitable source of CO₂ for the cultivation of microaerophilic organisms such as Campylobacter. Alternatively, one should use the special Campylobacter GasPak kit similar to those used for anaerobic or CO₂ atmospheres. The kit provides an atmosphere containing only traces of oxygen.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="classification-of-pathogenic-organisms">CLASSIFICATION OF PATHOGENIC ORGANISMS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#classification-of-pathogenic-organisms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Pathogenic organisms are classified according to the risk of infection they pose to health workers. There are four categories of pathogens:</p>
<p><strong>Group 1:</strong> An organism that is most unlikely to cause disease in man. For example, common moulds and food spoilage bacteria.</p>
<p><strong>Group 2:</strong> An organism that may cause disease in man and which may be hazardous to laboratory worker but not likely to spread within the community. Exposure does not usually produce infection and there is effective prophylaxis and treatment available. For example, common pathogenic bacteria such as staphylococci, polioviruses, Toxoplasma.</p>
<p><strong>Group 3:</strong> An organism which may cause disease in man and pose a serious hazard to the laboratory worker. There may also be a risk of spread within the community. Effective prophylaxis and treatment are usually available. Examples in this group include <em>Brucella</em>, <em>Salmonella typhi</em>, <em>Mycobacterium tuberculosis</em>, <em>arboviruses</em> and <em>Histoplasma</em>.</p>
<p><strong>Group 4:</strong> An organism which causes severe disease in man and is a serious hazard to the laboratory worker. There is also a risk of spread within the community. There is no effective prophylaxis</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-46d96bcc.jpeg" alt="img-59.jpeg">
Fig. 8.5 Candle jar</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Principles and Procedures of Diagnostic Bacteriology 611</p>
<p>and treatment. This group consists of viruses such as <em>Ebola</em>, <em>Lassa</em>, <em>Marburg</em>.</p>
<p>There are various categories of containment for each of these groups of pathogens (refer to Section I). One of the important ways of containing the infections in the laboratory is the use of the Safety Cabinets.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="safety-cabinets">SAFETY CABINETS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#safety-cabinets" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Since all clinical specimens potentially contain pathogens, strict safety precautions in their handling must be enforced by the department. Specimens should be processed in the appropriate safety cabinet depending on the group of organisms suspected.</p>
<p>The design of safety cabinet should conform to the specifications for microbiological Safety Cabinets. The specifications refer to the description of the three classes of Safety Cabinet, i.e., Classes I, II, and III. The specifications include methods of testing air flow and filtration efficiency and for determining the level of safety provided.</p>
<p><strong>Class I cabinet</strong> This is an open-front exhaust safety cabinet. Potentially infectious aerosols are contained within the cabinet and filtered from the exhaust air by a high efficiency particulate absorption (HEPA) filter (Fig. 8.6). This cabinet is used for groups 1, 2 and 3 organisms. Procedures such as shaking or mixing of infectious materials can be performed in Class I cabinet.</p>
<p><strong>Class II cabinet</strong> This cabinet is designed to control airborne contamination of the material inside the cabinet and reduce exposure of the operator to any infectious aerosols released during the work procedure. It is used for containment of group 2 and 3 organisms. It has a recirculating flow of filtered air over the work area together with inflow of air through the opening (Fig. 8.7). About 30% of the air is filtered out through the HEPA filter.</p>
<p><strong>Class III cabinet</strong> This cabinet is the only one that offers protection against group 4 organisms. It is a totally enclosed exhaust safety cabinet with gloves mechanically attached. An inlet filter allows a supply of filtered air into the cabinet and is</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-79ea9ad8.jpeg" alt="img-60.jpeg">
Fig. 8.6 Class I biological safety cabinet</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-34d0a867.jpeg" alt="img-61.jpeg">
Fig. 8.7 Simplified diagram of Class II biological safety cabinet</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>612 Bacteriology</p>
<p>exhausted to the atmosphere through a filtered system (Fig. 8.8).</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-ad7a22e7.jpeg" alt="img-62.jpeg">
Fig. 8.8 Class III biological safety cabinet</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="quality-assurance">QUALITY ASSURANCE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#quality-assurance" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Quality assurance in microbiology is very essential for the reproducibility and reliability of results obtained for the effective treatment of patients and control of infectious diseases in the community.</p>
<p>The quality control measures that are put up to achieve quality assurance ensures prudent management of resources and prompt release of results. Each laboratory normally should set up its own methods of internal quality control. The methods adopted should include controls of such vital areas of the laboratory procedures as:</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="1-specimen">1. Specimen<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-specimen" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>The control of specimen collection and dispatch involves helping those charged with collection of specimen with clearly written instructions regarding the correct type of specimen, the best time and aseptic method of collection. It should also include guidelines for storage and dispatch of specimen, the type of preservatives and transport media to use if necessary. Correct procedures for handling, storage of specimens in the laboratory and processing of urgent requests for specimens such as cerebrospinal fluid, blood cultures, unpreserved urine, faecal specimens containing blood and mucus etc should be practised. It is an area of constant dialogue between the laboratory and the clinical staff.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="2-bacteriological-techniques">2. Bacteriological Techniques<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-bacteriological-techniques" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>It is essential to control techniques and methods used in the laboratory. The department must have Methods/Techniques Manual or Bench Workbooks. The information contained in these books should include:</p>
<p>(i) Procedures for processing different specimens that are received in the laboratory.
(ii) Preparation of culture media and culture methods.
(iii) Staining methods, preparation of stains and reagents.
(iv) Antibiotic sensitivity testing methods.
(v) Serological tests.</p>
<p>The review and updating of the manual should be a continuous exercise. The last but surely not the least of quality control measures is ‘the teaching by example’ approach. Aseptic and other unique bacteriological techniques should be demonstrated to trainees and new members of staff by a senior and experienced staff member.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="3-culture-media">3. Culture Media<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-culture-media" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>The quality control of culture media is an important procedure performed in the laboratory. This has been discussed in Chapter 7.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="4-stains-and-reagents">4. Stains and Reagents<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#4-stains-and-reagents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>A control smear should be stained at regular intervals to ensure that correct staining properties of the stains are obtained. All stains and reagents should be clearly labelled and date of preparation shown. A badly made smear usually gives a poor staining reaction.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5-control-of-equipment">5. Control of Equipment<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-control-of-equipment" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The correct functioning of all laboratory equipment is essential for the production of accurate results. For a new equipment, it is important that the manufacturer’s instructions contained in the operating manual should be followed to the letter. Regular maintenance and cleaning of all equipments helps to prolong the life of such equipments. Incubator temperatures should be monitored on daily basis. The care and maintenance of the major equipments in the bacteriology laboratory are shown in Table 8.4.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="6-reports-and-results">6. Reports and Results<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#6-reports-and-results" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The laboratory must have standardised guidelines for reporting and recording results. These guidelines must be communicated to the clinicians whose duty is to interpret them. Results should be clearly and neatly recorded. Many laboratories in the past made use of rubber stamps to maintain reproducibility; some made use of printed forms while others typed their results. Today, more and more laboratories are being hooked up to the hospital computer main frame so that results are logged in the computer and are received in the wards.</p>
<p>It is however important that</p>
<p>(i) all results are verified by senior technical staff or medical microbiologists in the department before being made available to clinics and wards;</p>
<p>(ii) record of all results are kept by the laboratory either in the form of work sheets or copies of the final results, and</p>
<p>(iii) communicating laboratory results by telephones should, where possible, not be encouraged due to frequent misrepresentation of facts through the phone.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Chapter 9</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="diagnosis-of-infection-by-specific-anatomic-site">Diagnosis of Infection by Specific Anatomic Site<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#diagnosis-of-infection-by-specific-anatomic-site" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="upper-respiratory-tract-urt">UPPER RESPIRATORY TRACT (URT)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#upper-respiratory-tract-urt" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="1-throat">1. Throat<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-throat" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>'Sore throat' is the term used to describe most infections of the throat, majority of which are caused by viruses. (Table 9.1)</p>
<p>A. Conventional pathogen Beta-haemolytic streptococcus group A (Streptococcus pyogenes).</p>
<p>B. Casual pathogens Beta-haemolytic streptococci (groups B,C,G); Haemophilus influenzae; Staphylococcus aureus; Candida species; Vincent's organisms; Corynebacterium diphtheriae; Neisseria gonorrhoeae; Neisseria meningitidis.</p>
<p>C. Normal flora of the URT Table 9.2 shows a list of the normal flora of URT.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="collection-and-transport-of-specimen">Collection and Transport of Specimen<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#collection-and-transport-of-specimen" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>(i) Collect specimen before the commencement of antibiotic therapy. Collection should be done by an experienced physician or nurse or laboratory technologist.</p>
<p>(ii) In good light and using sterile wooden spatula to depress the tongue, collect sample with sterile swab from area of inflammation, exudate or pus.</p>
<p>(iii) The swab should reach the laboratory within two hours of collection for immediate processing.</p>
<p>Table 9.1 Throat and mouth: Disease situations and their infectious agents</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Disease</th><th>Agent</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>'Sore throat' or streptococcal pharyngitis</td><td>Group A beta-haemolytic streptococcus (Streptococcus pyogenes)</td></tr><tr><td>Diphtheria</td><td>Corynebacterium diphtheriae</td></tr><tr><td>Acute epiglottitis in children</td><td>H. influenzae</td></tr><tr><td>Oral thrush in young children, diabetics and immunocompromised persons</td><td>Candida albicans</td></tr><tr><td>Stomatitis</td><td>Vincent's organisms</td></tr><tr><td>Vincent's angina or Vincent's gingivitis</td><td>Borrelia vincenti, Leptospira buccalis and Bacteriodes melaninogenicus (Prevotella melaninogenicus)</td></tr></tbody></table>

<p>α-haemolytic Streptococci

Staphylococci:
Staphylococcus aureus

Hemophilus species
Neisseria species
Branhamella species
Corynebacterium species "diphtheroids"
Escherichia coli and other Enterobacteriaceae
Anaerobes</p>
<p>Procedure For routine culture:
Inoculate a Blood agar (BA) plate
Incubate anaerobically at 37°C for 18–24 hours.
Identify the Beta-haemolytic streptococci if isolated.</p>
<p>Additional tests
(a) Gram smear and tellurite blood agar (Hoyles medium) if diphtheria is indicated.
(b) Gram smear, and Sabouraud agar if patient is immunocompromised.
(c) Gram smear in cases of Vincent’s angina (ulcerating gingivostomatitis).
(d) Inoculate modified Thayer Martin agar for Neisseria gonorrhoeae or Neisseria meningitidis if indicated by history.</p>
<p>Reporting
(i) Report β-haemolytic streptococci (group A) with the antibiotic sensitivities.
(ii) Report other α-haemolytic streptococci, Staph aureus, H. influenzae if the growth is heavy.
(iii) Report Candida species if the patient is elderly, neonate or immunocompromised.
(iv) Report Vincent’s organisms (spirochaetes) when seen in large numbers together with fusiform bacteria.</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>Pernasal-Nasopharynx</li>
</ol>
<p>A special technique is used to obtain specimen from pernasal and nasopharyngeal sites. For this, specimens are collected by experienced physicians.</p>
<p>A. Conventional pathogens Streptococcus pneumoniae; Corynebacterium diphtheriae; Haemophilus influenzae; Neisseria meningitidis (carriers); Bordetella pertussis; Bordetella parapertussis; Klebsiella ozaenae. (Table 9.3)
B. Casual pathogens Mycobacterium leprae.
C. Commensals Streptococcus viridans; Neisseria species; Haemophilus species; Micrococci; Enterococci; Diptheroids.</p>
<p>Table 9.3 Nasopharynx: Disease situation and their infectious agents</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Disease</th><th>Agent</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Pneumonia or bronchopneumonia</td><td>S. pneumoniae, Klebsiella pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, Branhamella catarrhalis</td></tr><tr><td>Whooping cough</td><td>Bordetella pertussis.</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Diagnosis of Infection by Specific Anatomic Site 617</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="collection-and-transport-of-specimens">Collection and Transport of Specimens<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#collection-and-transport-of-specimens" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>When it is very difficult or not possible to obtain sputum especially from children, secretion aspirated from the nasopharynx is examined for pathogens. This aspiration should be carried out by a physician or an experienced nurse.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="technique">Technique<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#technique" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p><strong>For nasopharyngeal aspirate</strong> Slowly, insert a sterile catheter through one nostril as far as the pharynx.</p>
<p>Attach a sterile syringe to the catheter.</p>
<p>Aspirate a specimen of mucopus. Empty the specimen into a small sterile container.</p>
<p>Deliver to the laboratory as soon as possible.</p>
<p><strong>For pernasal swab</strong> Pernasal swab is collected in suspected cases of whooping cough. Collect the swab if the nasal passages are clear as follows:</p>
<p>With a sterile cotton or alginate wool swab attached to a thin flexible piece of wire (West's swab), slowly pass the swab along the floor of one nostril, turning the swab downwards and backwards as far as the nasopharynx.</p>
<p>Replace the swab in its container without allowing it to be contaminated.</p>
<p>The specimens are delivered to the laboratory without delay.</p>
<p>When it is not possible to collect pernasal swab, a 'cough plate' culture can be done. Hold a culture plate medium in front of the child's mouth during a coughing attack.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="culture-for-b-pertussis">Culture for B. pertussis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#culture-for-b-pertussis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="inoculate">Inoculate<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#inoculate" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>(a) Charcoal agar
(b) Chocolate agar (plain)</p>
<p>Incubate charcoal agar in a moist chamber aerobically for up to five days. Incubate chocolate agar in 10% CO₂ for 24 hours or 48 hours if need be.</p>
<p><strong>Reporting</strong> Report <em>Bordettela pertussis</em> or any other pathogen when isolated with appropriate sensitivities.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="3-nasal-specimens">3. Nasal Specimens<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-nasal-specimens" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Anterior nasal swabs are usually done in order to detect carriers of some pathogens, especially <em>Staph.aureus</em>.</p>
<p>A. <strong>Usual pathogens</strong> <em>Staph. aureus</em>; <em>Strep. pyogenes</em>; <em>Neisseria meningitidis</em>.</p>
<p>B. <strong>Casual pathogen</strong> <em>Haemophilus influenzae</em> (usually non-capsulated).</p>
<p>C. <strong>Commensals</strong> The same commensals as for pernasal specimen.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="collection-and-transport-of-specimens">Collection and transport of specimens<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#collection-and-transport-of-specimens" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>A sterile cotton wool swab is moistened with sterile saline or peptone water.</li>
<li>Slowly, swab the inside surface of the nose.</li>
<li>Replace the swab in the container and deliver to the laboratory without delay.</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>Culture</strong> Inoculate 1 blood agar plate and incubate in air at 36°C overnight.</p>
<p><strong>Reporting</strong> Report <em>Staph.aureus</em> if isolated. Perform a methicillin sensitivity test to detect methicillin resistant <em>Staph. aureus</em> (MRSA). The infection control officer should be notified of such findings.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="4-antral-washout-lavage-drainage-of-sinus">4. Antral Washout/Lavage/Drainage of Sinus<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#4-antral-washout-lavage-drainage-of-sinus" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>These specimens are collected during acute or chronic sinusitis. The infection is usually endogenous with bacterial flora of the URT. Acute infections usually accompany viral infections and chronic infections may be associated with nasal obstruction.</p>
<p>A. <strong>Conventional pathogens</strong> <em>Haemophilus influenzae</em>; <em>Staphylococcus aureus</em>; <em>Streptococcus pneumoniae</em>.</p>
<p>B. <strong>Casual pathogens</strong> β-haemolytic streptococci; <em>Neisseria species</em>; <em>Klebsiella species</em> (especially <em>K. ozaenae</em> and <em>K. rhinoscleromatis</em>); Anaerobes (especially <em>Bacteriodes</em> and some anaerobic streptococci).</p>
<p>C. <strong>Normal flora</strong> Sinuses are normally sterile.</p>
<p><strong>Procedure</strong> Centrifuge the specimen</p>
<p>(a) Gram smear to look for pus cells
(b) Inoculate:</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>618 Bacteriology</p>
<p>(i) Blood agar(BA) — -CO₂ incubation
(ii) Chocolate agar — -CO₂ incubation (CHOC)
(iii) Gentamicin blood agar — Anaerobic incubation
(iv) Robertson's cooked meat medium (RCM)</p>
<p>Incubate all media at 37°C overnight.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="additional-tests">Additional tests<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#additional-tests" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>(i) Add metronidazole disc to the anaerobic blood agar.
(ii) Inoculate tellurite blood agar if diphtheria is indicated.
(iii) Inoculate modified Thayer Martin medium if Neisseria meningitidis is suspected.
(iv) After overnight incubation subculture RCM broth to BA, CHOC and incubate at 37°C in CO₂, BA for anaerobic incubation at 37°C.</p>
<p><strong>Reporting</strong> Pathogens isolated from A or B groups are reported with antibiotic sensitivities. Any other organisms in heavy and pure growth may be reported.</p>
<p>If no pathogen is isolated, report as ‘Normal flora of the URT isolated’.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="lower-respiratory-tract-sputum">LOWER RESPIRATORY TRACT Sputum<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#lower-respiratory-tract-sputum" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Sputum examination is done to study bronchial and pulmonary secretions or exudates. Sputum specimens should be expectorated from the lower respiratory tract and must be distinct from saliva. Table 9.4. The presence of a large number of polymorphonuclear neutrophils (PMNs), at least 25 per low power field, is indicative of infection; and a large number of squamous epithelial cells indicates contamination with saliva. Sputum specimens are collected for either non-mycobacterial (routine) or mycobacterial investigations.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="non-mycobacterial-routine-examination">Non-mycobacterial (routine) Examination<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#non-mycobacterial-routine-examination" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Conventional pathogens <em>Streptococcus pneumoniae</em>; <em>Haemophilus influenzae</em>.</p>
<p>B. Casual pathogens <em>Staphylococcus aureus</em>; <em>Klebsiella pneumoniae</em>; <em>Pseudomonas aeruginosa</em>; <em>Streptococcus pyogenes</em>; <em>Legionella species</em>; <em>Mycoplasma species</em>; <em>Candida albicans</em> and other fungi.</p>
<p>C. Commensal normal flora encountered in sputum specimens</p>
<p>These are the same as those of the upper respiratory tract. This is because sputum, when being collected</p>
<p>Table 9.4 Lower respiratory tract: Disease conditions and their infectious agents</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Disease</th><th>Agents</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Lobar pneumonia, bronchopneumonia in children, the elderly and the immunocompromised patients.</td><td>Strep. pneumoniae</td></tr><tr><td>Influenza virus pneumonia</td><td>H. influenzae, Staph. aureus, Strep. pyogens.</td></tr><tr><td>Chest infection following surgical operation.</td><td>H.influenzae</td></tr><tr><td>Bronchitis</td><td>Strep. pneumoniae, H.influenzae</td></tr><tr><td>Chronic lung cavities, long use of immunosuppressive drugs</td><td>Ps. aeruginosa</td></tr><tr><td>Pneumonic plague</td><td>Yersinia pestis</td></tr><tr><td>Atypical pneumonia</td><td>Mycoplasma pneumoniae</td></tr><tr><td>Legionaire’s disease (a severe form of pneumonia)</td><td>Legionella pneumophila</td></tr><tr><td>Tuberculosis</td><td>(Mycobacterium tuberculosis</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Diagnosis of Infection by Specific Anatomic Site 619</p>
<p>lected, passes through the pharynx and the mouth and becomes contaminated with the commensal organisms of the throat and mouth.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="procedure">Procedure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#procedure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>All primary work must be down in the safety cabinet</p>
<ol>
<li>Note and record the appearance of the specimen (purulent, mucopurulent, mucoid, salivary).</li>
<li>Add an equal volume of fresh sputasol, a mucolytic agent, to the specimen to homogenise it.</li>
<li>Shake gently at intervals over a period of 30 minutes.</li>
<li>Reject frank salivary specimens and request for a repeat sample.</li>
<li>Gram smear to look for pus cells and epithelial cells.</li>
<li>Inoculate:
2 Blood agar (BA):
BA-aerobic incubation
BA-anaerobic incubation
Chocolate agar with or without inhibitory substances.
CLED or MacConkey agar.
Incubate all plates at 37°C for 18–24 hours.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="additional-tests">Additional tests<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#additional-tests" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>(a) Add optochin disc to the BA plate for quick identification of <em>Strep. pneumoniae</em>.
(b) Sabouraud agar if yeast cells are present in the Gram smear.
(c) Gentamin BA if <em>Actinomyces</em> is indicated and incubate anaerobically for up to five days.
(d) Selective media for any other pathogen if and when indicated.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="reporting">Reporting<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#reporting" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Report any pathogen in A or B groups with antibiotic sensitivities.</p>
<p>If no pathogen is isolated, report as ‘Normal flora of the URT’ isolated.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="note">Note<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#note" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Sputasol may be added to liquefy mucus.</li>
<li>Alternatively, the sputum can be homogenised either by shaking with sterile Ringer’s solution and glass beads or by adding 1 % pancreatin and incubating for 1 hour.</li>
</ol>
<table><thead><tr><th>Ringer’s solution</th><th></th><th></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Sodium Chloride</td><td>9.0</td><td>g</td></tr><tr><td>Potassium Chloride</td><td>0.42</td><td>g</td></tr><tr><td>Calcium Chloride</td><td>0.48</td><td>g</td></tr><tr><td>0.2 % Sodium bicarbonate</td><td>1000</td><td>ml</td></tr><tr><td>1 % Pancreatin</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Add 1g pancreatin to sterile normal saline</td><td>100</td><td>ml</td></tr><tr><td>Buffer solution</td><td>7</td><td>ml</td></tr><tr><td>(Buffer solutions: 0.2 M NaOH</td><td>1 volume</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>0.2M KH₂PO₄)</td><td>1.2 volume</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="examination-of-sputum-specimen-for-mycobacteria">Examination of sputum specimen for Mycobacteria<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#examination-of-sputum-specimen-for-mycobacteria" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="procedure">Procedure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#procedure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Decontamination: There are several methods to decontaminate the specimen of the numerous commensal flora of the URT and at the same time homogenise it. Refer to Chapter 16 for details.</li>
<li>Make smear and stain by Ziehl-Neelsen’s method or with Auramine fluorescent stain for the presence or absence of acid fast bacilli.</li>
<li>Culture: Inoculate Lowestein-Jensen slope with 200 µl of the well homogenised sputum. Allow the specimen to run down the slope.</li>
</ol>
<p>Incubate at 35–37°C in a rack placed at an angle of about 45°C so that the specimen is in contact with the full length of the slope.</p>
<p>Place the slope in an upright position after one week incubation. Continue to incubate the cultures for further 4–6 weeks.</p>
<ol start="4">
<li>Examination of Culture: Examine the LJ slope culture for the typical or atypical mycobacterial growth.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="19e7d963">♦ EYE SWAB<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#19e7d963" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>There are three categories of eye-infections:</p>
<p>(a) Conjunctivitis
(b) Infection of the inner eye following penetrating injury. (Table 9.5)
(c) Infection of neonates during birth.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>620 Bacteriology</p>
<p>Table 9.5 Eye: Diseases conditions and their infectious agents</p>

<p>B. Casual pathogens <em>Enterobacteria</em>; <em>Streptococcus</em> group A; Other beta-haemolytic streptococci.</p>
<p>C. Usual commensals encountered in eye specimens <em>Viridans streptococcus</em>; <em>Diphtheroids</em>; <em>Non-pathogenic neisseriae</em>.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="collection-and-transport-of-eye-specimens">Collection and Transport of Eye Specimens<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#collection-and-transport-of-eye-specimens" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Collection of eye swabs or conjunctival scraping should be done by an experienced physician or nurse. The specimens must be processed as soon as possible after collection. This is to minimise the antibacterial activity of ocular enzymes.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="procedure">Procedure<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#procedure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Gram smear - Examine for pus cells and bacteria.</li>
</ol>

(v) Sabouraud agar  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>−</mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">-\mathrm{O}_{2}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord">−</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">O</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  incubation.</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>Incubate all culture plates at  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>36</mn><mo>−</mo><msup><mn>37</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∘</mo></msup><mi>C</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">36 - 37^{\circ}C</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">36</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">3</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">7</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6741em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∘</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">C</span></span></span></span></span>  for 18-24 hours. The gentamicin blood agar may be incubated for 48 hours and the Sabouraud agar for up to five days.</li>
</ol>
<p>Reporting Report with antibiotic sensitivities any pathogen from A or B groups. When there is no pathogen, report as 'commensal flora isolated'.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="b69edb77"><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">♠</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\spadesuit</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8241em; vertical-align: -0.1296em;"></span><span class="mord">♠</span></span></span></span></span>  PUS, ABSCESS AND WOUND DRAIN<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b69edb77" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The type of examination of pus specimen very much depends on the site of the pus, and also if it is a swab specimen or an exudate collected in a sterile container. (Table 9.7).</p>
<p>A. Conventional pathogens Staph.aureus, Beta-haemolytic streptococci (groups A, C, G).
B. Other pathogens Group D streptococci; Coliform bacilli; Pseudomonas aeruginosa; Clostridium species (C. tetani, C. perfringens and others); Bacteriodes species and other anaerobes; Actinomyces species; Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
C. Commensal flora Commensal flora of pus specimen depends on the site of the neoformans, but the usual ones are Staph.epidermidis, diphtheroids and Bacillus species.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="note">Note<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#note" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>Fungal infection is not uncommon, e.g., Cryptococcus neoformans, Candida albicans and Histoplasma duboisii.</li>
<li>Certain parasites are found in pus exudate. For example, Entamoeba</li>
</ol>
