margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<p>When the organism containing catalase comes in contact with hydrogen peroxide, bubbles of oxygen are given off.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="reagents">Reagents<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#reagents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Hydrogen peroxide, 3 % (10 volume solution).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="method-i">Method I<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#method-i" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Emulsify few colonies of the organism in distilled water on a clean slide placed in a petri dash.</li>
<li>Add a 1–2 drops of <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{H}_2\mathrm{O}_2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">H</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">O</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> and cover the dish.</li>
<li>Gas bubbles indicates a positive reaction.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="method-ii">Method II<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#method-ii" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Place 2–3 ml of <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{H}_2\mathrm{O}_2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">H</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">O</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> in a test-tube.</li>
<li>With a sterile wooden applicator or plastic rod or glass stirrer, pick some colonies of the organism and immerse it in the <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{H}_2\mathrm{O}_2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">H</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">O</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> solution.</li>
<li>Immediate gas bubbling indicates positive test.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="controls">Controls<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#controls" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<table><thead><tr><th>Staphylococcus species</th><th>-Positive</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Streptococcus species</td><td>-Negative</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>&gt; <strong>Note</strong>
&gt; 1. Use fresh culture of not more than 24 hour old.
&gt; 2. False positive result may occur in the presence of blood.
&gt; 3. False positive results also occur if nichrome wire loop is used.
&gt; 4. Shake the <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{H}_2\mathrm{O}_2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">H</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">O</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> container before use in order to expel any dissolved oxygen.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Identification Methods 647</p>
<p>gen which may cause a false positive result.</p>
<ol start="5">
<li>Hydrogen peroxide—20 volumes or 30 volumes can also be used.</li>
<li>With the slides test, there is a risk of aerosols being released, so it should be performed in the exhaust cabinet or perform the test tube method.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="camp-test">CAMP TEST<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#camp-test" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>(Christie, Atkins, Munch-Petersen)</p>
<p>This is used to differentiate <em>Strep. agalactiae</em> (Group B streptococci) from other streptococci.</p>
<p><strong>Principle</strong> <em>Strept. agalactiae</em> under aerobic condition produces a substance known as CAMP factor which increases the β-lysin produced by <em>Staph.aureus</em> and so increases an area of haemolysis at the junction of <em>Strep. agalactiae</em> and <em>Staph.aureus</em>. This area usually appears in the form of an arrow-head or crescent.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="requirements">Requirements<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#requirements" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>5–10 % sheep blood agar</p>
<p>Pure culture of <em>Staph. aureus</em> (β-lysin producing).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="test">Test<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#test" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Streak a β-lysin producing <em>Staph. aureus</em> on the blood agar.</li>
<li>Make a single streak of the streptococcal strain perpendicular to the staphylococcal streak, leaving a space of one mm between the two organisms.</li>
<li>Incubate the plate at 37°C in air for 24 hours.</li>
<li>An arrow-head formation of haemolysis is indicative of a positive test. (Fig. 10.2)</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="controls">Controls<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#controls" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li><em>Strept. agalactiae</em> — Positive</li>
<li><em>Strept. faecalis</em> — Negative.</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Note</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Do not incubate anaerobically since some Group A streptococci may give false positive results.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Test can be incubated in 10 % CO₂.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>5 % bovine blood can also be used.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-50a9d0dc.jpeg" alt="img-68.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="carbohydrate-assimilation-utilisation-test">CARBOHYDRATE ASSIMILATION (UTILISATION) TEST<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#carbohydrate-assimilation-utilisation-test" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Some non-fermentative bacteria and fungi can utilise carbohydrates as a sole source of carbon for growth. A characteristic profile can help in the identification.</p>
<p><strong>Medium</strong> Prepare a 2% agar solution and sterilise by autoclaving at 15psi for 15 minutes.</p>
<p>Dissolve 6.7 g yeast nitrogen base in 100 ml distilled water. Adjust the pH to 7.4 for bacteria (and to 6.2–6.4 for yeasts) with 0.1 N NaOH. Sterilise by filtration.</p>
<p>Add 8.8 ml of the nitrogen base to 100 ml of 2% agar base, melted and cooled to 45°C. Mix and pour plates.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="method">Method<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#method" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Inoculate the test organism on a carbohydrate-free medium as a lawn culture.</li>
<li>Place filter paper discs impregnated with 1% solution of the carbohydrate and dried before use.</li>
<li>Incubate at 37°C for 24–48 hours.</li>
<li>Growth around the disc indicates utilisation of the carbohydrate.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="carbohydrate-fermentation-test">CARBOHYDRATE FERMENTATION TEST<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#carbohydrate-fermentation-test" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Principle</strong> Bacteria can breakdown carbohydrate fermentatively depending on the enzymes they can</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>648 Bacteriology</p>
<p>produce. Ability to ferment a range of carbohydrates is used as an identification tool for many groups of bacteria. The carbohydrate to be tested is added in 0.5 to 1% concentration to a peptone water base containing an acid-base indicator such as phenol red or Andrade’s indicator. Fermentation is indicated by change of colour due to acid production. Gas may or may not be produced during fermentation. An inverted Durham’s tube added to the medium can trap the gas produced. Characteristic fermentation profiles are used for the identification of bacteria.</p>
<p><strong>Medium</strong> Refer to Chapter 25.</p>
<p><strong>Test</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Inoculate the test organism in a tube containing the carbohydrate medium, e.g., glucose, with inverted Durham’s tube.</li>
<li>Incubate overnight at 37°C.</li>
<li>Change of colour from straw yellow to pink indicates fermentation of the sugar.</li>
<li>Gas production is indicated by trapped air in the Durham’s tube.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="dd55b83a">♦ CITRATE UTILISATION TEST<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#dd55b83a" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This test is one of the important tests used in the identification of enterobacteria.</p>
<p><strong>Principle</strong> It is based on the ability of an organism to utilise citrate as its only source of carbon, and ammonium as its only source of nitrogen. The citrate is metabolised to acetoin and CO₂.</p>
<p><strong>Medium</strong> Koser’s citrate medium or Simmon’s citrate agar.</p>
<p>[For preparation of these media, refer to Chapter 25].</p>
<p><strong>Test</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Make a light suspension of the organism in saline.</li>
<li>Inoculate the Koser’s citrate medium with a straight wire; or stab inoculate Simmon’s citrate agar.</li>
<li>A growth indicated by turbidity in the Koser’s medium, or a growth of blue colour in Simmon’s agar, indicates positive result. This means that citrate has been utilised.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="controls">Controls<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#controls" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Klebsiella pneumoniae
E. coli</p>
<ul>
<li>Positive</li>
<li>Negative</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="d72fb649">♦ COAGULASE TEST<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#d72fb649" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This test is used to differentiate <em>Staph. aureus</em> from other staphylococci.</p>
<p><strong>Principle</strong> The enzyme, coagulase, causes plasma to clot by converting fibrinogen to fibrin. Coagulase is produced by <em>Staph. aureus</em>. It is considered a pathogenicity test for <em>Staph. aureus</em>.</p>
<p>There are two types of coagulase:</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Free coagulase—this converts fibrinogen to fibrin by first activating the coagulase reacting factor (CRF) in plasma. This coagulase is detected by the formation of a clot in the tube test in which bacterial broth culture is mixed with plasma. The free coagulase is released in the surrounding medium.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Bound coagulase—this converts the fibrinogen directly to fibrin in the absence of the coagulase reacting factor. It is detected by clumping in the slide test. The bound coagulase is associated with the bacterial cells.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>The free coagulase is the most constantly produced extracellular product. It is usually recommended to do tube coagulase test on all ‘slide-coagulase-negative’ staphylococci.</p>
<p><strong>Requirements</strong> Human or rabbit plasma, preferably from EDTA (ethylene diamine-tetra acetic acid) or citrate anticoagulated blood.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="slide-test-to-detect-bound-coagulase">Slide Test to Detect Bound Coagulase<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#slide-test-to-detect-bound-coagulase" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Place two separate drops of saline on a slide.</li>
<li>Emulsify one or two colonies of the organism in each of the drops to make thick suspensions.</li>
<li>Dip the tip of a straight wire into the undiluted plasma and mix the adhering traces of plasma into one of the bacterial suspensions.</li>
</ol>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Identification Methods 649</p>
<ol start="4">
<li>Look for immediate coarse clumping of the mixture (within 5–10 seconds). The clumping indicates positive coagulase test.</li>
<li>No plasma is added to the other suspension. It serves as negative control to the test and to differentiate non-specific granular appearance from true coagulase clumping.</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>Note:</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>If the colonies are auto clumping, and fail to give smooth suspension, the test may be abandoned.</li>
<li>It is not necessary to use a loopful of plasma for the test.</li>
<li>The clumping should be immediate. Any slow reacting strain (more than 10 seconds) should be retested by the tube method.</li>
<li>Include a known positive strain as a positive control along with the test.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="tube-coagulase-test-to-detect-free-coagulase">Tube Coagulase Test to Detect Free Coagulase<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#tube-coagulase-test-to-detect-free-coagulase" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>Dilute the neat plasma 1 in 10 in saline. (0.2 ml of plasma with 1.8 ml of saline).</li>
<li>Into each of three small test tubes, labelled (T), (P), and (N) add 0.5 ml of the diluted plasma.</li>
<li>Add five drops (about 0.1 ml) of an 18–24 hour broth culture of the test organisms to tube (T).</li>
<li>Add five drops of a 18–24 hour broth cultures of <em>Staph. aureus</em> to the tube (P).</li>
<li>Add five drops of sterile broth to the tube (N).</li>
<li>Mix gently and incubate all three tubes at 37°C preferably in a water bath.</li>
<li>Examine for clot after one hour, two hours; and if still there is no clot, examine at 30 minutes interval for up to six hours. Gently tilt the tube to observe the clot. The positive control should produce clot within one hour. The negative control should produce no fibrin clot.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="controls">Controls<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#controls" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p><em>Staph. aureus</em>
<em>Staph epidermidis</em>
-Positive
-Negative</p>
<p><strong>Note:</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Examine at prescribed times as the formed clot may liquefy after some time.</li>
<li>Use colonies from non-inhibitory culture medium.</li>
<li>Any doubtful result can be confirmed by other tests such as DNAse.</li>
<li>A rapid slide latex agglutination test is available for the identification of <em>Staph. aureus</em>. The reagent consists of polystyrene latex particles which have been coated with fibrinogen and immunoglobulin G (IgG). Most strains of <em>Staph. aureus</em> produce protein A which has an affinity for IgG. When the reagent is mixed with a suspension of <em>Staph. aureus</em>, clumping of latex particles occurs due to the action of both the coagulase and protein A.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="decarboxylase-test">DECARBOXYLASE TEST<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#decarboxylase-test" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This is used as an aid in differentiating species within the enterobacteria.</p>
<p><strong>Principle</strong> The decarboxylase enzyme acts on a series of amino acids, namely, lysine, arginine and ornithine, to produce amines. When the amino acid is decarboxylated, the pH of the medium becomes alkaline even though the glucose in the medium is fermented.</p>
<p><strong>Medium</strong> Decarboxylase medium contains a nutrient base as well as dextrose, 1% of the specific amino acid and bromocresol purple which acts as the indicator.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="test">Test<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#test" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>Inoculate three tubes of media each containing one specific amino acid of lysine, arginine and ornithine.</li>
<li>Seal the medium surface with paraffin oil. This is to allow the oxygen within the</li>
</ol>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Bacteriology</p>
<p>system to be used and to retain CO₂ which adds to the alkalinity.</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>Incubate the tubes at 37°C for up to three days.</li>
<li>Observe colour change to violet in any of the tubes.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="positive-controls">Positive Controls<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#positive-controls" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Arginine -Ps. aeruginosa
Lysine -E. coli
Ornithine -E. cloacae.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="deoxyribonuchlease-dnase-test">DEOXYRIBONUCHLEASE (DNASE) TEST<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#deoxyribonuchlease-dnase-test" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This test is used to differentiate <em>Staph. aureus</em> from <em>Staph. epidermidis</em>.</p>
<p><strong>Principle</strong> The enzyme, Deoxyribonuclease, hydrolyses deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA).</p>
<p><strong>Medium</strong>
DNase agar
1NHCl</p>
<p><strong>Test</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Inoculate the medium by 'spot' inoculation or streak across the plate.</li>
<li>Incubate at 37°C overnight.</li>
<li>Flood the plate with 1 N HCl which precipitates the DNA. Tip off the excess acid.</li>
<li>A clear zone around the colony indicates a positive test.</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>Controls</strong>
<em>Staph. aureus</em> -Positive
<em>Staph. epidermidis</em> -Negative.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ff0ce606">HYDROGEN SULPHIDE (H₂S) PRODUCTION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ff0ce606" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The test is used to assist in the identification of enterobacteria. It is also occasionally used to differentiate some other bacteria such as <em>Bacteriodes</em> and <em>Brucella</em> species.</p>
<p><strong>Principle</strong> Hydrogen sulphide is produced when a sulphur containing amino acid is decomposed by the enzymatic action of the bacterium.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="requirement">Requirement<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#requirement" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Lead acetate paper strips</strong> These are prepared by soaking strips of filter paper in a 50 g/L (5% w/v) solution of lead acetate and leaving them to dry at 60°C. Store in an air-tight container.</p>
<p><strong>Test</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Inoculate the organism in peptone water or in any other nutrient broth.</li>
<li>Insert a lead acetate paper strip in the neck of the tube above the medium.</li>
<li>Stopper the tube well so that the strip is firmly wedged between the tube and the stopper.</li>
<li>Incubate at 37°C for 24 hours.</li>
<li>Examine for blackening of the lower part of the strip of paper.</li>
</ol>
<p>Blackening indicates H₂S production.</p>
<p><strong>Controls</strong>
<em>Proteus vulgaris</em> -Positive
<em>E. coli</em> -Negative</p>
<p>&gt; <strong>Note</strong> Some media, such as the Kligler iron agar (KIA), are also suitable for detecting H₂S production by enterobacteria. Detection of H₂S is due to its ferric citrate content which turns the medium black. The use of KIA is described in Chapter 25.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="indole-test">INDOLE TEST<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#indole-test" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This test for indole production is used as an aid in differentiation of Gram negative bacilli.</p>
<p><strong>Principle</strong> Some bacteria are able to break down the amino acid tryptophan present in peptone water to release indole.</p>
<p><strong>Reagents</strong> Indole is detected with Kovac’s reagent or Ehrlich’s reagent.</p>
<p><strong>Kovac’s reagent</strong>
Para-dimethylaminobenzaldehyde 5 g
Iso-amyl alcohol 75 ml
Hydrochloric acid (Conc) 25 ml
Dissolve the aldehyde in the amyl alcohol by gentle warming in a 50°C water bath.</p>
<p>Cool and add the HCl.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Identification Methods 651</p>
<p>Store in a dark bottle at 4°C.</p>
<p><strong>Note</strong>
Iso-amyl alcohol is a very flammable and toxic chemical. Handle with care; and prepare the reagent in a fume cabinet.</p>
<p><strong>Ehrlich's reagent</strong>
Para-dimethylaminobenzaldehyde 4 g
Absolute alcohol 380 ml
Hydrochloric acid (Conc) 80 ml
Dissolve the aldehyde in the alcohol and slowly add the HCl. Store in dark bottles at 4°C.</p>
<p><strong>Test</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Grow the organism in peptone water overnight.</li>
<li>If using Ehrlich's reagent, extract the indole by shaking the culture with equal volume of xylene, ethyl ether or petroleum ether.</li>
<li>Add about 1 ml of Ehrlich's reagent.</li>
<li>Observe a red rose ring between the layer of ether and the peptone water.</li>
<li>If using Kovac's reagent, add a few drops of the reagent to the overnight peptone water culture.</li>
<li>Observe a red ring above the peptone water. The red ring indicates positive indole production.</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>Controls</strong>
E. coli - Positive
Enterobacter aerogenes - Negative.</p>
<p><strong>Note</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>The indole production can also be tested using strips of filter paper which have been soaked in the Kovac's reagent and then allowed to dry. The technique is same as that described below for MIU medium.</li>
<li>The oxalic acid paper strip is used in a similar way as the Kovac's reagent soaked paper strips. It is considered very sensitive, but because the chemistry of the test is not fully understood, it is not commonly used.</li>
<li>Indole is also tested for with the motility indole urea (MIU) medium.</li>
</ol>
<p>Indole test using motility indole urea (MIU) medium</p>
<p>Place an indole paper strip in the neck of the MIU tube above the medium. Stopper the tube and incubate at 35–37°C overnight.</p>
<p>Indole production is shown by reddening of the indole paper strip. If the test is not clear, add 1 ml of Kovac's reagent to the culture and observe a red colour within 10 minutes.</p>
<p>◆ LECITHINIASE (Phospholipase C) TEST</p>
<p>This test is used to differentiate Clostridium and Bacillus groups.</p>
<p><strong>Principle</strong> Some bacteria are able to produce the enzyme lecithinase which will split the lecithin (lipoprotein) present in serum or egg yolk. Lecithinase is also referred to as phospholipase C.</p>
<p><strong>Medium</strong>
Nutrient agar 80 ml
Human serum 20 ml
Or
Nutrient agar 95 ml
Egg yolk 5 ml
Cool the agar to 50°C, add the egg yolk, mix and pour plates.</p>
<p><strong>Method</strong> This test is often done in conjunction with the toxin inhibition test (Nagler reaction) for Clostridium perfringens.</p>
<ol>
<li>Inoculate one half of the plate with Clostridium antitoxin.</li>
<li>Dry the plate.</li>
<li>Streak the culture of the test organism across the plate in a single line starting from the antitoxin free half.</li>
<li>Incubate the plates under conditions suitable for growth of the species involved.</li>
<li>Observe the zones of opalescence surrounding the lecithinase producing colonies on the half not treated with antitoxin.</li>
</ol>
<p>The growth on the antitoxin treated half show no opalescence.</p>
<p><strong>Controls</strong>
Cl. perfringens - Positive
Cl. tetani - Negative</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>652 Bacteriology</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5865152e">♦ MELTYL RED (MR) TEST<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5865152e" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This test is used to differentiate enterobacteria. It detects the production of sufficient acid during the fermentation of glucose.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="principle">Principle<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#principle" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>In the fermentation of glucose, different organisms produce different end products at different pH levels. Some bacteria with extended incubation times, are able to maintain the pH level at below 4.5. This is demonstrated by a change in colour of methyl red indicator which is added at the end of the incubation period.</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Medium</th><th>Glucose phosphate peptone water</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Peptone</td><td>5 g</td></tr><tr><td>Dipotassium hydrogen phosphate,</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>K₂HPO₄</td><td>5 g</td></tr><tr><td>Distilled Water</td><td>1 litre</td></tr><tr><td>Dissolve the peptone and phosphate in water.</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Adjust the pH to 7.6</p>
<ul>
<li>Filter and dispense in five ml volumes.</li>
<li>Sterilise at 121°C for 15 minutes.</li>
<li>Add 0.25 ml of 10% sterile glucose solution to each tube aseptically. (Final concentration 0.5%).</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="methyl-red-indicator-solution">Methyl red indicator solution<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#methyl-red-indicator-solution" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<table><thead><tr><th>Methyl red</th><th>0.1 g</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Ethanol</td><td>300 ml</td></tr><tr><td>Distilled water</td><td>200 ml</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Store at room temperature.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="test">Test<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#test" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Inoculate the medium lightly from a young culture of the organism.</li>
<li>Incubate at 30°C for five days or at 35°C for two days.</li>
<li>Add five drops of the indicator to the culture.</li>
<li>A red colour indicates a positive (acid) reaction.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="controls">Controls<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#controls" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ul>
<li>E. coli - Positive</li>
<li>Enterobacter aerogens - Negative.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="586f4840">♣ NITRATE REDUCTION TEST<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#586f4840" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This test is employed as an aid in the identification of enterobacteria and other groups of coliforms. It tests for the production of nitrites or nitrogen gas from nitrates.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="principle">Principle<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#principle" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>The enzyme nitrate reductase causes the reduction of the nitrate, in the presence of a suitable electron donor, to nitrite or nitrogen.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="medium">Medium<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#medium" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Prepare peptone water containing 0.1% potassium nitrate in five ml volumes and autoclave at 121°C for 15 minutes.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="test-reagents">Test reagents<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#test-reagents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Solution A: 0.8 % sulphanilic acid in 5 N (5 mol/L) acetic acid.</li>
<li>Solution B: 0.5 % alphanaphthylamine in 5 N (5 mol/L) acetic acid (dissolve by gentle heat).</li>
</ol>
<p>Immediately before use, mix equal volumes of solutions A and B to give the test reagent.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="test">Test<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#test" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="method-i">Method I<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#method-i" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<ol>
<li>Inoculate the medium and incubate for 18–24 hours.</li>
<li>To 1 ml of the broth culture, add 1 ml of the test reagent.</li>
<li>Shake and read after 1–2 minutes.</li>
<li>Pink/red colour-Positive nitrate reduction. No colour change-Negative nitrate reduction.</li>
</ol>
<p>No colour change could either be a true negative nitrite reduction or the nitrate has been split beyond nitrite, in which case it may yield other gases such as nitrogen gas, ammonia or nitrous oxide. To detect this, add zinc dust to the test. Metallic zinc reduces nitrate to nitrite, and so a red colour following the addition of zinc dust means that the organism was unable to reduce the nitrate to nitrite.</p>
<p>That is, after the addition of zinc dust.</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Pink/red colour</th><th>Nitrates present (Negative nitrate reduction)</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>No colour change</td><td>Nitrate absent (Positive nitrate reduction).</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="method-ii">Method II<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#method-ii" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<ol>
<li>Incubate 0.5 ml of a heavy suspension of the organism in the medium (see above) at 37°C for 15 minutes.</li>
</ol>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Identification Methods 653</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>Add three drops of Solution A and mix.</li>
<li>Add three drops of Solution B</li>
<li>Continue as for method I.</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>Note</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Agar can be added to the medium and then prepared as slopes.</li>
<li>Alpha-naphthylamine is potentially carcinogenic. Substitute it with N-N-dimethyl-1-naphthylamine.</li>
</ol>
<p>Yellow colour is positive ONPG test.</p>
<p><strong>Controls</strong>
E. coli - Positive
Proteus mirabilis - Negative</p>
<p><strong>Note</strong>
Results can be seen as from 30 minutes of incubation.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="onpg-beta-galactosidase-test">ONPG (BETA-GALACTOSIDASE) TEST<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#onpg-beta-galactosidase-test" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This test is employed to differentiate late lactose fermenting organisms from non-lactose fermenting ones.</p>
<p><strong>Principle</strong> Lactose is a disaccharide consisting of a molecule of glucose and galactose, joined by a beta-galactoside link. Lactose fermentation depends on the presence of two enzymes: a permease which controls the uptake of lactose into the cell, and a beta-D-galactosidase which metabolises lactose. Lack of permease causes delay in the fermentation of lactose. Certain bacteria which possess the beta galactosidase and not the permease are therefore potential lactose fermenters and may take several days to produce acid in the traditional peptone water. O-Nitrophenyl-beta-D-galactopyranoside (ONPG) is a colourless substance. When its galactoside linkage is broken, it gives a yellow compound. This indicates the presence of galactosidase activity.</p>
<p><strong>Medium</strong>
ONPG 0.6 g
0.01M Phosphate buffer (pH 7.5) 100 ml
Dissolve without heat and sterilise by filtration.</p>
<p>Add aseptically 1 part of the ONPG to three parts of 1% peptone water.</p>
<p>Dispense in aliquots of 2 ml.</p>
<p>Store at 4°C for up to 1 month.</p>
<p><strong>Test</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Inoculate the medium</li>
<li>Incubate at 37°C for 24 hours.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="oxidase-test-cytochrome-oxidase">OXIDASE TEST (CYTOCHROME OXIDASE)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#oxidase-test-cytochrome-oxidase" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This test is employed to aid in the identification of Pseudomonas, Neisseria, Vibrio and other groups.</p>
<p><strong>Principle</strong> The enzyme oxidase will oxidise a redox dye such as tetramethyl paraphenylene diamine dihydrochloride (TMPPDH) to deep purple colour. This enzyme is produced by some aerobic bacteria as part of their respiratory oxidation mechanism.</p>
<p><strong>Reagent</strong> 1% Tetramethyl paraphenylene diamine dihydrochloride in water.</p>
<p>Store in a dark bottle at 4°C or prepare fresh when required; or keep frozen until ready to use.</p>
<p><strong>Note</strong>
The oxidase reagent is unstable and is easily oxidised to blue colour. When oxidised, do not use the reagent again.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="test-methods">Test methods<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#test-methods" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="method-i">Method I<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#method-i" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Add a few drops of the oxidase reagent on to a few colonies on the culture plate.</li>
<li>Observe the colonies become blue to deep purple within 5–10 seconds.</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>Note</strong>
The colonies are killed by the reagent after a few minutes. If the colonies are required for further studies, they should be selected and picked quickly for subculture.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="method-ii">Method II<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#method-ii" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Add a loopful of reagent to filter paper in a petri dish.</li>
</ol>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>654 Bacteriology</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>Using a platinum or plastic loop, smear the suspected colony across the wetted filter paper.</li>
<li>Observe a purple colour appearing across the streak within 10 seconds.</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>Note</strong> Do not use nichrome wire loop as it is capable of initiating purple colour on its own.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="method-iii">Method III<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#method-iii" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Cut Whatman’s No.1 filter paper into strips and soak them in freshly prepared 1% solution of tetramethyl-paraphenylene diamine dihydrochloride.</li>
<li>Drain the strips for about 30 seconds and freeze dry them. The papers have a tint of purple.</li>
<li>Store in a dark container with tight fitting cover. They can keep for several months.</li>
<li>For use, remove a strip and moisten it with a drop of distilled water.</li>
<li>Pick the suspected colony with a plastic or platinum wire loop and smear over the moist area of the paper.</li>
<li>A deep purple colour appearing within 5–10 seconds indicates positive oxidase test.</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>Note</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>A delayed positive reaction may appear in about 10–30 seconds.</li>
<li>Absence of purple colouration after 30 seconds is a negative result.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="controls">Controls<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#controls" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Pseudomonas aeruginosa - Positive
E. coli - Negative</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="oxidation-fermentation-o-f-test">OXIDATION-FERMENTATION (O-F) TEST<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#oxidation-fermentation-o-f-test" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This test is used to differentiate those bacteria that ferment carbohydrates (anaerobic utilisation) such as E. coli, from those that oxidise carbohydrates (aerobic utilisation) such as Pseudomonas aeruginosa.</p>
<p><strong>Principle</strong> The utilisation of glucose (or any other carbohydrates) by oxidation or fermentation is critically different. Fermentation is anaerobic, and results in the formation of acids where as oxidation is aerobic and results in the formation of alkaline products.</p>
<p><strong>Medium</strong> Hugh and Leifson O-F medium (see Chapter 25).</p>
<p>Prepare the basal medium and dispense in 5.0 ml amounts in 100 × 12 mm tubes. Sterilisation is at 115°C for 10 minutes. Add 0.5 ml of sterile 10% glucose solution to each tube. The medium is semisolid in consistency.</p>
<p><strong>Note</strong> For organisms that grow poorly or not at all in the medium, enrich the medium with 2–5 % calf serum or 0.1 % yeast extract.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="test">Test<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#test" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Using a straight wire, inoculate the organism to the bottom of a pair of tubes.</li>
<li>Cover the inoculated medium in one tube with about 1.5 ml of sterile paraffin oil. Leave the other tube uncovered.</li>
<li>Incubate the tubes upright at 35–37°C for up to 4–5 days.</li>
<li>Examine daily for carbohydrate utilisation as shown by acid production as a colour change in the medium:</li>
</ol>
<table><thead><tr><th>Open tube</th><th>Sealed tube</th><th>Interpretation</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Yellow (acid)</td><td>Mauve (no change, or blue)</td><td>Oxidative</td></tr><tr><td>Yellow (acid)</td><td>Yellow (acid)</td><td>Fermentative</td></tr><tr><td>Mauve (no change, or blue)</td><td>Mauve (no change, or blue)</td><td>No utilisation of carbohydrate</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><strong>Note</strong> The colour produced depends on the indicator used in the medium.</p>
<p>Figure 10.3 shows the final pH in glucose utilisation by oxidative and fermentative bacteria.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Identification Methods 655</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-0516844c.jpeg" alt="img-69.jpeg">
Fig. 10.3 Oxidative and Fermentative utilisation of glucose</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="controls">Controls<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#controls" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Ps. aeruginosa - Oxidative
E. coli - Fermentative
Acinetobacter - Inactive</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="9d7a0240">♦ PHENYLALANINE DEAMINASE TEST<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#9d7a0240" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This test is used to assist in differentiating <em>Proteus</em> and <em>Providencia</em> species from other enterobacteria.</p>
<p><strong>Principle</strong> Some bacteria are able to deaminate phenylalanine (by oxidative deamination) with the production of phenylpyruvic acid (PPA). The PPA will react with ferric salts to produce a green colour. This test is also referred to as PPA test.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="medium">Medium<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#medium" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Prepare phenylalanine agar. (Chapter 25)</li>
<li>10% ferric chloride, aqueous solution.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="test">Test<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#test" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Inoculate the PPA medium fairly heavily with the test organism.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Incubate at 35–37°C overnight.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Add four or five drops of the freshly prepared 10% FeCl₃, by allowing it to run down over the growth on the slope.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Observe a green colour in the water of condensation and the slope. This green colour which is transient is positive phenylalanine deamination.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="controls">Controls<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#controls" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Proteus species - Positive
E. coli - Negative</p>
<p><strong>Note</strong> This test and the utilisation of malonate can be combined in one test.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="1583683f">♦ MALONATE UTILISATION TEST<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1583683f" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This test is used to assist in the identification of enterobacteria.</p>
<p><strong>Principle</strong> Some bacteria are able to utilise sodium malonate as the sole source of carbon and make the medium alkaline by the production of sodium carbonate.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="medium">Medium<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#medium" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Malonate-PPA medium.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="test">Test<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#test" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Inoculate the medium with the test organism.</li>
<li>Incubate at 37°C for up to 48 hours.</li>
<li>Observe change of colour from green to blue which indicates positive malonate utilisation.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="controls">Controls<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#controls" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Citrobacter diversus - Positive
E. coli - Negative</p>
<p><strong>Note</strong> 1. Use young culture of the test organism.
2. The indicator turns blue because of the production of alkaline products (rise in pH).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="a2ea41d2">♦ GLUCONATE TEST<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a2ea41d2" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This test is used to differentiate some coliform bacilli such as <em>Klebsiella</em>, <em>Enterobacter</em> and <em>E. coli</em>.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>656 Bacteriology</p>
<p>and also assists in the identification of <em>Ps.aeruginosa</em>.</p>
<p><strong>Principle</strong> Some bacteria are able to oxidise gluconic acid (gluconate) to a reducing compound, 2-keto-gluconate.</p>
<p><strong>Medium and reagent</strong> Gluconate medium (Chapter 25)
Benedicts qualitative reagent (Clinical Chemistry, Chapter 4)</p>
<p><strong>Test</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Inoculate 1 ml of gluconate broth with the test organism</li>
<li>Incubate for 48 hours at 37°C.</li>
<li>Add 1 ml of Benedict’s reagent</li>
<li>Mix and boil for 10 minutes.</li>
<li>Observe colour change:
Positive = Green to orange precipitate
Negative = Unchanged blue colour of Benedict’s solution.</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>Controls</strong>
<em>Ps. aeruginosa</em> - Positive
<em>E. coli</em> - Negative.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ad0127cc">♦ POTASSIUM CYANIDE (KCN) TEST<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ad0127cc" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This test is used as an aid in the differentiation of enterobacteria.</p>
<p><strong>Principle</strong> Potassium cyanide inhibits some enzymes involved with aerobic respiration, and therefore, some bacteria are inhibited while others are able to resist. The test is based on this difference whereby bacteria are challenged to grow in a nutrient broth with a concentration of KCN.</p>
<p><strong>Medium</strong> Potassium cyanide complete medium (Chapter 25).</p>
<p><strong>Test</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Inoculate KCN medium with a loopful of an overnight broth culture.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Screw down the cap of the bottle tightly to prevent air exchange.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Incubate at 37°C for up to 48 hours.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Turbidity in the medium indicates positive for the KCN test; no turbidity is negative.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>Caution</strong> KCN is poisonous; handle with care.</p>
<p><strong>Controls</strong>
<em>Citrobacter freundii</em> - Positive
<em>E. coli</em> - Negative</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="b6304908">♦ UREASE TEST<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b6304908" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is an important test for differentiating enterobacteria.</p>
<p><strong>Principle</strong> The enzyme urease is possessed by some bacteria. The urease is able to decompose urea by hydrolysis to give ammonia and carbon dioxide. This reaction turns the medium alkaline which is shown by a change in colour of the indicator to red-pink.</p>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mover><mo stretchy="true" minsize="3.0em">→</mo><mpadded width="+0.6em" lspace="0.3em"><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow></mpadded></mover><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mover><mo stretchy="true" minsize="3.0em">→</mo><mpadded width="+0.6em" lspace="0.3em"><mtext>Urease</mtext></mpadded></mover><mn>2</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{CO} \xrightarrow{\mathrm{NH_2}} \mathrm{H_2O} \xrightarrow{\text{Urease}} 2\mathrm{NH_3} + \mathrm{CO_2}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.1113em;
