<p>Dye concentrations:  a = 1/25,000.
b = 1/50,000.
c = 1/100,000.</p>
<p>722 Bacteriology</p>
<p>(1) Acute brucellosis This is the real undulant fever accompanied by prolonged septicaemia. It is mostly caused by <em>B. melitensis</em>. It is characterised by irregular fever which shows undulations of pyrexia. The symptoms include muscular pains, nocturnal drenching sweat, exhaustion, anorexia, constipation, chills and irritability.</p>
<p>(2) Chronic brucellosis This is usually a low grade infection and with the absence of bacteraemia. The clinical manifestations include sweating, joint pains with little or no fever.</p>
<p>(3) Latent brucellosis There are no clinical signs and symptoms. Diagnosis is based only on serological evidence.</p>
<p>Human infection results from ingesting unpasteurised infected milk and meat products. The organisms may also enter the host via damaged skin or through the mucous membrane of the eye; or by inhalation of air borne particles. Blood sucking insects also help in transmission from animal to animal or animal to man.</p>
<p>Brucella organisms spread from the initial site of infection through the lymphatic channels to the local lymph nodes in the reticuloendothelial cells of the spleen, liver, kidneys and bone marrow. From here, they spill over into the blood stream and are disseminated throughout the body.</p>
<p>Brucellosis is distributed worldwide, being endemic in some parts of the world. Human infections are caused by different species in different regions.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="laboratory-diagnosis">Laboratory Diagnosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#laboratory-diagnosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Specimens</strong> Specimens include blood for blood culture, serum for antibody testing, bone marrow, lymph node biopsy, joint aspirates, cerebrospinal fluid and abscess swab.</p>
<p>&gt; <strong>Note</strong>
&gt; Specimens for Brucella culture should carry the biohazard label and should be processed in the safety exhaust cabinet.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="microscopy">Microscopy<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#microscopy" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Stained Smear</strong> The organisms are Gram negative coccobacilli and may show bi-polar staining.</p>
<p><strong>Culture</strong> Blood culture is the most definitive method of diagnosis of acute brucellosis. The organisms grow very slowly and need prolonged incubation. <em>B. abortus</em> requires 5–10% CO₂ enriched atmosphere for primary isolation and so all blood cultures should be incubated in CO₂. <em>Brucella</em> blood cultures must be incubated at 37°C for at least 4–6 weeks before being reported as ‘No organisms isolated’.</p>
<p>The Castaneda method of blood culture was most popular for the isolation of <em>Brucella</em> species. The medium is diphasic, consisting of an agar slope and broth. The blood is inoculated into the broth and the bottle incubated in upright position. Colonies grow on the slant. This method minimises the risk of contamination and infection. Blood cultures are positive only for about 40% of cases. <em>B. abortus</em> is not difficult to isolate.</p>
<p>Serum-dextrose agar and tryptone soya agar are widely used to isolate <em>Brucella</em>. Tryptone soya agar containing various concentrations of dyes such as basic fushsin and thionin is used in the differentiation of the <em>Brucella</em> species (Table 15.3).</p>
<p>Colonies on solid media are small, moist, and glistening. In liquid media growth is uniform, but in old cultures a powdery deposit is formed.</p>
<p><strong>Identification tests</strong> Brucellae do not ferment carbohydrates but they possess oxidative capacity. Only a few biochemical tests are routinely used to identify the species:</p>
<ul>
<li>Catalase +</li>
<li>Oxidase + (B. neotomae and B. ovis are negative)</li>
<li>Nitrates reduction +</li>
<li>Citrate -</li>
<li>Indole -</li>
<li>MR -</li>
<li>VP -</li>
</ul>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Small Gram Negative Rods 723</p>
<p>The differential features of <em>Brucella</em> species and <em>bryopyces</em> are listed in Table 15.3.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="serology">Serology<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#serology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Since cultures are not always successful, serological testing for antibodies is very useful in the diagnosis of brucellosis. Several serological tests are employed: rapid slide agglutination, standard agglutination (tube agglutination test), 2-mercaptoethanol titration test, complement fixation test (CFT), antihuman globulin test (Coomb's test) and enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA).</p>
<p>The somatic antigens of <em>Brucella</em> species contain two main determinants called A and M. The amounts of A and M antigens in the three major species vary. <em>B. abortus</em> contains about 20 times as much A as M, <em>B. melitensis</em> contains about 20 times as much M as A; and <em>B. suis</em> contains an intermediate pattern. Absorbed A and M monospecific sera are used for the species identification of <em>Brucella</em>.</p>
<p>In <em>Brucella</em> infection, IgM followed by IgG antibodies appear in the blood within 7–10 days after the onset of the disease. Antibody response in acute brucellosis is in the form of high levels of IgM. The IgM levels gradually fall as the disease progresses, but IgG antibodies persist or increase in titre. This persistence is pronounced in chronic brucellosis or as a result of immunisation from drinking infected milk.</p>
<p>Following successful treatment, however, The IgG antibodies gradually disappears over a period of several months while the IgM antibody titre falls rapidly and disappears within a few weeks.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="agglutination-tests">Agglutination tests<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#agglutination-tests" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>(1) Slide test The slide test is a screening test which is employed in high risk areas to cut down on materials and time. However, all positive slide tests should be confirmed by the tube agglutination test.</p>
<p>It is in the first instance a qualitative test in which stained <em>Brucella</em> antigen suspension is mixed with a drop of the patient's serum. A slide titration test is possible but the titre obtained is regarded as a general guide as to whether the antibody value is high or low.</p>
<p>&gt; <strong>Note</strong>
&gt; Brucella stained antigen suspension is available commercially The same antigen suspension is used for both slide and tube agglutination.</p>
<p>(2) Standard agglutination test (SAT) This is the tube agglutination test in which serial doubling dilutions of the patient's serum are made in phenol saline in 1 ml volumes for <em>B. abortus</em> and <em>B. melitensis</em>. A drop of stained respective antigen suspension is added to each dilution and then incubated at 37°C for 24–48 hours. Positive and negative control sera must be run along with the test.</p>
<p>Some sera contain ‘blocking’ or ‘non agglutinating’ antibodies (which are usually IgA), which cause agglutination to occur only in higher dilutions and not in lower ones. This is known as Prozone reaction or phenomenon. The following is an example of an agglutination test showing prozone phenomenon.</p>
<p>|  Dilutions
Agglutination | 1:20
– | 1:40
– | 1:80</p>
<ul>
<li>| 1:160</li>
<li>| 1:320</li>
<li>| 1:640</li>
<li>|
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |</li>
</ul>
<p>The prozone effect can be eliminated by</p>
<ol>
<li>Pre-heating the serum at 56°C for 30 minutes.</li>
<li>Using 5% phenol saline as diluent for the test.</li>
<li>Extending the serum dilutions up to 1/1280.</li>
<li>By performing the Coomb's antihuman globulin test.</li>
</ol>
<p>For more details on the agglutination tests for <em>Brucella</em>, you are referred to Immunology section.</p>
<p>(3) 2-mercaptoethanol agglutination test This test is performed in a similar manner as the tube agglutination test except that the diluent used is 0.05M 2-mercaptoethanol phosphate buffered saline. The IgM antibodies are selectively destroyed by the 2-mercaptoethanol. Therefore, any agglutination test is performed.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>724 Bacteriology</p>
<p>nation occurring is due to IgG antibodies which are not affected by the 2-mercaptoethanol.</p>
<p><strong>Testing for <em>Brucella</em> antibodies in milk</strong>Brucella* bacilli are excreted in the milk of infected cows and goats. The milk also contains antibodies which are detected by:</p>
<p>(1) <strong>Milk ring test</strong> A sample of whole milk is mixed well with a drop of haematoxylin stained <em>Brucella</em> antigen (a concentrated suspension of killed <em>B. abortus</em>) and incubated at 37°C for about 50 minutes. If antibodies are present in the milk, the bacilli are agglutinated and rise with the cream to the top and form a blue ring, leaving the milk unstained. If antibodies are absent, the milk remains uniformly coloured with no blue ring at the top.</p>
<p>(2) <strong>Whey agglutination test</strong> To 2 ml of milk sample in a conical flask are added 100 ml of renin and 10 ml chloroform, mixed well, and incubated at 37°C for two hours. The milk clot is then centrifuged to obtain the liquid whey for testing. The whey agglutination is carried out just like the serum agglutination.</p>
<p>A titre greater than 20 is indicative of infection of the individual animal, provided there is no history of recent vaccination.</p>
<p><strong><em>Brucella</em> bacteriophage</strong> There are several bacteriophages that lyse <em>Brucella</em> strains. The reference phage is the Tblisi (Tb) phage which at Routine test dose (RTD) does not lyse <em>B. melitensis</em> but will lyse <em>B. abortus</em>, <em>B. suis</em> is lysed at 10,000 RTD.</p>
<p><strong>Antibiotic sensitivity</strong> <em>Brucella</em> species are sensitive to tetracycline, streptomycin and cotrimoxazole. For acute brucellosis, tetracycline is the drug of choice.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Chapter 16</p>
<p>Mycobacteria</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="genus-mycobacterium">GENUS MYCOBACTERIUM<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#genus-mycobacterium" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Mycobacteria are slender, straight or slightly curved, non-motile rods; are aerobic, non-capsulated and non-sporing. They do not stain easily but once stained, they resist decolourisation with dilute mineral acids. They are therefore referred to as acid fast bacilli (AFB). Mycobacteria are aerobic, non-capsulated and non-sporing. They comprise obligate pathogens, opportunistic pathogens and saprophytes.</p>
<p>Type species <em>M. tuberculosis</em> (tubercle bacilli). More than forty species of mycobacteria are recognised.</p>
<p><em>M. tuberculosis</em> complex is the term used to describe <em>M. tuberculosis</em>, <em>M. africanum</em> and <em>M. bovis</em> collectively.</p>
<p>Atypical mycobacteria Saprophytic mycobacteria which are non-tubercle bacilli and isolated from a number of environmental sources are loosely grouped under the term ‘atypical’ or anonymous mycobacteria. Most of these organisms have now been speciated and the term atypical or anonymous is no longer used; instead they are referred to as environmental mycobacteria. However, some workers still make use of Runyon’s classification which divides the organisms into groups (i)-(iv).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="mycobacteria-of-clinical-importance">Mycobacteria of Clinical Importance<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#mycobacteria-of-clinical-importance" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<table><thead><tr><th>Pathogens</th><th>Diseases</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>M. tuberculosis</td><td>Tuberculosis</td></tr><tr><td>M. africanum</td><td>Tuberculosis</td></tr><tr><td>M. bovis</td><td>Tuberculosis</td></tr><tr><td>M. leprae</td><td>Leprosy</td></tr><tr><td>M. ulcerans (M. buruli)</td><td>Skin ulcers</td></tr><tr><td>(Buruli ulcer).</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="opportunistic-pathogens">Opportunistic pathogens<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#opportunistic-pathogens" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<table><thead><tr><th>Pathogens</th><th>Diseases</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>M. kansasii</td><td>Mostly pulmonary infections</td></tr><tr><td>M. malmoense</td><td>Mostly pulmonary infections</td></tr><tr><td>M. szulgai</td><td>Mostly pulmonary infections</td></tr><tr><td>M. simiae</td><td>Mostly pulmonary infections</td></tr><tr><td>M. xenopi</td><td>Mostly pulmonary infections</td></tr><tr><td>M. avium intracellulare</td><td>Mainly cervical adenitis especially in children.</td></tr><tr><td>M. scrofulaceum</td><td>Mainly cervical adenitis especially in children.</td></tr><tr><td>M. fortuitum</td><td>Mainly skin infections.</td></tr><tr><td>M. chelonei</td><td>Mainly skin infections.</td></tr><tr><td>M. marinum (M. balnei)</td><td>Skin infection and may involve superficial lymph glands.</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="af201ee6">Runyon’s Classification<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#af201ee6" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Mycobacteria grow on protein enriched culture media. The only exceptions to this statement is</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>726 Bacteriology</p>
<p>M. leprae which does not grow on any artificial culture media. Some saprophytic species such as M. fortuitum and M. chelonei are able to grow on nutrient agar. Mycobacteria require CO₂ enriched atmosphere for improved growth.</p>
<p>Cultural differentiation of mycobacteria is based on:</p>
<p>(1) Rate of growth.
(2) Temperature of growth.
(3) Production of pigments in light and darkness.</p>
<p><strong>Rate of growth</strong> The organisms grow slowly. Appearance of colonies may be delayed for up to 6–8 weeks. M. fortuitum and M. chelonei and many saprophytic species, however, produce colonies within 2–5 days.</p>
<p><strong>Temperature of growth</strong> The optimum temperature of growth for most mycobacteria is 35–37°C. A few species e.g. M. ulcerans, M. fortuitum, can grow at 30–32°C.</p>
<p><strong>Pigment production</strong> Some mycobacteria species can produce pigments when incubated in darkness or light; and the following terms are used to describe the various pigment productions:</p>
<p>(i) Photochromogen (Runyon Group I) A Mycobacterium species that produces pigment only when exposed to light.</p>
<p>Examples: M. kansasii, M. marinum, M. simiae (M. habana).</p>
<p>(ii) Scotochromogen (Runyon Group II) A Mycobacterium species that produces a pigment when grown in the dark and in the light. This pigment is usually yellow or yellow orange becoming deeper in colour as growth progresses.</p>
<p>Examples: M. scrofulaceum, M. szulgai.</p>
<p>(iii) Non-chromogon (Runyon Group III) This is a Mycobacterium species that does not produce pigment in the light or in darkness.</p>
<p>Examples: M. tuberculosis, M. bovis, M. fortuitum, M. chelonei.</p>
<p>(iv) Rapid Growers (Runyon Group IV) These mature from small inocula at room temperature in 2–7 days. They are usually non-pigmented. Examples are M. smegmatis, M. phlei.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="culture-media-for-mycobacteria">Culture Media for Mycobacteria<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#culture-media-for-mycobacteria" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Lowenstein-Jensen (LJ) glycerol medium This is the recommended medium for human type of tubercle bacilli. The malachite green in the medium is inhibitory to organisms other than mycobacteria, and also provides a colour contrast which makes it easy to recognise colonies even when they are small. Glycerol in the medium enhances the growth of M. tuberculosis but not that of M. bovis which may fail to grow on it.</li>
</ol>
<p>The colonies of M. tuberculosis on LJ medium are rough, tough, buff to yellowish in colour and luxuriant (eugonic growth).</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>Lowenstein Jensen (LJ) pyruvate medium This medium is used for the isolation of M. bovis because glycerol in the standard medium is inhibitory to it.</li>
</ol>
<p>The colonies of M. bovis are tiny and transparent, later becoming white. Growth is poor even when confluent (dysgonic growth).</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>
<p>Dorset egg medium This simple medium is suitable for the growth of laboratory strains of tubercle bacilli.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Dubo’s medium This is one of the earliest liquid medium that gives uniformly dispersed cultures used for sensitivity tests and biochemical tests.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Selective Kirchner medium This enrichment medium is ideal for specimens other than sputum and should be used in parallel with LJ medium.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Middlebrook 7H9 broth This medium is used for the isolation, cultivation and identification of mycobacteria.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="staining-characteristics">Staining Characteristics<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#staining-characteristics" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Mycobacteria are known for their acid fastness: When they are stained with carbol fuchsin in the Ziehl-Neelsen’s(ZN) method, the bacilli are able to retain the red colour of the stain after being treated with mineral acid solution. The reasons for this is because the organisms contain a thick cell wall which is composed of waxes and lipids with high content of mycolic fatty acids. The heated</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Mycobacteria 727</p>
<p>stain is able to penetrate the thick cell wall. Because they resist decolourisation with mineral acids, the organisms are referred to as 'acid fast' bacilli. They stain poorly with Gram's method, appearing as Gram positive (shadow cells). The degree of acid fastness varies from species to species. M. leprae for example, is much less acid fast than M. tuberculosis. For such species like M. leprae, a weaker acid solution is used for decolourisation.</p>
<p><strong>Note</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Nocardia species and some Corynebacterium species are also acid fast.</li>
<li>Routinely acid alcohol is used for decolourisation in the ZN technique for tubercle bacilli because it gives a clearer background. Some workers use the term acid-alcohol fast, even though the alcohol is not essential in the technique.</li>
<li>Most bacteria are readily destroyed by acids and alkalis while mycobacteria show resistance. For this reason, some specimens e.g. sputum and urine, are decontaminated with acid or alkali before culturing for M. tuberculosis.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="criteria-for-the-identification-of-mycobacteria">Criteria for the Identification of Mycobacteria<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#criteria-for-the-identification-of-mycobacteria" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The criteria for the identification of mycobacteria are based on the result of some identification tests together with the cultural characteristics and positive ZN stain.</p>
<p>Identification features for mycobacteria are shown in Table 16.1.</p>
<p>The usual identifications tests for mycobacteria are:</p>
<ol>
<li>Growth on medium containing 500 µg/ml para-nitro-benzoic acid.</li>
<li>Growth on medium containing 10 µg/ml thiacetazone.</li>
<li>Nitrate reduction.</li>
<li>Arylsulphatase test.</li>
<li>Tween 80 hydrolysis test.</li>
<li>Catalase-peroxidase test.</li>
<li>Niacin test.</li>
<li>Urease production.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="161d2741">♦ MYCOBACTERIUM TUBERCULOSIS (Human Tubercle Bacilli)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#161d2741" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>It is the major cause of tuberculosis in man. Other causative agents of tuberculosis include M. bovis and M. africanum. M. tuberculosis was originally referred to as Koch's bacillus after Robert Koch who first identified it in 1882.</p>
<p><strong>Habitat</strong> M. tuberculosis is found in infected humans and is transmitted to primates, dogs and other animals that are in close association with man. M. bovis is the causative agent of tuberculosis in cattle and is transmissible to man, primates, pigs and domestic animals.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pathogenicity">Pathogenicity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathogenicity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>M. tuberculosis causes tuberculosis in man, primates and dogs. The disease is contagious.</p>
<p>The main route of the bacilli entering the body is by inhalation of droplets or dust particles containing the bacilli. Factors such as dose, virulence, age and immune status of the host, contribute to determine the course of the disease. Thus, tuberculosis can occur in different forms:</p>
<p><strong>Pulmonary tuberculosis</strong> In primary infection, the bacilli lodge in the pulmonary alveoli and the surrounding lymph glands resulting in lesions characterised by acute inflammatory reaction with accumulation of fluid and white blood cells around the bacilli. The lesions may heal by resolution; or advance to the productive stage. This stage results in liquefied destruction and breakdown of infected lung tissue into a cheese-like mass (caseation). This is a productive type of lesion as the yellow pieces of caseation material containing large number of the bacilli are coughed out in sputum by the patient. The infection creates cavities in the lung making breathing difficult.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Table 16.1 Identification features of mycobacteria</p>
<table><thead><tr><th></th><th>Growth at</th><th></th><th></th><th>Rate of growth</th><th>Pigment in dark</th><th>Pigment photo-activated</th><th>Niacin production</th><th>Nitrate avium-intracellulare</td><td>+</td><td>+</td><td>±</td><td>S</td><td>-</td><td>-</td><td>-</td><td>-</td><td>-</td><td>+</td><td>±</td></tr><tr><td>M.
