chelonei</td><td>+</td><td>+</td><td>-</td><td>R</td><td>-</td><td>-</td><td>-</td><td>-</td><td>-</td><td>+</td><td>+</td></tr><tr><td>M. malmoense</td><td>+</td><td>+</td><td>+</td><td>S</td><td>-</td><td>-</td><td>-</td><td>-</td><td>+</td><td>+</td><td>-</td></tr><tr><td>M. simiae</td><td>+</td><td>+</td><td>-</td><td>S</td><td>-</td><td>+</td><td>-</td><td>-</td><td>-</td><td>+</td><td>+</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>S = slow; M = intermediate; R = rapid growth</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Mycobacteria 729</p>
<p>The symptoms of pulmonary tuberculosis in adult include chronic cough with the production of mucopurulent sputum which may contain blood (haemoptysis), loss of weight, fever, tiredness, chest pain, anaemia and night sweats (during sleep). The disease in children is not easy to diagnose since there is hardly any productive cough. The symptoms are usually weight loss and enlargement of the lymph glands which may cause obstruction of the bronchi and emphysema.</p>
<p>Complications of the disease include pleural effusion, lung collapse, acute miliary tuberculosis and tuberculous meningitis, especially in children.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="non-pulmonary-tuberculosis">Non-pulmonary tuberculosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#non-pulmonary-tuberculosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>(i) Renal and urogenital tuberculosis The bacilli find their way to the kidney and genital tract via the blood stream. Suspicion is aroused when repeated urine specimens show pus cells with negative urine culture. The late symptoms may include frequency and haematuria with an on and off fever. The infection may result in pelvic inflammatory disease and infertility.</p>
<p>(ii) Miliary tuberculosis The rupture of a site of primary infection into a vein, results in a spread of infection to other parts of the body. This is referred to as miliary tuberculosis. Symptomatically, the patient is very ill with fever. The chest X-ray film usually shows wide spread fine nodules. There is usually low white cell count. The liver, spleen and lymph glands are enlarged and meningitis may also occur.</p>
<p>(iii) Tuberculous (TB) meningitis Tuberculous meningitis occurs most commonly in infants and young children following a primary tuberculosis infection. The fatality is high unless treated promptly. When the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) contains high count of lymphocytes, tuberculosis should be excluded.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="laboratory-diagnosis">Laboratory Diagnosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#laboratory-diagnosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>All procedures involving <em>M. tuberculosis</em> must be carried out in the safety cabinet located in the special TB room.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="specimens">Specimens<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#specimens" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These include sputum, pleural effusion, CSF and urine.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="microscopy">Microscopy<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#microscopy" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="stained-smears">Stained smears<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#stained-smears" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>(i) Gram stain Due to its resistant cell wall, Gram stain is not routinely done for tubercle bacilli.</p>
<p>(ii) Ziehl-Neelsen (ZN) stain Smears are made directly from the sputum or any other specimen after proper treatment and stained by Ziehl-Neelsen's method. The bacilli are stained red against a blue or green background (depending whether the counterstain used is methylene blue or malachite green). At least 100 fields should be examined before a negative smear report is given. On the average, 10–15 minutes should be spent on one slide. A positive report is given only if two or three typical bacilli have been seen. Usually positive smears are graded depending on the number of bacilli seen e.g. 1+ when 3–9 bacilli are seen in the entire smear, 2+ when 10 or more are seen in the smear, and 3+ when 10 or more are seen in most of the fields. Some workers count and report the number of bacilli per high power field.</p>
<p>Smears of <em>M. tuberculosis</em> culture may show 'cording' (the clumping together of the bacilli like pieces of strings or cord caused by the culture not being easily emulsified.</p>
<p>(iii) Fluorescent microscopy The bacilli, when stained with fluorescent-stains such as auramine phenol or auramine-rhodamine, fluoresce bright yellow against a dark background. Because of the sharp contrast, the bacilli are readily seen under the high power dry objective, making it possible to cover large areas of smear in a short time. This technique is useful for screening where several smears are examined daily. Positive slides may be stained with ZN stain for confirmation. This may however not be necessary if the microscopist has sufficient expertise and experience to recognise AFBs.</p>
<p>Microscopic demonstration of acid fast bacilli is only a presumptive diagnosis of tuberculosis. This is because some saprophytic species stain similarly with <em>M. tuberculosis</em>.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>730 Bacteriology</p>
<p><strong>Note</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>M. tuberculosis bacilli may show 'beaded' or 'barred' appearance which the saprophytic one's do not show.</li>
<li>Always include a control AFB smear (alcohol fixed) with any batch of smears to be stained.</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>Concentration methods</strong> Sputum and other specimens are homogenised and concentrated before they are processed for microscopy, culture or animal inoculation. There are several methods for achieving this; some of them kill the tubercle bacilli in which case they are used for microscopy only while others concentrate the bacilli without inactivating them so that they are useful for culture. Some of the concentration methods also decontaminate the specimens by killing other microorganisms that may be present in the specimen.</p>
<p><strong>Note</strong>
It is a must that all procedures involving M. tuberculosis are carried out in the safety cabinet located in the special TB room.</p>
<p><strong>Petroff's method</strong> This method used to be popular and widely used for its simplicity:</p>
<ol>
<li>Mix the sputum with equal volume of 4% sodium hydroxide.</li>
<li>Incubate at 37°C and shake at intervals, for about 20 minutes (or till when, the mixture becomes clear).</li>
<li>Centrifuge at 3000 rpm for 30 minutes.</li>
<li>Neutralise the sediment with N/10 HCl.</li>
<li>Use the treated sediment for smear, culture and animal inoculation.</li>
</ol>
<p>The above technique can be modified to use, instead of alkali, dilute acids e.g. 6% sulphuric acid; 3% hydrochloric acid and 5% oxalic acid and then neutralised with alkali.</p>
<p><strong>Sputazole</strong> Sputazole is one of the recently developed reagents used to homogenise sputum. Instruction for use is usually enclosed in the pack.</p>
<p><strong>Note</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Many laboratories have stopped the concentration of tubercle bacilli by centrifugation. Instead, a measured volume of the homogenised sputum is inoculated directly onto an acid culture medium such as a Lowenstein Jensen medium. This minimises the risk of spread of infection through aerosols during centrifugation. The direct inoculation is therefore cheaper, and safer than the centrifuge technique.</li>
<li>Excessive exposure to alkali is detrimental and so this should be avoided.</li>
<li>If a sodium hydroxide treated sputum is to be inoculated directly, the culture medium should be buffered to an acid pH.</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>Culture</strong>
A definitive diagnosis of tuberculosis is dependent on the isolation and identification of M. tuberculosis by culture. Many laboratories send their specimens for culture and sensitivity to a tuberculosis reference centre where full and controlled facilities are available for isolation and identification of Mycobacterium species.</p>
<p><strong>Routine culture</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Inoculate at least two LJ media with the liquefied specimens.</li>
<li>Incubate in the specialised incubators (maintains cultures at controlled temperatures) at 35–37°C.</li>
<li>Examine cultures for growth at four days (for rapid growing mycobacteria, fungi and contaminant bacteria). Thereafter at least twice a week for eight weeks.</li>
<li>A negative culture report is given if no growth occurs at eight weeks.</li>
<li>Make smears from colonies that appear on the media and stain by ZN method and examine.</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>Result</strong> A slow growing, non-pigmented, acid-alcohol fast bacillus is highly suggestive of M. tuberculosis.</p>
<p>Confirm the organism by animal inoculation and niacin test.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Mycobacteria 731</p>
<p>A positive niacin test is diagnostic, that is, the organism is tubercle bacillus. A niacin negative result will require further identification tests to be performed.</p>
<p><strong>Animal inoculation</strong> Animal inoculation was used to diagnose tuberculosis in the recent past. Due to the high risk of spread of infection involved in the procedure, it is no longer commonly practised. The student is referred to the manual of the Tuberculosis Reference Laboratory for details about animal inoculation.</p>
<p><strong>Computerised systems</strong> e.g. Bactec: The automated computerised systems can be used for the isolation of <em>M. tuberculosis</em>. The systems are quick, reliable but expensive. Most hospital laboratories cannot afford the set-up and so the manual culture methods are still used.</p>
<p><strong>Sensitivity testing</strong> Drug resistance is a common occurrence with mycobacteria. It is advisable to perform sensitivity test on all freshly isolated strains. There are three types of sensitivity tests for tubercle bacilli:</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p><strong>Absolute concentration method</strong> A number of culture media containing serial dilutions of the drug are inoculated and the minimum inhibitory concentration calculated from the lowest dilution that inhibits growth.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><strong>Resistance ratio</strong> Two sets of media containing graded concentrations of the drug are inoculated, one with the isolated organism and the other with a standard strain of known sensitivity. The standard strain used is usually the H37RV.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>The resistance of the test strain is expressed as a ratio of the two.</p>
<ol start="3">
<li><strong>Proportion method</strong> The method shows the average sensitivity of a strain since a population of tubercle bacilli will always show a proportion that is resistant to the drug.</li>
</ol>
<p>Sensitivity testing is very helpful if a relapse occurs during a course of treatment. In many parts of the world, the sensitivity test is performed only in the reference laboratory.</p>
<p><strong>Choice of antibiotic</strong> Antimicrobials effective for treatment of tuberculosis include isoniazid (INH), streptomycin, p-aminosalicylic acid (PAS), thiacetazone, rifampicin, ethambutol and pyrazinamide.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="hypersensitivity-and-immunity">Hypersensitivity and Immunity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hypersensitivity-and-immunity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Infection with <em>M. tuberculosis</em> induces delayed hypersensitivity (allergy) and immunity (resistance to infection). Koch demonstrated allergy and immunity (Koch phenomenon) by injecting subcutaneously virulent tubercle bacilli into a guinea pig which had been infected with <em>M. tuberculosis</em> 4–6 weeks earlier. Within two days, an indurated lesion appears at the site of injection which undergoes necrosis in another day to form a shallow ulcer that heals up rapidly without involving the surrounding tissues and lymph nodes. In a previously unexposed guinea pig, a nodule forms at the site within two weeks, ulcerates and the ulcer will persist till the death of the animal.</p>
<p>Hypersensitivity can be induced not only by virulent tubercle bacilli but also by injecting attenuated or killed bacilli. This is the basis of the tuberculin test.</p>
<p><strong>Tuberculin test</strong> This test is used to test for a present or past immune response (sensitisation) to mycobacteria. Koch initially prepared a protein extract of the organism. The bacilus was grown in 5% glycerol broth, filtered and then concentrated 10 times by evaporation. This was called ‘original’ or ‘old tuberculin’ (OT). This preparation was later abandoned due to its adverse effects on the patients. It was replaced by a purified standardised preparation of active tuberculo-protein of bacilli grown in a synthetic medium. This is called purified protein derivative (PPD). The test is performed by injecting into the skin a small amount of PPD. There are several ways of doing the tuberculin test. The common method of the tuberculin test in use is the Mantoux test.</p>
<p><strong>Mantoux test</strong> In this test, a test dose of tuberculin is injected intradermally on the forearm with the tuberculin syringe and needle. After 48–72 hours, a positive reaction is denoted by oedema and induration at the site of injection, measuring about 10 mm or more in diameter. Individuals with pre</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>732 Bacteriology</p>
<p>vious infection (clinical or sub-clinical), will give positive result. Other antigenically related mycobacteria (e.g. some atypical mycobacteria) cause false positive result. Where large numbers of people are to be screened, the Heaf test is used. In Heaf test, a standardised suspension of PPD is applied over the skin surface and a Heaf gun is used to make multiple punctures. The results are read as in Mantoux test.</p>
<p>&gt; <strong>Not</strong>
&gt; A test dose of 0.1 ml PPD or OT containing five Tuberculin Units is used. If completely negative, the test may be repeated with higher dose e.g. 10 or 100 Tuberculin Units.</p>
<p>Control Some measures in the general prevention of tuberculosis include adequate nutrition, well ventilated houses and general health education. Immunoprophylaxis is achieved by BCG vaccination.</p>
<p>BCG (Bacille Calmette-Guerin) vaccine The vaccine is the live attenuated strain of <em>M. bovis</em> which is given by injection to protect against tuberculosis. In most developing countries, the BCG is given to children in the first year of life. The level of protection after BCG vaccination is controversial. In some countries, it is claimed to be good and lasts for years; in others it is poor.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ae8241f0">♦ MYCOBACTERIUM LEPRAE (Leprosy Bacillus)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ae8241f0" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><em>M. leprae</em> is the causative agent of leprosy. It was first observed microscopically by Hansen in 1897. It has not been grown on artificial culture media.</p>
<p>Habitat <em>M. leprae</em> is present in the nose and upper respiratory tract of infected persons. The infection is acquired by prolonged contact with an infected person mainly through inhalation. The actual pathogenesis is not fully understood but it is possibly inhaled or gains direct entry through the skin.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pathogenicity">Pathogenicity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathogenicity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Leprosy is worldwide in distribution, being most common in the South and Central America, Africa, South East Asia, Far East and parts of the Middle East.</p>
<p>It is a chronic condition that affects mainly the skin and peripheral nerves. It is not a highly contagious disease. There are five forms of clinical leprosy, depending on the patient's cell mediated immune response.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="types-of-leprosy">Types of Leprosy<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#types-of-leprosy" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Tuberculoid leprosy (TT) There is a good cell-mediated immune response (CMI) and usually only a single or very few well-defined skin lesions are present. The lesions are flattened and hypopigmented with raised edges. There is no sense of touch or perspiration. The loss of feeling is due to the destruction of the nerve tissues by inflammatory cells which may lead to deformities of hands and feet. No organisms are found in skin or nasal smears.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Borderline tuberculoid (BT) leprosy The skin lesions are few in number and the CMI is less than in TT. There is marked loss of feeling, perspiration and pigment. Skin smears show very scanty bacteria while the nasal smears contain none at all.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Mid-borderline (BB) leprosy The immune response CMI in this type is only partial and lesions may be many. There is a slight to moderate loss of feeling and perspiration. Skin smears show numerous bacteria while nasal smears contain none.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Borderline lepromatous (BL) leprosy In this type, there is a poor CMI and there is only a slight to moderate loss of feeling and perspiration. Skin smears may show numerous bacteria in the BL disease while the nasal smears show only a few.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Lepromatous leprosy (LL) There is no CMI. The lesions are small and appear in many</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Mycobacteria 733</p>
<p>parts of the body. There is no loss of feeling and nodules may appear on the face and trunk. Skin and nasal smears show numerous organisms. The bacteria multiply mainly in the macrophages in the dermis of the skin.</p>
<p>Table 16.2 shows the differentiation of the types of leprosy.</p>
<p>&gt; <strong>Note</strong> When only the nerves are affected with no skin lesions, the condition is referred to as Neural leprosy.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="laboratory-diagnosis">Laboratory Diagnosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#laboratory-diagnosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Specimens</strong> Tissue juice is collected by a special technique for microscopy. Other specimens of value include nasal swab or washings and skin scraping. Biopsy is required for histopathological diagnosis of leprosy.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="collection-of-specimen">Collection of specimen<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#collection-of-specimen" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li><strong>Skin smears</strong> Skin smears should be collected from the following groups of patients:</li>
</ol>
<p>(i) Patients with visible skin lesions: Take at least three smears, one from the ear lobe and two from the active parts of the lesions. Usually, one smear is taken from the centre and the other from the edge of the lesion.</p>
<p>(ii) Patients without visible skin lesions: If it is an old case with records of previous positive sites, take smears from the two ear lobes and from previously active sites from which original smears were made. If there is no record, take six smears: from both ear lobes, the back of both fore arms and fronts of the thighs just above the knees.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="method-of-collecting-skin-smears">Method of collecting skin smears<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#method-of-collecting-skin-smears" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>(i) Mark the areas from where the smears are to be collected on the outline drawing of the body in the patient's notes.</p>
<p>(ii) Cleanse the area from where the smear is to be taken with a cotton wool swabs soaked in 70% ethyl alcohol.</p>
<p>(iii) Hold a fold of the skin tightly between the thumb and forefinger.</p>
<p>(iv) With a sterile blade, make a small cut through the skin surface, 5 mm long and about 2–3 mm deep.</p>
<p>(v) Wipe away any blood at the site of the cut with a dry piece of cotton wool. There should be little or no bleeding if the skin is held tightly.</p>
<p>(vi) Turn the scalpel blade until it is at right angle to the cut. With blunt edge of the blade, scrape firmly 2–3 times along the edges and the bottom of the cut.</p>
<p>(vii) Make a small circular smear, about 5–7 mm in diameter, on a clean slide, with the tissue juice and cells. Label the slide with date and patient's name and number.</p>
<p>(viii) Protect the smears from direct sunlight, dust and flies until they are ready to be stained.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="table-16-2-differentiation-of-types-of-leprosy">Table 16.2 Differentiation of types of leprosy<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#table-16-2-differentiation-of-types-of-leprosy" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<table><thead><tr><th></th><th>TT</th><th>BT</th><th>BB</th><th>BL</th><th>LL</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>M. leprae in lesions</td><td>±</td><td>+</td><td>+</td><td>++</td><td>+++</td></tr><tr><td>M. leprae in nose</td><td>-</td><td>-</td><td>-</td><td>+</td><td>+++</td></tr><tr><td>Cell mediated immunity (CMI)</td><td>Good</td><td>Good</td><td>Fair</td><td>Poor</td><td>Absent</td></tr><tr><td>Antibody level</td><td>Low</td><td>Low</td><td>Moderate</td><td>High</td><td>Very high</td></tr><tr><td>Lepromin test</td><td>++</td><td>+</td><td>±</td><td>±</td><td>-</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>TT = Tuberculoid leprosy; BT = Borderline tuberculoid; BB = Mid-borderline leprosy; BL = Borderline lepromatous; LL = Lepromatous leprosy</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>734 Bacteriology</p>
<p>(ix) Sterilise the scalpel blades after use if they are non-disposable.</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>Nasal smears The nasal mucosa is rich in <em>M. leprae</em> though other saprophytic mycobacteria may also be present. Nasal smears are not as reliable as the skin smears. The smears can be made from nasal swab, washings or from nose blows.</li>
</ol>
<p>(i) Nasal swab: by swabbing the area near the nasal septum.
(ii) Nasal washings: after instilling a few drops of saline in the nose and blowing into a small sheet of plastic or cellophane.
(iii) Nose blow: by the patient blowing hard onto a small sheet of plastic or cellophane, soon after waking up in the morning.</p>
<p><strong>Note</strong> Dispose off the used sheet of plastic by burning.</p>
<p>Microscopy <em>M. leprae</em> bacilli are non-motile, non-sporing straight or slightly curved organisms. They are typically seen tightly packed in macrophage cells though single extracellular ones are also seen. The packed bacilli are referred to as globi.</p>
<p>The leprosy bacilli are acid fast but less so than the <em>M. tuberculosis</em> and so a weaker solution of acid is used for decolourisation.</p>
<p>Ideally, two smears should be stained by the ZN method, the one with a strong acid decolouriser (e.g. 20% H₂SO₄) and the other with a weak acid decolouriser (e.g. 5% H₂SO₄). <em>M. leprae</em> may thus be distinguished from <em>M. tuberculosis</em> as it will be acid-fast only in the 5% H₂SO₄.</p>
<p>Reporting of smears The method of reporting <em>M. leprae</em> smears is to record the total number of bacilli in smears as a Bacterial Index (BI). The BI is used to monitor progress and treatment of the patient.</p>
<p>Technique for BI The number of bacilli in a globus may be difficult to be accurately counted, so it is usually assumed that:</p>
<ul>
<li>A large globus contains about 100 organisms.</li>
<li>A medium globus contains about 60 organisms.</li>
<li>A small globus contains about 30 organisms.</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li>If bacteria are found in almost every oil immersion field, estimate the number of bacilli in each field and record as follows:</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>&gt; 1000 per field = BI 6</li>
<li>100–1000 per field = BI 5</li>
<li>10–100 per field = BI 4</li>
<li>1–10 per field = BI 3</li>
</ul>
<ol start="2">
<li>If bacteria are not found in almost every oil immersion field, systematically examine the smear and record as follows:</li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li>1–10 bacilli per 10 fields = BI 2</li>
<li>1–10 bacilli per 100 fields = BI 1</li>
<li>No bacilli in 100 fields = BI 0</li>
</ul>
<p><strong>Note</strong> It is important to include positive smears from cases of treated and untreated lepromatous leprosy in each batch of slides.</p>
<p>Morphological Index (MI) This is the percentage of bacilli showing uniform staining i.e. viable organisms in the smear. It is used to monitor the response of a patient to anti-leprosy drugs. The viable organisms appear clearly as evenly stained red rods.</p>
<p>The non-viable organisms are the dead or dying ones and they stain poorly and unevenly, showing beaded, fragmented or granular appearance. (Fig. 16.1)</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-6858f78b.jpeg" alt="img-87.jpeg">
(a) Viable <em>Mycobacterium leprae</em> showing uniform staining</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-0d30b9ba.jpeg" alt="img-88.jpeg">
(b) Beaded staining of non-viable <em>Mycobacterium leprae</em></p>
<p><strong>Fig. 16.1</strong> <em>Mycobacterium leprae</em></p>
<p>Calculation of MI Count a total number of at least 100 bacilli. The number of viable bacilli in the 100 is expressed as percentage MI or MI%.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Mycobacteria 735</p>
<p>Solid fragmented granular (SFG Percentages)
The SFG is another method of reporting morphology of the leprosy bacilli. It calculates the percentage of the solid, fragmented and granular bacilli separately as percentages.</p>
<p>Culture The leprosy bacilli can be grown in the foot pad of the mouse and rat. The armadillo has been found to be susceptible to wide spread infection with <em>M. leprae</em> and can be used to produce large number of the bacilli for research and vaccine production.</p>
<p>Lepromin skin test This is a test that elicits two types of reactions:</p>
<ol>
<li>A maximal reaction at 48 hours, similar to a positive tuberculin test and is called Fernandez reaction.</li>
<li>The reaction appears after 3–4 weeks of injection in the form of a nodule that may proceed to ulcerate, and is called Mitsuda reaction.</li>
</ol>
<p>Fernandez reaction indicates past infection but not current disease formation, while the Mitsuda reaction indicates some degree of infection and is also associated with tuberculoid leprosy.</p>
<p>Antibiotic sensitivity <em>M. leprae</em> is sensitive to the following drugs and are used for treatment. Dapsone (4:4 diaminodiphenylsulphone or DDS), rifampicin and clofazamine. Dapsone-resistant strains are fairly common and this is usually a problem in the control of leprosy.</p>
<p>Treatment with dapsone must be closely monitored because of its adverse side effects which include haemolytic anaemia and methaemoglobinaemia.</p>
<p>Urine tests for dapsone Several urine tests have been developed to monitor the level of dapsone in the system during treatment. One of such methods is the quantitative test in which the ratio of the urinary concentrations of DDS and its diazotizable metabolites to that of creatinine is measured. This method eliminates false negative results in dilute urines or false positive results in concentrated urines. The reason for this being that there is minimal variation in the hourly rates of excretion of creatinine of any individual.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="mycobacterium-ulcerans">MYCOBACTERIUM ULCERANS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#mycobacterium-ulcerans" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><em>M. ulcerans</em> is the causative agent of Buruli ulcer. (Buruli is a district in Uganda).</p>
<p>Habitat <em>M. ulcerans</em> is believed to be an environmental organism living in the soil and on swamp shrubs.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pathogenicity">Pathogenicity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathogenicity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Infection with <em>M. ulcerans</em> may occur by direct entry into the damaged skin through cuts, scratches or wounds.</p>
<p>Buruli ulcer is a skin ulcer usually in the dermal layer. Children are more at risk.</p>
<p>The ulcer is usually located in the leg or arm and causes extensive tissue necrosis with little inflammation. The ulcer may take years to heal and leaves severe scarring.</p>
<p>The disease has been reported in Uganda and other Central and West African countries, Mexico, parts of South America and Australia.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="laboratory-diagnosis">Laboratory Diagnosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#laboratory-diagnosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Specimen Collect material from the base and sides of the ulcer. Discharges from the ulcer are not valuable as the bacilli are not easily detected.</p>
<p>Microscopy <em>M. ulcerans</em> is strongly acid-fast. Smears are stained by ZN method, and also by Gram’s stain technique to rule out secondary bacterial infection.</p>
<p>Culture <em>M. ulcerans</em> grows very slowly on LJ medium as well as on other enriched culture media used to grow <em>M. tuberculosis</em>. The colonies are smooth and pale coloured. The range of growth temperature is 30–33°C. It does not grow at 37°C. When <em>M. ulcerans</em> is suspected, inoculated media should be incubated at 32°C and 37°C. The organism is a non-chromogen and is inhibited by p-nitrobenzoic acid (PNB).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="identification-criteria">Identification criteria<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#identification-criteria" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Pigment production :Non chromogen</li>
<li>Growth at 25°C :Negative</li>
<li>Growth on 500mg/ml PNB :Negative</li>
</ol>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>736 Bacteriology</p>
<p>Antibiotic sensitivity Rifampicin is the most active drug against <em>M. ulcerans</em>. It is partially or fully resistant to most anti-tuberculous drugs.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="atypical-mycobacteria">ATYPICAL MYCOBACTERIA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#atypical-mycobacteria" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="m-kansasii"><em>M. kansasii</em><span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#m-kansasii" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>This species is associated with pulmonary infection. It is a photochromogen and an opportunistic pathogen. It belongs to Runyon Group 1. It is strongly acid fast.</p>
<p>Colonial morphology On LJ medium, colonies may be smooth, or rough like those of <em>M. tuberculosis</em>.</p>
<p>Pigmentation Yellow pigment when exposed to light.</p>
<p>Growth temperature At 25°C grows slowly in 3–4 weeks; at 37°C it grows in 1–2 weeks.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="identification-criteria">Identification criteria<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#identification-criteria" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Catalase : Positive</li>
<li>Tween 80 hydrolysis (in 10 days) : Positive</li>
<li>Growth on thiacetazone : Negative (TCZ)</li>
<li>Nitrate reduction : Positive</li>
<li>Arylsulphatase test : Negative</li>
<li>Pathogenicity in guinea pig : None.</li>
</ol>
<p>Antibiotic sensitivity The infection is treated as for <em>M. tuberculosis</em>.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="m-marinum"><em>M. marinum</em><span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#m-marinum" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>This organism is indistinguishable from <em>M. balnei</em>. It is photochromogenic and pathogenic. It is strongly acid fast. It is in Runyon Group 1.</p>
<p><em>M. marinum</em> has been isolated from swimming pool water and walls and causes skin lesions on the knee and elbow.</p>
<p>Temperature of growth is 25°C–35°C.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="identification-criteria">Identification criteria<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#identification-criteria" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Tween 80 hydrolysis : Positive</li>
<li>Growth on TCZ : Positive</li>
<li>Nitrate reduction : Negative</li>
<li>Arylsulphatase test : Positive</li>
<li>Growth at 25°C : Positive</li>
</ol>
<p><em>M. simiae</em> is another photochromogen which is tween 80 negative; TCZ positive and nitrate negative.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="m-scrofulaceum"><em>M. scrofulaceum</em><span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#m-scrofulaceum" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p><em>M. scrofulaceum</em> was isolated from cervical adenitis. It can produce pulmonary infection in man or it can remain a saprophyte. It is scotochromogenic. Growth on LJ medium may be eugonic or dysgonic. Yellow orange pigment is produced even when grown in the dark. It is in Runyon Group II.</p>
<p>Temperature of growth is 25–37°C.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="identification-criteria">Identification criteria<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#identification-criteria" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Catalase : Positive</li>
<li>Tween 80 hydrolysis : Negative</li>
<li>Nitrate reduction : Negative</li>
<li>Arylsulphatase : Positive</li>
<li>Pathogenicity in guinea pig : None</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="m-szulgai"><em>M. szulgai</em><span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#m-szulgai" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>This is another scotochromogenic species similar to <em>M. scrofulaceum</em>. It is nitrate negative. Tween 80 hydrolysis variable and arylsulphatase strongly positive.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="m-avium-intracellulare-group"><em>M. avium-intracellulare</em> Group<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#m-avium-intracellulare-group" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>This is a combined species of <em>M. avium</em> and <em>M. intracellulare</em> based on the strong relationship between the two. They belong to Runyon Group III.</p>
<p><em>M. avium</em> causes generalised tuberculosis of fowls and pigeons. It grows faster than <em>M. tuberculosis</em>. <em>M. intracellulare</em> is often associated with pulmonary infections in man. The group has the following features:</p>
<ul>
<li>Morphology No cord formation.</li>
<li>Colonies on LJ medium Smooth and easily emulsified.</li>
<li>Pigmentation Generally non-pigmented though a few strains show pale yellow non-photochromogenic colour.</li>
<li>Growth temperature Grows very slowly at 25°C (room temperature) and faster at 37°C and 44°C.</li>
</ul>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Mycobacteria 737</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="identification-criteria">Identification criteria<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#identification-criteria" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Growth at 25°C : Positive</li>
<li>Growth at 44°C : Positive</li>
<li>Tween 80 hydrolysis (at 10 days) : Negative</li>
<li>Pathogenicity to guinea pig : Minimal</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="m-xenopi">M. xenopi<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#m-xenopi" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This species is associated with pulmonary disease. It was originally isolated from South African toad, <em>Xenopus laevis</em>. The colonies are generally smooth and moist. <em>M. xenopi</em> belongs to Runyon group III but may produce pale yellow colour. Temperature of growth is 37°C–44°C. It is more sensitive to INH than any other atypical mycobacteria.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="identification-criteria">Identification criteria<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#identification-criteria" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>Catalase : Variable</li>
<li>Growth at 25°C : Negative</li>
<li>Growth at 44°C : Positive</li>
<li>Pathogenicity in Guinea pigs : None</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="m-fortuitum">M. fortuitum<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#m-fortuitum" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is a rapid growing non-pigmented species of mycobacteria. It is associated with human and animal infections. It grows at 20–37°C but not at 42°C or 44°C. This distinguishes it from other fast growing species all of which grow at 44°C. It belongs to Runyon Group IV. Other characteristic features of <em>M. fortuitum</em> are:</p>
<ul>
<li>Cording : present in most strains</li>
<li>Catalase : Positive</li>
<li>Nitrate reduction : Positive</li>
<li>Arylsulphatase test (at 18 days) : Positive</li>
<li>Pathogenicity in guinea pig : None.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="m-smegmatis">M. smegmatis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#m-smegmatis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is a rapid growing species that is present in the smegma of humans and dogs. It grows at 37°C and 44°C. It does not grow at 52°C. It is usually a saprophyte. It is similar to <em>M. fortuitum</em> except that it grows at 44°C and negative for arylsulphatase test (at 18 days). It is non-pigmented.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="m-phlei-timothy-grass-bacillus">M. phlei (Timothy Grass Bacillus)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#m-phlei-timothy-grass-bacillus" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>It is similar to <em>M. fortuitum</em> and <em>M. smegmatis</em> except that it grows at 52°C.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Chapter 17
Actinomycetes</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-f309fa7a.jpeg" alt="img-89.jpeg"></p>
<p>Actinomycetes are Gram positive, non-motile, non-capsulated and non-sporing filamentous structures that break up into bacillary and coccoid forms. Actinomycetes bear a superficial resemblance to fungi because they form a mycelium of branching filaments. The four medically important genera of the group are Actinomyces, Nocardia, Streptomyces and Actinomadura.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="genus-actinomyces">GENUS ACTINOMYCES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#genus-actinomyces" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The genus consists of organisms that grow in the form of mycelium which breaks up into rods of unequal lengths, thus giving filamentous, bacillary and coccoid forms. They are non-motile, non-acid fast, microaerophilic or anaerobic. At their periphery, the ends of the filaments may be expanded into club shapes which stain Gram negative.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="type-species-a-israeli">Type species A. israeli<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#type-species-a-israeli" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Other species of importance include A. bovis, A. naeslundi, A. odontolyticus and A. viscosus.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="habitat">Habitat<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#habitat" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Actinomyces are normally present in the mouth and the female genital tract.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="pathogenicity">Pathogenicity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathogenicity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>A. israeli It causes actinomycosis—a chronic granulomatous and suppurative disease in man. The common sites of infection are the jaws, abdomen and thorax, lungs and brain. In the infected tissues the organism grows as a mycelium which appears as granules about 0.3–1 mm in size. The granules are known as sulphur granules because they later change from white to yellow in colour.</p>
<p>&gt; <strong>Note</strong> Women wearing intrauterine devices are prone to actinomyces infections such as cervicitis and endometritis.</p>
<p>A. bovis It causes actinomycosis in cattle. A. naeslundi, A. odontolyticus and A. viscosus are associated with dental caries and gingivitis as well as endometritis.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="laboratory-diagnosis">Laboratory Diagnosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#laboratory-diagnosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="specimens">Specimens<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#specimens" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<p>Specimen include pus, sputum and infected tissue.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="microscopy">Microscopy<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#microscopy" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<p>Actinomyces species are Gram positive in reaction. Their branches appear as fine intertwining threads.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h4 level="4" id="treatment-of-sulphur-granules-1">Treatment of sulphur granules (1)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#treatment-of-sulphur-granules-1" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h4></div>
<p>Wash the granules free of pus with sterile distilled water or normal saline. If the granules are not visible, add pus to sterile saline in a universal container, cap tightly and shake. Allow the granules to settle to the bottom and collect them with a capillary pipette. Pus may also be spread over the floor of a petri dish to make the granules visible and accessible.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Actinomycetes 739</p>
<p>(2) For microscopy, crush the granules between two slides.
(3) For culture, crush the granules in a small volume of sterile water with a sterile glass rod. Inoculate on blood agar.</p>
<p>Culture Incubate the inoculated blood agar anaerobically at 37°C. After 5–7 days incubation, the colonies are small, greyish white and glistening with nodular surface and are adherent to medium.</p>
<p>Identification tests <em>A. israeli</em> produces acid in glucose, mannitol, xylose and lactose. It is catalase negative and hydrolyses aesculin. It is indole, urease and nitrate negative.</p>
<p>Table 17.1 shows the differentiation between some species of <em>Actinomyces</em>.</p>
<p>Antibiotic sensitivity Most of the <em>Actinomyces</em> species are sensitive to penicillin, tetracycline, clindamycin and erythromycin.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="genus-nocardia">GENUS NOCARDIA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#genus-nocardia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><em>Nocardia</em> species are similar morphologically to the <em>Actinomyces</em> species but the major difference is that they are aerobic and are weakly acid fast. They produce aerial hyphae. They are non-motile and non-sporing.</p>
<p>Type species <em>N. asteroides</em>.</p>
<p>Other important species of the genus include <em>N. brasiliensis</em> and <em>N. caviae</em> (<em>N. otitidiscaviarum</em>).</p>
<p>Habitat <em>Nocardia</em> organisms are found as saprophytes in soil.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pathogenicity">Pathogenicity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathogenicity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><em>N. asteroides</em> causes pulmonary infections especially in immunosuppressed individuals; it also causes brain abscess.</p>
<p><em>N. brasiliensis</em> causes mycetoma and occasionally pulmonary infection.</p>
<p><em>N. caviae</em> is also associated with pulmonary disease.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="laboratory-diagnosis">Laboratory Diagnosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#laboratory-diagnosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Specimens Specimens for the isolation of <em>Nocardia</em> bacteria include pus, sputum and infected tissue.</p>
<p>Microscopy Smears show branching filaments which may fragment to form bacillary or coccoid forms.</p>
<p>They are Gram positive but may show uneven staining reaction. The branches are weakly acid fast (with 1% H₂SO₄).</p>
<p>Culture <em>Nocardia</em> species will grow on a wide range of culture media including ordinary media. Optimum temperature of growth is between 25°C and 37°C. They are slow growing, requiring about 3–14 days for colonies to appear. The colonies are usually dry, granular and wrinkled. They produce pigment ranging from yellow to red.</p>
<p>Identification tests Table 17.2 shows the differentiation of the <em>Nocardia</em> species.</p>
<p>Antibiotic sensitivity Nocardiae are usually inhibited by sulphonamides, rifampicin, co</p>
