<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>746 Bacteriology</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="a70524b5">♦ OTHER CORYNEBACTERIA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a70524b5" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These other species are collectively referred to as diphtheroids because of their similarity to <em>C. diphtheriae</em>. Most of them are resident flora of some parts of the body (conjunctiva, skin and throat). They are capable of causing opportunistic infections.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="c-haemolyticum"><em>C. haemolyticum</em><span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#c-haemolyticum" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>This organism is similar to the animal pathogen <em>C. pyogenes</em>. It is regarded as occasional human pathogen, causing cases of pharyngitis and cervical adenitis. It has been isolated from chronic skin ulcers and brain abscess.</p>
<p>It does not grow on tellurite media. It produces a wide zone of haemolysis on human blood agar and can easily be mistaken for <em>Streptococcus</em> (there is only a small zone of haemolysis on horse blood).</p>
<p>It ferments glucose, maltose, lactose, sucrose, and starch; and liquefies gelatine slowly.</p>
<p><em>C. haemolyticum</em> is sensitive to penicillin and erythromycin.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="c-ovis-c-pseudotuberculosis"><em>C. ovis</em> (<em>C. pseudotuberculosis</em>)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#c-ovis-c-pseudotuberculosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>This species of <em>Corynebacterium</em> causes caseous lymphadenitis in sheep and in persons in close contact with infected animals.</p>
<p>It grows well on nutrient agar, Loeffler's serum agar and produces beta haemolysis on blood agar.</p>
<p>It produces a toxin that is antigenically different from diphtheria toxin.</p>
<p>It is glucose, urease and gelatine liquefaction positive.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="j-k-group-c-jeikeium">J K group (<em>C. jeikeium</em>)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#j-k-group-c-jeikeium" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>This is a group of corynebacteria with a special inclination for causing opportunistic infections in man.</p>
<p>The group was recognised not too long ago as pathogens, though the organisms are well known skin flora. They are associated with hospital acquired infections especially in leukaemia, post cardiac surgical and post bone marrow transplant patients or any other immuno compromised patients.</p>
<p>The J K organisms grow well on blood or serum enriched media at 37 °C in 24–48 hours. In Gram stained smear, they are pleomorphic Gram positive rods.</p>
<p>Biochemically, these organisms are relatively inert, only fermenting glucose and maltose slowly in serum media. They are urease positive.</p>
<p><strong>Antibiotic sensitivity</strong> They are usually sensitive to vancomycin, penicillin and erythromycin. They tend to be resistant to many antibiotics commonly used.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="c-hofmanii"><em>C. hofmanii</em><span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#c-hofmanii" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>This species is a known commensal and hardly causes any opportunistic infection. It grows well aerobically on ordinary simple media producing large creamy colonies.</p>
<p>In Gram stained smear, the bacilli appear strongly positive, short and arranged mainly in palisades. No granules are demonstrated with Albert's stain. It does not ferment glucose and other carbohydrates; it hydrolyses urea.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="c-xerosis"><em>C. xerosis</em><span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#c-xerosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>This species is a commensal mainly in the conjunctival sac but is also found in the ear.</p>
<p>It grows on ordinary media as well as on tellurite media and produces colonies similar to those of <em>intermidius</em> type <em>C. diphtheriae</em>. In stained smear, it resembles <em>C. diphtheriae</em> though it is more strongly Gram positive and has fewer granules. Unlike <em>C. diphtheriae</em>, it ferments sucrose in addition to glucose and maltose. It does not produce toxicity in animals.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="90b76f33">♦ GENUS LISTERIA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#90b76f33" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Type species</strong> <em>L. monocytogenes</em></p>
<p><em>L. monocytogenes</em> is considered the only pathogen in the genus <em>Listeria</em>.</p>
<p><strong>Characteristics</strong> The organisms are small Gram positive rods or <em>coccobacilli</em> often arranged in pairs (diplobacilli). It is non-capsulated and non-</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Aerobic Gram Positive Rods 747</p>
<p>sporing aerobic and facultatively anaerobic, grows between <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>−</mo><msup><mn>40</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∘</mo></msup><mi>C</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">2-40^{\circ}C</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">2</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">4</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">0</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6741em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∘</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">C</span></span></span></span></span> and motile at room temperature. Habitat It is found in soil, vegetables, sewage and in the faeces of humans and animals. It is naturally pathogenic to a number of animals.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pathogenicity">Pathogenicity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathogenicity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>L. monocytogenes causes listeriosis in man either as a case of occupational hazard among animal handlers or directly from human carriers. The disease is most common in neonates, pregnant women and those with immunodeficiency.</p>
<p>Intrauterine infection causes abortion, still birth or premature delivery of a neonate with pneumonic septicaemia and meningitis. Subclinical infection is the possible cause of habitual abortion in humans. In elder immuno-compromised patients and in infants, the organism causes meningoencephalitis often with septicaemia, endocarditis and brain abscesses.</p>
<p>The organism owes its name to the fact that it causes monocytosis in rabbits. Infections in other animals are similar to those of humans.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="laboratory-diagnosis">Laboratory Diagnosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#laboratory-diagnosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The principal danger in the laboratory diagnosis of listeriosis is that because it is not a common infection, when observed or isolated, it may be disregarded as a skin contaminating commensal diphtheroid. If therefore, diphtheroid-like bacilli are seen in smears of cerebrospinal fluid or blood culture from neonates, they should be further investigated to exclude Listeria.</p>
<p><strong>Specimens</strong> Blood for culture and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) for microscopy, culture and sensitivity.</p>
<p><strong>Microscopy</strong> In Gram stained smears, it is a small straight or curved rod or coccobacillus and tends to stain unevenly. In CSF microscopy, cell count may be up to <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>2000</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><mn>3</mn></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">2000/\mathrm{mm}^3</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.0641em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">2000/</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mm</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">3</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> and mainly lymphocytes. The Gram smear shows few diphtheroid-like bacilli.</p>
<p><strong>Motility test</strong> Inoculate peptone water with culture from blood agar, incubate at <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>20</mn><mo>−</mo><msup><mn>25</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∘</mo></msup><mi>C</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">20-25^{\circ}C</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">20</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">2</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">5</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6741em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∘</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">C</span></span></span></span></span> (room temperature) for six hours and examine a wet preparation or hanging drop preparation for motility. The bacilli have a characteristic tumbling motility. At <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>35</mn><mo>−</mo><msup><mn>37</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∘</mo></msup><mi>C</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">35-37^{\circ}C</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">35</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">3</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">7</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6741em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∘</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">C</span></span></span></span></span>, there is little or no motility at all.</p>
<p><strong>Culture</strong> L. monocytogenes grows well aerobically and anaerobically on media such as blood or serum agar. Growth temperature range is <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>−</mo><msup><mn>40</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∘</mo></msup><mi>C</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">2-40^{\circ}C</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">2</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">4</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">0</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6741em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∘</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">C</span></span></span></span></span> with optimum at <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>35</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∘</mo></msup><mi>C</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">35^{\circ}C</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">3</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">5</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6741em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∘</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">C</span></span></span></span></span>.</p>
<p><strong>Selective culture</strong> The above culture methods are satisfactory for processing specimens such as blood and CSF. Selective culture media are required for specimens such as faeces, vaginal swabs and tissues that may contain other bacteria.</p>
<p><strong>Cold extraction</strong> This technique is employed and is based on the ability of L. monocytogenes to multiply, though slowly, at such a low temperature that will inhibit most other bacteria. The technique is to inoculate *selective tryptose phosphate broth (5 ml) with the specimen, incubate at <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>4</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∘</mo></msup><mi>C</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">4^{\circ}C</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">4</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6741em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∘</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">C</span></span></span></span></span> and subculture from it every two weeks for up to six months.</p>
<ul>
<li>Selective tryptose phosphate broth is made selective by the incorporation of <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>200</mn><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi>μ</mi><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">200~\mu\mathrm{g/ml}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">200</span><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathnormal">μ</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">g/ml</span></span></span></span></span></span> of thallous acetate and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>40</mn><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi>μ</mi><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">40~\mu\mathrm{g/ml}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">40</span><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathnormal">μ</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">g/ml</span></span></span></span></span></span> of nalidixic acid.</li>
</ul>
<p>On blood agar after 48 hours incubation, colonies are small (droplet-like) and grey with a narrow zone of beta-heamolysis. When viewed from the side (<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>45</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∘</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">45^{\circ}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6741em;"></span><span class="mord">4</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">5</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6741em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∘</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> angle) with reflected light, the colonies are blue-green in colour.</p>
<p><strong>Identification tests</strong> L. monocytogenes produces acid, but no gas, from glucose and maltose in peptone water incubated for 48 hours at <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>37</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∘</mo></msup><mi>C</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">37^{\circ}C</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">3</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">7</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6741em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∘</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">C</span></span></span></span></span>. Lactose and sucrose are fermented after 3-10 days.</p>
<p>Other tests are:</p>
<p>Catalase -positive
Indole -negative
Oxidase -negative
Urease -negative</p>
<p>Usually, the cultural characteristics and the demonstration of the characteristic motility are sufficient criteria for diagnosis.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>748 Bacteriology</p>
<p>Typing There are 12 serovars of <em>L. monocytogens</em>. The isolates can be typed by agglutination tests with type-specific sera. Serovars 1 and 4b are the most common pathogens.</p>
<p>Antibiotic sensitivity The organism is sensitive to ampicillin, tetracycline, penicillin, cotrimoxazole, erythromycin, gentamycin and rifampicin. A combination therapy of ampicillin and gentamicin is most effective.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="genus-erysipelothrix">GENUS ERYSIPELOTHRIX<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#genus-erysipelothrix" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Type species <em>E. rhusiopathiae</em> and it is the only one of medical importance in the genus.</p>
<p>Characteristics It is a Gram positive, small curved bacillus, though easily decolourised and non-acid fast. It is non-motile.</p>
<p>It grows well on ordinary media but growth is enhanced with the addition of serum or 0.5% glucose to the media. It is microaerophilic on primary isolation but aerobic and facultatively anaerobic on subcultures. Optimum temperature of growth is 37°C and grows slowly at room temperature. It is non-haemolytic.</p>
<p>Habitat <em>E. rhusiopathiae</em> is widely distributed in pigs, sheep, cattle and other domestic animals, birds and fish.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pathogenicity">Pathogenicity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathogenicity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><em>E. rhusiopathiae</em> causes erysipelas in pigs and erysipeloid in man.</p>
<p>Infection in man is mainly an occupational hazard of butchers, fish and poultry workers. It can also cause septicaemia with endocarditis and arthritis. Introduction into the body is through damaged or abraded skin. It causes the formation of a painful swollen erythematous area which is slightly raised and extends peripherally. The usual sites of infection are the fingers, hands and arms.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="laboratory-diagnosis">Laboratory Diagnosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#laboratory-diagnosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Specimens Tissues or tissue fluid for microscopy and culture and blood for culture.</p>
<p>Microscopy Wet preparation It resembles <em>Listeria monocytogenes</em> except that it is non-motile.</p>
<p>Stained smear In Gram stained smears, <em>E. rhusiopathiae</em> is a small, slender Gram positive bacillus, sometimes unevenly stained (beaded forms).</p>
<p>Culture It grows well on blood or serum agar incubated in CO₂ at 30–37°C. After 24 hours incubation, colonies may be either very small, round, convex, smooth like dew drops about 0.5–1 mm in diameter; or larger, rough and granular. It is alpha-haemolytic when grown on horse blood agar.</p>
<p>Identification tests <em>E. rhusiopathiae</em> is catalase negative but H₂S positive. Table 18.2 shows simple differentiation between <em>E. rhusiopathiae</em>, <em>L. monocytogenes</em> and <em>C. diphtheriae</em>.</p>
<p>Antibiotic sensitivity <em>E. rhusiopathiae</em> is sensitive to penicillin (the drug of choice), erythromycin, cephalosporins and streptomycin.</p>
<table><thead><tr><th></th><th>C. diphtheriae</th><th>L. monocytogenes</th><th>E. rhusiopathiae</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Motility</td><td>-</td><td>+</td><td>-</td></tr><tr><td>Catalase</td><td>+</td><td>+</td><td>-</td></tr><tr><td>H₂S</td><td>-</td><td>-</td><td>+</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Aerobic Gram Positive Rods 749</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="genus-lactobacillus">GENUS LACTOBACILLUS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#genus-lactobacillus" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Lactobacilli are Gram positive, non-motile and non-sporing rods. Most of the species are microaerophilic and facultatively anaerobic while a few others may be strict anaerobes.</p>
<p>Habitat Lactobacilli form part of the normal vaginal flora from puberty to menopause. They form part of the defence mechanism against infection of the vagina by producing lactic acid. They are found in the mouth, intestinal tract and in breast milk.</p>
<p>Two species of the genus <em>Lactobacillus</em> are well documented.</p>
<p><em>L. acidophilus</em> This species is found mainly in the vagina, milk, faeces of adults and bottle-fed babies and saliva.</p>
<p>In direct Gram stained smears from vagina, the organisms appear as large Gram positive rods (Doderlein's bacilli) in chains or palisades.</p>
<p><em>L. bifidus</em> This is an anaerobic organism present in the faeces of breast fed babies. Smears show Gram positive rods, often in Y formation.</p>
<p>Culture Lactobacilli grow best in acid pH and so they are not easily isolated on routine media with neutral or alkaline pH. They grow best in glucose-containing medium or tomato-juice agar with acid pH.</p>
<p>Identification tests Identification is based on their being Gram positive, non-motile, catalase negative, microaerophilic and aciduric.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="genus-bacillus">GENUS BACILLUS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#genus-bacillus" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Characteristics This group of organisms consists of large aerobic spore-bearing rods. They are Gram positive bacilli which may sometimes be arranged in long chains. Most of the species are motile.</p>
<p>Type species <em>B. anthracis</em> (anthrax bacillus). It is the main pathogen of the group.</p>
<p>Other important species that may cause infections are <em>B. cereus</em> and <em>B. subtilis</em>. Several other species are mainly saprophytes.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="b-anthracis">B. anthracis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-anthracis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p><em>Bacillus anthracis</em> is primarily a pathogen of herbivores. The organisms are excreted in the faeces, urine and saliva of infected animals. They form spores which can remain viable in the environment for years and thus the environment can be a source of infection for many years.</p>
<p>Saprophytic species The other species of the genus <em>Bacillus</em>, including <em>B. cereus</em> and <em>B. subtilis</em> are saprophytes found in the soil, water, vegetation and foodstuffs such as meat, milk, cereals and spices. They form spores which are found everywhere.</p>
<p>Some of them are found contaminating clinical specimens and culture media. Some of these spores e.g. those of <em>B. subtilis</em>, are very resistant to boiling at 100°C for several hours but are killed by autoclaving at 121°C for 15 minutes.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="pathogenicity">Pathogenicity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathogenicity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="b-anthracis">B. anthracis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-anthracis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>It is the causative agent of anthrax.</p>
<ol>
<li>Cutaneous anthrax begins as a single painless blister which is usually referred to as 'malignant pustule'. Infection is generally by spores entering through damaged skin. The spores germinate in the tissue at the site of entry and spread via the lymphatics to blood stream causing septicaemia, toxaemia and death.</li>
</ol>
<p>Herdsmen, butchers and those involved in treating of animal skins are most at risk.</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>
<p>Pulmonary anthrax is caused through inhalation of the organism or spores. It causes a severe haemorrhagic condition in the bronchi and lungs which may result in septicaemia and death. The condition is referred to as 'wool sorter's disease' as those engaged in wool and hides treatment are mostly infected.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Enteric anthrax is caused by ingestion of contaminated foodstuffs such as meat and</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>750 Bacteriology</p>
<p>milk. It is a severe form of gastroenteritis which progresses to septicaemia, toxaemia and death.</p>
<ol start="4">
<li>Meningitis is a complication of anthrax septicaemia.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="b-cereus">B. cereus<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-cereus" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>It causes:</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Food poisoning which may result from eating of either contaminated cooked rice or other cereals, or meat. The symptoms are onset of vomiting and diarrhoea within a few hours or up to 24 hours depending on the kind of contaminated food eaten.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Pneumonia, broncho pneumonia and wound infections. These conditions are not common.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="b-subtilis">B. subtilis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-subtilis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This species has been reported to cause meningitis, endocarditis and other infections in debilitated and immunosuppressed patients.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="laboratory-diagnosis">Laboratory Diagnosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#laboratory-diagnosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="b-anthracis">B. anthracis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-anthracis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p><strong>Specimens</strong> Specimens include pus or fluid from the pustule, sputum, blood, spinal fluid and swabs from cutaneous lesions.</p>
<p><strong>Caution</strong> All procedures should be carried out in the safety cabinet. The specimens must carry the biohazard labels.</p>
<p><strong>Microscopy</strong> Gram stained smears from the specimens show large Gram positive rods of about <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>5</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>8</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>1.5</mn><mi>μ</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">5-8 \times 1.5 \mu \mathrm{m}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">5</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">8</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8389em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">1.5</span><span class="mord mathnormal">μ</span><span class="mord mathrm">m</span></span></span></span></span> with square or round ends and are without spores (Fig. 18.3). Blood film stained with polychrome methylene blue shows capsulated large bacilli mostly in chains. The capsule material stains purple. This is McFadyean's reaction.</p>
<p>&gt; <strong>Note</strong>
&gt; B. anthracis capsule is a polypeptide unlike most other capsules which are polysaccharides.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-560d3e0d.jpeg" alt="img-92.jpeg">
Fig. 18.3 B. anthracis isolated from blood: Gram stained smear</p>
<p>Smears from cultures show large bacilli containing spores which are of the same diameter as the bacilli. The spores are centrally placed.</p>
<p><strong>Motility test</strong> B. anthracis is non-motile while the other species are generally motile.</p>
<p>&gt; <strong>Note</strong>
&gt; Smears should be chemically fixed before staining. This is to ensure complete killing of the bacilli. A good fixative is 4% potassium permanganate for 10-15 minutes.</p>
<p><strong>Culture</strong> The Bacillus species grow well on most culture media. B. anthracis and majority of the species grow aerobically at optimum temperature of <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>35</mn><mo>−</mo><msup><mn>37</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∘</mo></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">35-37^{\circ} \mathrm{C}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">35</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">3</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">7</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6741em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∘</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm">C</span></span></span></span></span> within a range of <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>12</mn><mo>−</mo><msup><mn>45</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∘</mo></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">12-45^{\circ} \mathrm{C}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">12</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">4</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">5</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6741em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∘</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm">C</span></span></span></span></span>.</p>
<p>On blood agar after 24 hours incubation, B. anthracis produces large (2–3 mm in diameter), grey, opaque irregular colonies with wavy edges (Medusa head). Colonies are non-haemolytic or slightly haemolytic. When grown in the presence of a high concentration of <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{CO}_{2}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">CO</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>, it produces smooth mucoid colonies.</p>
<p>Broth cultures of B. anthracis contain thick pellicles on the surface of the medium, with no turbidity. Other species produce turbidity in broth culture.</p>
<p><strong>Animal Infection and Inoculation with B. anthracis</strong> Herbivores and other animals are generally infected by ingesting contaminated grass</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Aerobic Gram Positive Rods 751</p>
<p>and other type of vegetation. The spores, on ingestion, germinate in the tissue and get into the blood stream. A full post mortem on a dead animal is not encouraged. The carcass is disposed off by burning according to the guidelines of the Public Health Authority.</p>
<p>Identification of <em>B. anthracis</em> can be confirmed by inoculating the thigh of a guinea pig with fluid from a suspected malignant pustule or 0.5 ml broth culture of the organism. The animal dies within 48–72 hours after inoculation. Post-mortem shows gelatinous exudate at the site of inoculation; and enlarged, congested dark red spleen. Smears of blood and spleen material show characteristic appearance and positive Mcfadyean's reaction.</p>
<p><strong>Note</strong></p>
<ol>
<li>Spores are not seen in smears made directly from animal tissue or blood, they are seen in smears from cultures.</li>
<li>Capsules (polypeptides) which are lost on culture, are only visible in smears made from blood or fluid and stained by polychrome methylene blue. The capsule stains red to purple (McFadyean’s reaction).</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="b-cereus">B. cereus<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-cereus" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A selective medium is used to isolate it from faeces. Mannitol egg yolk phenol-red polymyxin agar is recommended. Colonies after 24 hours incubation are large (3–5 mm), flat, dry and grey colonies surrounded by white precipitates. <em>B. cereus</em> is beta haemolytic on blood agar.</p>
<p><strong>Identification tests</strong> <em>B. anthracis</em> ferments glucose, maltose, sucrose and trehalose with acid and no gas production. It is catalase positive, nitrate positive and unlike other species, liquefies gelatine slowly in an ‘inverted fir tree’ pattern. Other distinguishing features of the anthrax bacillus from other species are as follows:</p>
<table><thead><tr><th><em>B. anthracis</em></th><th>Other species</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Non-motile</td><td>Generally motile</td></tr><tr><td>Capsulated</td><td>Non Capsulated</td></tr><tr><td>No turbidity in broth</td><td>Often turbidity in broth</td></tr><tr><td>Slow liquefaction of gelatine</td><td>Rapid liquefaction of gelatine</td></tr><tr><td>Inverted fir tree form</td><td>No inverted fir tree form</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Some stains of <em>Bacillus</em> produce little lecithinase.</p>
<p><strong>Antibiotic sensitivity</strong> The organisms are sensitive to penicillin, tetracycline, chloramphenicol and cotrimoxazole.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="some-useful-saprophytic-species">Some Useful Saprophytic Species<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#some-useful-saprophytic-species" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li><em>B. licheniformis</em>—used for the production of penincillinase.</li>
<li><em>B. polymyxa</em>—used for the production of antibiotic, polymyxin B.</li>
<li><em>B. stearothermophilus</em>—used for testing the efficiency of autoclaves.</li>
</ol>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Chapter 19</p>
<p>Anaerobic Gram Negative Rods</p>
<p>In this group of organisms, three genera will be considered:</p>
<ul>
<li>Bacteroides</li>
<li>Fusobacterium</li>
<li>Leptotrichia</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="genus-bacteroides">GENUS BACTEROIDES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#genus-bacteroides" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This genus consists of numerous species which have now been classified into two groups:</p>
<ul>
<li>Bacteroides fragilis group (6 species)</li>
<li>Bacteroides melaninogenicus group (4 species)</li>
<li>Characteristics: The organisms in the genus are small Gram negative, non-sporing and generally non-motile rods. They are obligate anaerobes.</li>
<li>Habitat: Most of the Bacteroides species live as normal flora in the mouth, intestinal tract, urethra, and female genital tract.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pathogenicity">Pathogenicity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathogenicity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Infection with Bacteroides are usually endogenous from their resident sites in the body, and very often they are mixed with other organisms, both obligate and facultative anaerobes.</p>
<p>Bacteroides species are associated with the following infections:</p>
<ol>
<li>Genitourinary infections including puerperal sepsis.</li>
<li>Post-operative abdominal wound infections and peritonitis.</li>
<li>Abscesses of the brain, lung, and maxillo-facial region</li>
<li>Ulcerative gingivitis is caused by B. melaninogenicus.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="laboratory-diagnosis">Laboratory Diagnosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#laboratory-diagnosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="specimens">Specimens<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#specimens" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Pus or swabs from sites of infection.</p>
<p>&gt; <strong>Note</strong>
&gt; Specimens for anaerobic cultivation should be sent to the laboratory without delay in a transport medium e.g. Stuart's transport medium.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="microscopy">Microscopy<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#microscopy" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Stained smear shows small or pleomorphic Gram negative bacilli.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="culture">Culture<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#culture" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Bacteroides species grow well in cooked meat broth. Growth on solid media is enhanced in an anaerobic environment enriched with <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{CO}_{2}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">CO</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>.</p>
<p>Gentamicin, neomycin or kanamycin blood agar are good selective media. Schaedler's blood agar is also highly recommended.</p>
<p>On blood agar, B. fragilis produces 1–3 mm. entire, smooth, shiny pale grey colonies after 48 hours incubation at <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>37</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∘</mo></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">37^{\circ}\mathrm{C}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">3</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">7</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6741em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∘</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm">C</span></span></span></span></span>.</p>
<p>B. melaninogenicus produces brown to black haemolytic colonies in about 3–7 days. The colo</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Anaerobic Gram Negative Rods 753</p>
<p>nies are smooth, circular and opaque. Colonies of B. melaninogenicus on blood agar will fluoresce pink-red under UV light.</p>
<p><strong>Note</strong>
For quick presumptive detection of anaerobes such as Bacteroides species, a disc of metronidazole (5 μg) is placed on the primary culture plate. Most anaerobes are sensitive to metronidazole.</p>
<p><strong>Identification tests</strong>
The routine biochemical tests are not very useful in the identification of the various species. Identification is therefore based on cultural, microscopical and antimicrobial sensitivity of the species. They are usually reported simply as Bacteroides species. An extensive identification can be performed using the API anaerobic system or Minitek II system. Also, gas liquid chromatography (GLC) is a useful tool for the identification of anaerobes.</p>
<p>Table 19.1 shows the differentiation of Bacteroides species from other Gram negative anaerobic rods based on their sensitivity to various antibiotics.</p>
<p><strong>Note</strong>
B. melaninogenicus is renamed Prevotella melaninogenicus.</p>
<p>Antibiotic sensitivity B. fragilis is uniformly resistant to penicillin, vancomycin and aminoglycosides. B. melaninogenicus is resistant to kanamycin. All Bacteroides species are sensitive to metronidazole, and generally to tetracycline and chloramphenicol.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="genus-fusobacterium-fusiform">GENUS FUSOBACTERIUM (FUSIFORM)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#genus-fusobacterium-fusiform" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="type-species-f-nucleatum">Type species F. nucleatum<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#type-species-f-nucleatum" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Another important species is <em>F. necrophorum</em>.</p>
<p>The fusobacteria are large Gram negative rods that are wide at the centre and with tapering pointed ends (fusiform), some are pleomorphic. They are obligate anaerobes, non-motile and non-sporing.</p>
<p><strong>Habitat</strong>
The bacilli are normal flora of the mouth, gastrointestinal tract and female genital tract.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="pathogenicity">Pathogenicity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathogenicity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>These organisms tend to occur in mixed infections such as abdominal wound, genital infections and lung abscess. <em>F. nucleatum</em> is usually found in the same type of infections as Bacteroides.</p>
<p><em>F. necrophorum</em> is frequently associated with Borrelia vincenti spirochaetes in ulcerative lesions of the mouth and throat (Vincent's angina).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="laboratory-diagnosis">Laboratory Diagnosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#laboratory-diagnosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p><strong>Specimens</strong>
Pus, wound exudates, tissue or blood transported to the laboratory in a closed system.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="table-19-1-differentiation-between-bacteriodes-species-and-other-gram-negative-anaerobes">Table 19.1 Differentiation between Bacteriodes species and other Gram negative anaerobes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#table-19-1-differentiation-between-bacteriodes-species-and-other-gram-negative-anaerobes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>

<p>754 Bacteriology</p>
<p>ringe. Swabs should be sent in transport media. Specimens containing fusobacteria are foul-smelling.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="microscopy">Microscopy<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#microscopy" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Stained smear</strong> <em>F. nucleatum</em> appears as slender spindle-shaped Gram negative rods about 5–10 × 1 μm with tapering ends.</p>
<p><em>F. necrophorum</em> is pleomorphic and irregularly stained. The bacilli are 1–10 × 0.5 μm; long filamentous forms are frequently seen.</p>
<p><strong>Culture</strong> Specimens must be processed without delay. Use freshly poured plates or pre-reduced plates for culture.</p>
<p>Incubate seeded plate promptly in an anaerobic environment at 37°C for 48 hours.</p>
<p>Selective culture media-Schaedler's blood agar is satisfactory; Robertson's cooked meat medium is also inoculated.</p>
<p><em>F. nucleatum</em> on blood agar after 48 hours incubation, produces irregular, grey, non-haemolytic colonies about 1–2 mm in diameter.</p>
<p><em>F. necrophorum</em> produces circular, grey, often beta-haemolytic colonies about 1–2 mm in diameter.</p>
<p><strong>Identification tests</strong> Identification of the group to species level is not a routine procedure. Identification is often based on the appearance of a direct Gram film from pus, their ability to ferment glucose and ability to grow in the presence of gentian violet dye. Extensive identification can be done using the API anaerobic system or the Minitek II system. They are distinguished from <em>Bacteroides</em> on the basis of their antimicrobial activity. Table 19.1 shows differentiating characteristics of <em>Fusobacterium</em> species from other Gram negative anaerobes.</p>
<p><strong>Antibiotic sensitivity</strong> Unlike <em>Bacteroides</em>, the fusobacteria are sensitive to Kanamycin and usually resistant to vancomycin, erythromycin and rifampicin. They are usually sensitive to penicillin and always sensitive to metronidazole.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="genus-leptotrichia">GENUS LEPTOTRICHIA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#genus-leptotrichia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Type species</strong> <em>L. buccalis</em>.</p>
<p>These organisms are found in close association with fusobacteria. They are characteristically seen in Gram stained smears from clinical specimens as long Gram negative rods with tapering ends, measuring up to 15 × 1.5 μm.</p>
<p><em>L. buccalis</em> mixed with <em>F. necrophorum</em>, <em>Bacteroides melaninogenicus</em> and <em>Borrelia vincenti</em> is associated with Vincent's angina and mouth ulcers.</p>
<p>On blood agar after 48 hours anaerobic incubation at 37°C, <em>Leptotrichia</em> species produce irregular and striated colonies about 2–3 mm in diameter.</p>
<p>The organism is sensitive to metronidazole, and is gentian violet tolerant.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Chapter 20</p>
<p>Anaerobic Gram Positive Rods</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="genus-clostridium">GENUS CLOSTRIDIUM<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#genus-clostridium" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The genus consists of Gram positive, anaerobic spore forming rods. A few strains are aerotolerant. The shape and the position of the spores within the bacterial cell aid in the identification of the species. There are several species and only those of medical importance will be considered.</p>
<p><strong>Characteristics</strong> Clostridia are motile (except <em>C. perfringens</em> and <em>C. tetani</em> type 6). They are Gram positive pleomorphic rods (older cultures may stain Gram negative), about <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>3</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>8</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>0.10</mn><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi>μ</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">3-8 \times 0.10 \ \mu\mathrm{m}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">3</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">8</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8389em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">0.10</span><span class="mspace">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathnormal">μ</span><span class="mord mathrm">m</span></span></span></span></span> with rounded ends. Some species are haemolytic and some may show swarming. They produce powerful exotoxins. Some species are proteolytic while others are saccharolytic.</p>
<p><strong>Habitat</strong> Clostridia are normally present in soil, dust, water and in the intestinal tract of humans and animals.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="classification-of-clostridia">Classification of Clostridia<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#classification-of-clostridia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Several methods have been used to classify Clostridium species. These methods include morphological features such as shape and position of the spores, biochemical actions such as proteolytic and saccharolytic activity; and the disease they produce (See the chart below).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="a-the-gas-gangrene-group">A. The gas gangrene group<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#a-the-gas-gangrene-group" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li><strong>Established pathogens</strong>: <em>C. perfringens</em> (the predominant pathogen), <em>C. septicum</em>, <em>C. oedematiens</em> (C.novyi).</li>
<li><strong>Less pathogenic</strong>: <em>C. histolyticum</em>, <em>C. fallax</em>, <em>C. bifermentans</em>, <em>C. sporogenes</em></li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li><strong>B. Tetanus</strong>: <em>C. tetani</em></li>
<li><strong>C. Food poisoning group</strong></li>
</ul>
<ol>
<li><strong>Gastro-enteritis</strong>: <em>C. perfringens</em> (Type A)</li>
<li><strong>Botulism</strong>: <em>C. botulinum</em></li>
</ol>
<ul>
<li><strong>D. Pseudomembranous colitis</strong>: <em>C. difficile</em></li>
</ul>
<p>Table 20.1 shows some differential features of clostridia.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pathogenicity">Pathogenicity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathogenicity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="1-c-perfringens-c-welchii">1. <em>C. perfringens</em> (C. welchii)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-c-perfringens-c-welchii" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p><em>C. perfringens</em> is divided into five main types: A, B, C, D, and E. <em>C. perfringens</em> produces alpha toxin and a host of other toxins including collagenase, proteinase, hyaluronidase and DNase. The alpha toxin is the major toxin produced by <em>C. perfringens</em>. It is also referred to as lecithinase C.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>756 Bacteriology</p>
<p>Table 20.1 Differential features of Clostridia</p>

<p>ST = subterminal; C = Central; T = Terminal
*Type 6 is non-motile</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Anaerobic Gram-Positive Rods 757</p>
<p>Type A causes gas gangrene, food poisoning, puerperal infection and septicaemia. It produces abundant alpha toxin which causes toxaemia.</p>
<p>Food poisoning strain is non-haemolytic and its spores resist boiling at 100°C for several hours. The illness is caused by a cold or warmed up meat-dish. Symptoms, which are abdominal pain, diarrhoea and vomiting, set in 8–12 hours after ingestion of contaminated food.</p>
<p>In gas gangrene, there is rapid fermentation of tissue carbohydrate with the production of gas in the decaying tissue. The presence of toxin and hyaluronidase aid in the spread of infection.</p>
<p>Type C causes acute jejunitis (pigbel), a disease that occurs in the Far East, Pacific islands, some parts of East Africa, and Bangladesh. The infection is contracted by eating infected pigmeat. The strain produces lethal beta toxin that causes severe intestinal impairment accompanied by abdominal pain, dysentery and vomiting.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="2-c-tetani">2. C. tetani<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-c-tetani" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>There are at least 10 types of <em>C. tetani</em> demonstrated by specific flagellar (H) antigens, but all types share a common somatic (O) antigen and produce the same neuro (exo) toxin that causes tetanus (lock jaw).</p>
<p>Tetanus develops from infection of a wound or occasionally from parenteral injection of contaminated substances. It is characterised by tonic muscular spasms which usually begins from the site of infection and later becomes generalised. Puncture wounds such as soiled nail prick, are most vulnerable as they favour the growth of anaerobic organisms.</p>
<p>Tetanus may be a complication of septic abortion. It may also result from using unsterile instruments as during ear piercing, circumcision or following post-operative wound as a result of using inadequately sterilised dressings.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="3-c-botulinum">3. C. botulinum<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-c-botulinum" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>There are five types of <em>C. botulinum</em>: A B C D and E.</p>
<p>Types A, B and E cause severe and usually fatal form of food poisoning, botulism, by ingestion of pre-formed toxin in preserved food. The organism usually grows in home canned food (meat, vegetables or fish products) under anaerobic condition, and produces toxin, which is then consumed along with the food.</p>
<p>Within 12–26 hours of ingestion, the following common signs and symptoms appear—vomiting, thirst, constipation, blurred vision, difficulty in swallowing, speaking and breathing. Death occurs in 1–5 days after the onset due to respiratory failure. Fatality rate is high. The symptoms of botulism are neurological rather than gastrointestinal.</p>
<p>Type C causes limber-neck in fowls, D causes botulism in cattle.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="4-c-difficile">4. C. difficile<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#4-c-difficile" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This species causes pseudomembranous colitis following the use of broad spectrum antibiotics. The antibiotic eliminates many bacterial flora thus allowing the overgrowth of <em>C. difficile</em> which is an occasional human bowel commensal.</p>
