<p><strong>Note</strong>
False positive reactions may occur in Proteus infections, relapsing fever, brucellosis and other acute febrile illness. False negative results are common in scrub typhus.</p>
<p>Antibiotic sensitivity Rickettsiae are usually sensitive to erythromycin, tetracycline, chloramphenicol. They are usually resistant to penicillin.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="genus-coxiella">GENUS COXIELLA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#genus-coxiella" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This genus belongs to the tribe Rickettsiaceae and is very closely related to the rickettsia organisms. It differs from the rickettsiae in being smaller (about 0.2–0.4 μm × 0.4–1.0 μm in size) and being more resistant to physical and chemical changes. It can remain infectious for months in tap water, milk, soil or dried blood. It survives for one hour at 60°C and it is Weil-Felix test negative.</p>
<p>The species of note is Coxiella burnetii.</p>
<p>Habitat The important reservoirs of the organism are cows, goats, sheep, rodents and several species of birds. Transmission of C. burnetii from animal to animal is by ticks, but it can also spread directly from infected faeces and infected dust particles. Human infection occurs through inhalation of infected aerosols, or by bite of infected tick, or by consuming untreated milk or as occupational hazards for workers in slaughter houses.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pathogenicity">Pathogenicity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathogenicity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>C. burnetii causes Q (Query) fever which was identified by Burnet and so it was named after him. Q fever is also referred to as Red River fever in Zaire. Q fever is an influenza-like infection with no rash or local lesions. It spreads through many organs but most frequently through the spleen, liver and the heart. It causes pneumonitis, hepatitis and other liver diseases, and infective endocarditis. Spontaneous recovery may occur.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="laboratory-diagnosis">Laboratory Diagnosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#laboratory-diagnosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Specimens meant for Q fever diagnosis should be handled with the same care and caution as for those of rickettsiae. Specimens may include tissues, blood and sputum.</p>
<p>Microscopy C. burnetii is Gram negative, small and pleomorphic. Employ the same staining methods of Giemsa, Castenada or Machiavello.</p>
<p>Culture C. burnetii is cultured in yolk sac of a chick embryo. This is usually carried out in spe</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Chlamydia, Mycoplasma, Rickettsia and Miscellaneous Bacteria 785</p>
<p>cialised laboratories. C. burnetii exhibits phase variations—fresh isolates are in phase I and change into phase II after repeated passages in yolk sac.</p>
<p><strong>Serology</strong> Complement fixation test (CFT) is the serological method commonly employed for the diagnosis of Q fever. Test using phase I antigens detects acute infection while chronic infections are diagnosed using phases I and II antigens.</p>
<p>Weil-Felix reaction is negative for C. burnetii.</p>
<p><strong>Antibiotic sensitivity</strong> C. burnetii is most sensitive to tetracycline.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="genus-rochalimaea">GENUS ROCHALIMAEA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#genus-rochalimaea" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The species of note is <em>Rochalimaea quintana</em> (formerly <em>Rickettsia quintana</em>). <em>R. quintana</em> is the causative agent of Trench fever which is also known as five-day fever. It affected soldiers in trenches during World War II. This organism differs from rickettsiae in that:</p>
<p>(i) it does not occur intracellularly in the arthropod host
(ii) it grows on bacteriological media such as blood agar after about two weeks aerobic incubation at 37°C under increased CO₂ tension.
(iii) it grows poorly in the yolk-sac of chick embryo
(iv) it is Weil-Felix reaction negative.</p>
<p>Trench fever is louse-borne but affects only man and monkeys.</p>
<p>Laboratory Diagnosis of the fever can be made by culture and serological methods.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="genus-ehrlichia">GENUS EHRLICHIA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#genus-ehrlichia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is a recently named genus in the tribe Rickettsiaceae. It was formerly known as Rickettsia sennetsu. It causes an infectious mononucleosis-like infection in Japan. It is notably resistant to antibiotics.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="genus-bartonella">GENUS BARTONELLA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#genus-bartonella" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The only species of medical importance of the genus is <em>B. bacilliformis</em>.</p>
<p><em>B. bacilliformis</em> is a pleomorphic, Gram negative, weakly motile rod-shaped bacterium. It can occur as oval or coccal forms or in X and Y forms. It is a strict aerobe and grows well on blood agar after 4–6 days incubation at 25–28°C. It is slightly haemolytic.</p>
<p><strong>Habitat</strong> <em>B. bacilliformis</em> is widely distributed in South America. The incidence of bartonellosis tends to be seasonal as transmission is more prevalent in the rainy season. The main reservoir of <em>B. bacilliformis</em> is infected persons. Usually transmission to man is by the sandfly, Lutzomiya, at night.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pathogenicity">Pathogenicity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathogenicity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><em>B. bacilliformis</em> causes bartonellosis which is also known as Carrion’s disease or Oroya fever. The illness is characterised by acute haemolytic anaemia with severe headache and general body pains. Spleen, liver and lymph nodes may become enlarged. <em>Salmonella septicaemia</em> is common in bartonellosis as a secondary infection.</p>
<p>The organism invades the red blood cells of the infected persons, causing the destruction of the red cells. This results in severe haemolytic anaemia with increased serum bilirubin. The uninfected red cells become macrocytic and highly reduced in number. Platelets may be reduced; and there is usually a leucocytosis with neutrophilia.</p>
<p>Death occurs due to intravascular haemolysis or <em>Salmonella septicaemia</em>.</p>
<p>Verruga beruana is the stage of bartonellosis when wart-like nodules appear on the skin. This occurs about 30–40 days after infection.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="laboratory-diagnosis">Laboratory Diagnosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#laboratory-diagnosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Specimens</strong> Blood is taken for microscopy and culture.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>786 Bacteriology</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="microscopy">Microscopy<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#microscopy" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Stained smear</strong> Gram stain shows small pleomorphic Gram negative organisms, about <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>0.5</mn><mi>μ</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">2 \times 0.5 \mu \mathrm{m}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">2</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8389em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">0.5</span><span class="mord mathnormal">μ</span><span class="mord mathrm">m</span></span></span></span></span> on the average.</p>
<p>With Giemsa stain, the organism stains red-purple.</p>
<p>In semi-solid medium, the organism shows weak motility.</p>
<p><strong>Culture</strong> <em>B. bacilliformis</em> grows on fresh blood agar. Colonies appear after about 4–6 days aerobic incubation at <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>25</mn><mtext>–</mtext><msup><mn>28</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∘</mo></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">25–28^{\circ} \mathrm{C}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">25–2</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">8</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6741em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∘</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm">C</span></span></span></span></span>. There may be a small zone of haemolysis around the colonies.</p>
<p><strong>Antibiotic sensitivity</strong> Chloramphenicol is the drug of choice for treatment because it is active against both <em>B. bacilliformis</em> and <em>Salmonella</em> species.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="genus-legionella">GENUS LEGIONELLA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#genus-legionella" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><em>Legionella</em> organisms are Gram negative, aerobic, non-sporing, non-acid fast and encapsulated bacteria. They measure about <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>0.3</mn><mtext>–</mtext><mn>0.7</mn><mi>μ</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">0.3–0.7 \mu \mathrm{m}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8389em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">0.3–0.7</span><span class="mord mathnormal">μ</span><span class="mord mathrm">m</span></span></span></span></span>. They are catalase and oxidase variable. Primary isolation may take up to 10 days incubation at <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>35</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∘</mo></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">35^{\circ} \mathrm{C}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">3</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">5</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6741em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∘</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm">C</span></span></span></span></span>. Growth is enhanced in an atmosphere containing <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>5</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">5\%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">5%</span></span></span></span></span> carbon dioxide <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(\mathrm{CO}_{2})</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">CO</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span>. Most of the members of the group are motile and produce beta-lactamase.</p>
<p><strong>Type species</strong> <em>L. pneumophila</em>. Other important species of the genus include <em>L. micdadei</em>, <em>L. bozemanii</em>, <em>L. longbeachae</em>, <em>L. dumoffii</em> and <em>L. gormanii</em>.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pathogenicity">Pathogenicity<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathogenicity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><em>L. pneumophila</em> causes <em>Legionnaire’s</em> disease or <em>Legionellosis</em>. The disease is an atypical pneumonia with a high fatality rate. The organism was first known as <em>Legionnaire’s</em> disease bacterium (LDB). The organism derived its name from the epidemic at the American Legion convention in Philadelphia in 1976. The outbreak resulted in the death of 29 from 183 cases. The causative agent was identified as <em>L. legionella</em>, later known as <em>L. pneumophila</em>.</p>
<p><em>L. pneumophila</em> is an environmental organism. Human infection usually occurs from transmission, through aerosol, of organisms that have colonised water supplies and air-conditioning systems. Person to person transmission is very uncommon. <em>Legionellosis</em> usually presents as non-productive cough, chest pain and high fever. Other associated symptoms are mental confusion, diarrhoea, nausea and vomiting.</p>
<p>Other species cause milder form of the disease especially in institutional communities.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="laboratory-diagnosis">Laboratory Diagnosis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#laboratory-diagnosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Specimens</strong> Specimens for the isolation of <em>Legionella</em> organisms include sputum, broncho-alveolar lavage, respiratory tissue and rarely pleural effusion and blood for culture.</p>
<p>It may be necessary to culture samples from hospital water supplies and samples from cooling systems of airconditioners.</p>
<p>Specimens should reach the laboratory with minimal delay. If delay is unavoidable keep the specimen in the refrigerator.</p>
<p><strong>Microscopy</strong> Gram stained smear of sputum reveals faintly stained Gram negative bacilli. Direct fluorescent antibody methods are also valuable though they may not be totally specific as occasional cross-reactions occur with non-legionella bacteria.</p>
<p><strong>Culture</strong> <em>Legionella</em> organisms are fastidious and slow growing. They require growth supplements and cysteine for growth.</p>
<p>Primary isolation medium is the buffered charcoal yeast extract (CYE) agar. The medium is made selective by the incorporation of certain antibiotics: vancomycin, polymixin B and anisomycin.</p>
<p>The medium is inoculated with 1:10 dilution of sputum or lavage, and incubated at <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>35</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∘</mo></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">35^{\circ} \mathrm{C}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">3</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">5</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6741em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∘</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm">C</span></span></span></span></span>. Colonies of about <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>1</mn><mtext>–</mtext><mn>2</mn><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1–2 \mathrm{~mm}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">1–2</span><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm">mm</span></span></span></span></span></span> may appear after three days incubation. The colonies are round, greyish-pink and opalescent with entire edges.</p>
<p>&gt; <strong>Note</strong>
&gt; Neat sputum and broncho-alveolar lavage contain substances that inhibit the growth of the legionellae. It is necessary to dilute the specimen to 1:10 for inoculation.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Chlamydia, Mycoplasma, Rickettsia and Miscellaneous Bacteria 787</p>
<p>Identification tests Presumptive identification of <em>Legionella</em> is made when the suspected isolate is found to be cysteine dependent and faintly Gram negative bacillus. When subcultured on a cysteine deficient medium, the organisms fail to grow. The differential biochemical reactions of some <em>Legionella</em> species are shown in Table 22.6.</p>
<p>Serology The method of choice for the confirmation of <em>Legionella</em> infection is the immunofluorescence technique. The indirect method is usually employed to detect <em>L. pneumophila</em> antibodies. A single serum titre of 128 or more is highly suggestive of legionella infection. A four-fold rise in titre between paired sera separated by 3–6 weeks is diagnostic of the infection.</p>
<p>A rapid microagglutination test is commercially available. It consists of stained <em>L. pneumophila</em> serotype 1 antigen. The patients serum is diluted serially and antigen added in a ‘V’ bottom microtitre plate. The mixture is shaken, incubated for 10 minutes at room temperature and then centrifuged in a microtitre plate at 350g. A tight button of the antigen-antibody complex is indicative of a positive reaction.</p>
<p>A negative result is indicated by a tear drop pattern on the sides of the well. A titre of 1:8 or higher is suggestive. Confirmation by immunofluorescence technique should be performed. A commercial radio-immunoassay for the detection of soluble <em>L. pneumophila</em> antigen is available. The technique is specific and highly sensitive.</p>
<p>Antibiotic sensitivity <em>Legionella</em> organisms are sensitive to erythromycin, rifampicin, cotrimoxazole and 4-fluoroquinolones. Most strains are resistant to penicillin due to their beta lactamase production. The aminoglycosides are effective for therapy.</p>
<p>Table 22.6 Differentiation of <em>Legionella</em> species</p>

<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Chapter 23</p>
<p>Antimicrobial Susceptibility Tests</p>
<p>A chemotherapeutic drug is a general term for a chemical compound which is used in the treatment of disease. This chemical compound may be synthesised in the laboratory or may come from natural sources. It may be used for the treatment of any type of disease including an infectious disease, a metabolic disorder or a neoplastic process. An antibiotic is an antimicrobial agent that is derived from a microorganism. The term antimicrobial agent is used for a drug that acts primarily against infectious microorganisms. It may be derived from a natural source or may be a synthesised chemical.</p>
<p>After the accidental discovery of the first antibiotic penicillin by Alexander Fleming (1928), more and more antibiotics became commercially available. Although these new antibiotics were looked at as 'wonder drugs' initially, the resistant bacterial strains soon started emerging and susceptibility tests for these drugs became necessary.</p>
<p>A major role of the clinical microbiology laboratory is to provide important information to the clinician such as:</p>
<p>(i) The presence or absence of an infectious agent in a clinical specimen
(ii) Identification of such a causative agent and
(iii) Susceptibility of isolated causative agent to selected drugs.</p>
<p>Besides providing an information regarding the appropriate drug therapy, microbiologists can also assist the clinician by providing data to help him decide whether the administered doses of the antimicrobial agent are adequate.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="antimicrobial-therapy">Antimicrobial Therapy<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#antimicrobial-therapy" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Antimicrobial therapy aims at treating infections with a drug to which the causal microorganism is sensitive and which has a selective toxicity only for the infecting organism without harming the host cells. Some antimicrobials are bacteriostatic, i.e., they arrest multiplication of bacteria, e.g., chloramphenicol, erythromycin and sulphonamides. If the drug is withheld, the organism may start reproducing again. Some other antimicrobials are bactericidal i.e. they bring about the death of the organism, e.g., streptomycin, penicillin. Drugs such as erythromycin or tetracycline are bacteriostatic at usual therapeutic blood levels but are bactericidal at higher concentrations. However, the demarcation between bacteriostatic and bactericidal actions is not very clear cut, and depends on the type of organism, the number of organisms present and the concentration of the drug in the blood.</p>
<p>Antimicrobial drugs differ in the range of bacteria they inhibit. Broad spectrum drugs such as ampicillin and tetracycline are effective against both Gram positive and Gram negative bacteria, whereas flucloxacillin has a narrow spectrum and is active against Gram positive bacteria such as Staphylococcus aureus, but ineffective against</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Antimicrobial Susceptibility Tests 789</p>
<p>most Gram negative bacteria. It is preferable to use a narrow spectrum drug for a known pathogen because it does not affect the composition of the normal flora at various sites. A broad spectrum drug may have an adverse effect on the normal flora.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="combination-of-drugs">Combination of drugs<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#combination-of-drugs" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Although a single antimicrobial drug should be used for the treatment of a particular infection, a combination of drugs is indicated in some situations:</p>
<p>(i) To achieve a synergistic effect, e.g., the use of sulphonamide and trimethoprim in the drug cotrimoxazole.
(ii) To prevent development of bacterial resistance, e.g., in the treatment of tuberculosis.
(iii) To treat mixed infections.</p>
<p>Some combinations may be antagonistic. For example, if penicillin, which acts on actively growing bacteria, is combined with a bacteriostatic agent, its action will be prevented.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="mode-of-action-of-antimicrobial-agents">Mode of action of antimicrobial agents<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#mode-of-action-of-antimicrobial-agents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>There are five main ways in which antimicrobial drugs act on bacteria.</p>
<p>(i) Inhibition of cell wall synthesis Some drugs inhibit the cell wall synthesis of bacteria by preventing the cross-linking of the polysaccharide chains in the peptidoglycan layer of the cell wall, e.g., penicillins, cephalosporins and vancomycin.
(ii) Damage to the cell membrane Some antimicrobial agents act as cationic detergents and bind to the cell membrane. This binding results in the loss of semipermeability of the membrane, leading to the loss of cell contents and cell death, e.g., the polymixins and amphotericin B.
(iii) Inhibition of protein synthesis Such drugs arrest protein synthesis by affecting the translation in the cell, e.g., Chloramphenicol, aminoglycosides, tetracyclines, erythromycin, lincomycin and clindamycin.
(iv) Inhibition of nucleic acid synthesis These antimicrobial agents prevent multiplication in bacteria, e.g., quinolones and nalidixic acid inhibit DNA replication and rifampicin inhibits RNA synthesis.
(v) Inhibition of folic acid synthesis Folic acid is needed as a cofactor in the synthesis of thymidine and other nucleotides. Sulphonamide structurally resembles para-aminobenzoic acid (PABA) and can enter into folic acid synthesis in place of PABA. As a result, non-functional analogs of folic acid are formed, preventing the synthesis of thymidine which is an essential ingredient of nucleic acid. Further growth of bacteria is thus arrested. Similarly, trimethoprim interferes with the production of purine.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="8952a499">♦ ANTIMICROBIAL DRUGS OF CLINICAL IMPORTANCE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#8952a499" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Antimicrobial drugs may be antibiotics, which are produced by living micro-organisms, or chemical antimicrobials, which are synthetic chemical compounds.</p>
<p>Commonly used antibiotics include the penicillins, cephalosporins, aminoglycosides, chloramphenicol, tetracyclines, polymixins, rifampicin, erythromycin, fusidic acid, clindamycin and vancomycin. Griseofulvin and amphotericin B are antifungal antibiotics.</p>
<p>The common synthetic antimicrobials are the sulphonamides, trimethoprim, cotrimoxazole, nitrofurantoin, nalidixic acid, metronidazole, p-aminosalicylic acid, isoniazid, ethambutol and thiosemicarbazone. Nystatin, flucytosine and imidazole are chemical antifungal agents.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="1-penicillins">1. Penicillins<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-penicillins" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Chemical structure Penicillin is a metabolic product of the mould Penicillium notatum. Its structure includes a <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>β</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\beta</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05278em;">β</span></span></span></span></span>-lactam ring with 4 members, which gives it the specific potency (Fig. 23.1). Alteration of the side chain (R) can lead to the formation of many derivatives.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-ae1bf9e4.jpeg" alt="img-106.jpeg">
Fig. 23.1 Chemical structure of penicillin</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>790 Bacteriology</p>
<p>Mode of action Penicillin inhibits cell wall synthesis by combining with transpeptidase responsible for cross-linking of the peptidoglycan. It is bactericidal, and the activity is dependent on an intact β-lactam ring.</p>
<p>Antibacterial spectrum It varies with individual penicillin. The activity is determined by the side chain (R) of the penicillin nucleus. Penicillin is inactivated by acid.</p>
<p>Resistance Penicillin resistance is common due to the production of an enzyme β-lactamase (Penicillinase) by some bacteria. This enzyme inactivates penicillin by acting on the β-lactam ring. The enzyme β-lactamase is plasmid associated in many cases.</p>
<p>β-lactamase producing bacteria include a large majority of Staphylococcus aureus, Haemophilus influenzae and Neisseria gonorrhoeae.</p>
<p>Penicillin can also elicit allergic reaction of varying severity.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="derivatives-of-penicillin">Derivatives of penicillin<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#derivatives-of-penicillin" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The side chain (R) attached to the β-lactam ring can be chemically altered to form derivatives of penicillin. Some penicillin derivatives are listed in Table 23.1.</p>
<p>The resulting penicillins may have a broader antibacterial spectrum, e.g., ampicillin; or may be resistant to enzyme penicillinase, e.g., methicillin, and cloxacillin; or may be relatively more resistant to acid so that it can be administered orally, e.g., penicillin V or oxacillin (Fig. 23.2).</p>
<p>Benzyl penicillin or penicillin G is the original penicillin and is still the most effective against streptococci such as Strep. pyogenes and Strep. pneumoniae; clostridia, non-penicillinease producing neisseriae and non-penicillinease producing Staph. aureus. Gram negative bacteria such as enterobacteria and Pseudomonas species are resistant to it.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ampicillin">Ampicillin<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ampicillin" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This semi-synthetic penicillin has a wider spectrum of activity than other penicillins. It is destroyed by penicillinase, and therefore it is of no use against penicillinase producers. With the exception of Enterococcus faecalis, it is less active against Gram positive bacteria than penicillin G, but more active against Gram negative bacteria. However, many enterobacteria are becoming resistant due to beta lactamase production. It is bactericidal in action.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="amoxycillin">Amoxycillin<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#amoxycillin" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>It has an activity similar to that of ampicillin but is better absorbed from the gut than ampicillin.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="cloxacillins">Cloxacillins<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cloxacillins" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These penicillin derivatives are produced by manipulation of the penicillin nucleus. They are resistant to β-lactamase. Methicillin was the first drug of this type, and is unstable in the gut due to the acidity. Cloxacillin and flucloxacillin are similar and can be given orally. However, they are less effective than penicillin G and should be used against β-lactamase producing organisms only. They are bactericidal in action.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-69fabf56.jpeg" alt="img-107.jpeg">
Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Antimicrobial Susceptibility Tests 791</p>
<p>Table 23.1 Penicillin and its derivatives</p>

<p>i.m. = intramuscular; i.v. : intravenous
Note: reference to penicillin is taken to mean Penicillin G or Penicillin V</p>
<p>Augmentin This is a combination of amoxycillin and clavulanic acid. The latter is an irreversible inhibitor of most β-lactamases. Augmentin can therefore be used orally against a broad spectrum of β-lactamase producing bacteria. The drug is relatively expensive.</p>
<p>Imipenem It is a carbapenem, a semi-synthetic β-lactam compound. It is administered with an enzyme inhibitor cilastatin which prevents its rapid degradation in the kidneys and thus increases its concentration in urine and serum. The drug is a β-lactamase inhibitor. It has an extremely broad spectrum and is active against Gram positive and negative aerobes and anaerobes.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="2-cephalosporins">2. Cephalosporins<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#2-cephalosporins" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Cephalosporins are a group of antibiotics that are chemically similar to penicillins. Their antibacterial activity can be varied by alteration in the side chains of the cephalosporin nucleus (Fig. 23.3). Their progressive development has led to their distribution into the first, second and now third generation cephalosporins as listed in Table 23.2.</p>
<p>Mode of action is similar to that of penicillin, but they are more resistant to β-lactamase.</p>
<p>Antibacterial spectrum is broad, inhibiting Gram positive and Gram negative bacteria. Most cephalosporins are administered parenterally.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>792 Bacteriology</p>
<p>Table 23.2 The cephalosporins</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Cephalosporin</th><th>Antibacterial spectrum</th><th>Clinical use</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td><strong>First generation</strong></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Cephaloridine</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Cephalothin</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Cephalexin</td><td>Wide range of Gram -positive and Gram-negative bacteria:</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Ent. faecalis, Ps. aeruginosa,</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>H. influenzae and Bacteroides species are resistant. Staph. aureus is sensitive unless methicillin resistant</td><td>Second-line drugs; formerly used in severe sepsis; oral drugs may be of value in ‘difficult’ urinary infections.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td><strong>Second generation</strong></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Cefuroxime</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Cefamandole</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Cefoxitin</td><td>Wide: with marked stability to β-lactamases of Gram-negative as well as gram-positive bacteria.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Active against H. influenzae (especially cefoxitin); Bacteroides species Inferior antistaphylococcal activity</td><td>Have largely replaced the first generation drugs in severe systematic infections.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Widely used in prophylaxis</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td><strong>Third generation</strong></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Cefotaxime</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Latamoxef</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Ceftazidime</td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Ceftriaxone</td><td>Similar to second-generation drugs but in addition activity against Ps. aeruginosa (especially ceftazidime)</td><td>Similar to second generation drugs particularly in serious sepsis due to susceptible aerobic Gram-negative bacilli</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-8812182d.jpeg" alt="img-108.jpeg">
Fig. 23.3 Chemical structure of Cephalosporins</p>
<p>About 10% of people who are hypersensitive to penicillin are also hypersensitive to cephalosporins so that the same precaution taken in administering penicillin is also applicable to the cephalosporins.</p>
<p>The third generation cephalosporins have a wider antibacterial spectrum, are resistant to β-lactamase and are less toxic.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="3-cotrimoxazole">3. Cotrimoxazole<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#3-cotrimoxazole" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Mode of action</strong> Cotrimoxazole contains sulphamethoxazone and trimethoprim in 5:1 ratio. Both drugs act sequentially in folic acid synthesis and have a synergistic action.</p>
<p><strong>Antibacterial spectrum</strong> The drug is effective against many Gram positive cocci, Haemophilus influenzae, Neisseria gonorrhoeae and many Gram negative bacilli.</p>
<p><strong>Resistance</strong> It is not uncommon and is due to the production of bacterial enzymes which are resistant to its action. The resistant enzymes are plasmid-coded.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="4-aminoglycosides">4. Aminoglycosides<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#4-aminoglycosides" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is a group of very useful antibiotics. The important members of the group are listed in Table 23.3.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Antimicrobial Susceptibility Tests 793</p>
<p>Table 23.3 Clinical uses of Aminoglycosides</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Aminoglycoside</th><th>Main clinical use</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Gentamicin</td><td>Severe infections in hospital due to coliforms; gentamicin is still most widely used in certain infections usually given in combination with β-lactam antibiotic.</td></tr><tr><td>Tobramycin</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Amikacin</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Streptomycin</td><td>Now little used most active aminoglycoside against mycobacteria.</td></tr><tr><td>Kanamycin</td><td>May be given orally in 'gut sterilization' regimens prior to surgery, in leukaemia, in chronic liver disease; neomycin also as topical cream.</td></tr><tr><td>Neomycin</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Mode of action The aminoglycosides inhibit protein synthesis by interfering with the genetic transcription which results in the production of a wrong amino acid in proteins. This finally causes cell membrane disruption. They are bacteriocidal in action.</p>
<p>Antibacterial spectrum Aminoglycosides are effective against Gram negative bacteria. Streptomycin is an aminoglycoside that is effective against Mycobacterium tuberculosis in combination with other drugs such as isoniazid, para-aminosalicylic acid. In combination with penicillin G it is also effective against enterococci.</p>
<p>Other aminoglycosides such as kanamycin, neomycin, gentamicin, tobramycin and amikacin, have a broad spectrum activity, but the last two have an exceptional activity against Pseudomonas aeruginosa. Strict anaerobes are intrinsically resistant to aminoglycosides.</p>
<p>Resistance Resistance to aminoglycosides may be due to plasmid-coded inactivating enzymes or decreased transport of the drug into the bacterial cell or due to mutation.</p>
<p>Toxicity All aminoglycosides have a serious toxicity potential including nephrotoxity (kidney damage) and ototoxicity (hearing damage). This is a big adverse side effect that cannot be ignored when selecting any of these drugs for treatment.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="5-tetracyclines">5. Tetracyclines<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5-tetracyclines" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is a group of closely related oral antibiotics which includes tetracycline, chlortetracycline, oxytetracycline, doxycycline and minocycline. The antibacterial activity of all the members of the group is very similar.</p>
<p>Mode of action Tetracyclines inhibit protein synthesis by preventing the attachment of amino acid to ribosomes. They are bacteriostatic in action.</p>
<p>Antibacterial spectrum Tetracyclines have a wide antibacterial spectrum. They are active against Gram negative bacilli including Brucella, Haemophilus ducreyi and Vibrio cholerae; Gram positive cocci such as Staphylococcus aureus Streptococcus pneumoniae and Streptococcus pyogenes; anaerobes; Mycoplasma pneumoniae; chlamydiae and rickettsiae. The tetracyclines are most useful in the management of chronic chest infections such as bronchitis.</p>
<p>However, plasmid-mediated resistance has now developed in some strains of Strep. pyogenes, Strep. pneumoniae and H. influenzae. Ps. aeruginosa and Proteus species are intrinsically resistant.</p>
<p>Toxicity Tetracyclines may give rise to liver and kidney damage, and should be avoided in renal or hepatic failure. It may also cause mild diarrhoea.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="6-chloramphenicol">6. Chloramphenicol<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#6-chloramphenicol" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Mode of action Chloramphenicol acts by inhibiting protein synthesis by attaching itself to the bacterial ribosomes. It is bacteriostatic in action.</p>
<p>Antibacterial spectrum Chloramphenicol is a broad spectrum antibiotic and it is effective against most pathogenic bacteria with the exception of</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>794 Bacteriology</p>
<p>Ps. aeruginosa. It is especially active against Salmonella species, Mycoplasma and some rickettsiae.</p>
<p>Toxicity Chloramphenicol has toxic effects on the bone marrow after a long term therapy. It may lead to fatal aplastic anaemia in some patients. Other adverse effects, such as leukopenia, thrombocytopenia and anaemia, are reversible when the drug is discontinued. For these reasons, the drug is generally restricted for use in life-threatening situations such as typhoid, or meningitis caused by penicillinase producing H. influenzae.</p>
<p>Resistance Many Gram negative bacteria, mainly coliforms, have developed resistance to chloramphenicol due to its frequent use.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="7-erythromycin">7. Erythromycin<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#7-erythromycin" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Erythromycin belongs to the macrolide group of antibiotics. These molecules contain a large lactone ring with one or more deoxy sugars.</p>
<p>Mode of action Erythromycin inhibits protein synthesis by acting on bacterial ribosomes. It is bacteriostatic in action.</p>
<p>Antibacterial spectrum Erythromycin is usually active against both Gram positive and Gram negative organisms such as streptococci, pneumococci and staphylococci, neisseriae, H. influenzae, Bordetella pertussis, Campylobacter species, Legionella pneumophila and Bacteroides fragilis. Many Gram negative bacilli including enterobacteria are resistant. Erythromycin is useful for patients who are hypersensitive to penicillin. Administration is oral or intravenous.</p>
<p>Resistance Erythromycin resistance is not common, but may be induced by mutation in some Gram positive cocci.</p>
<p>Toxicity At usual doses it is relatively non-toxic.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="8-lincomycins">8. Lincomycins<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#8-lincomycins" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Lincomycin and clindamycin are similar to erythromycin in mode of action, antibacterial spectrum and resistance. Clindamycin is better absorbed, and more active against anaerobes. Lincomycins have a very good penetration in tissues such as bones and therefore are recommended for treatment of osteomyelitis, especially when caused by Staphylococcus.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="9-nalidixic-acid">9. Nalidixic Acid<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#9-nalidixic-acid" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This antimicrobial agent inhibits DNA replication. It is active against enterobacteria, but not against Ps. aeruginosa. Clinically, it is used particularly in urinary tract infections and administered orally. It is not recommended for systemic infections.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="10-nitrofurantoin">10. Nitrofurantoin<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#10-nitrofurantoin" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is a synthetic antibacterial agent. It is effective against Gram positive cocci including Enterococcus faecalis and most members of Enterobacteriaceae, but not against Pseudomonas species.</p>
<p>It is administered orally and is readily excreted from kidneys. It is useful for the treatment of urinary tract infections only. Resistance is not common. Nausea is the most common side effect.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="11-vancomycin">11. Vancomycin<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#11-vancomycin" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Vancomycin acts by inhibiting cell wall synthesis. It is active against staphylococci including those resistant to methicillin. It is also active against streptococci and clostridia. It is administered intravenously for serious infections such as endocarditis and septicaemia due to Gram positive cocci, especially in cases of penicillin hypersensitivity. It is used orally in the treatment of colitis. Resistance to this drug is low. It is necessary to monitor serum levels carefully as higher levels may lead to nephrotoxicity and ototoxicity. It is an expensive drug.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="12-polymixins">12. Polymixins<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#12-polymixins" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This group of antibiotics includes polymixin B, polymixin E or colistin and bacitracin. They are selectively active against Gram negative bacilli except Proteus species. However, polymixins are very toxic for systemic use. Hence they are mainly</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Antimicrobial Susceptibility Tests 795</p>
<p>used as topical agents against infections of the eye, ear and burns. Bacitracin sensitivity is used as a screening test in the laboratory for the identification of Group A streptococcus. Colistin is less toxic than other polymyxins and bacitracin and so can be administered intramuscularly. They are bacteriostatic in action.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="13-metronidazole">13. Metronidazole<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#13-metronidazole" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This drug was originally used for the treatment of Trichomonas vaginalis infection in women and has been found to be extremely effective against anaerobes. It is bactericidal in action and inhibits DNA and RNA polymerases.</p>
<p>Metronidazole has no effect on aerobic bacteria. It is also used for the treatment of protozoal infections such as trichomoniasis, amoebiasis and giardiasis. It is used as a post-operative prophylactic drug against anaerobic infections.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="14-rifampicin">14. Rifampicin<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#14-rifampicin" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This is an effective antituberculous drug. It is also active against a wide range of Gram positive and Gram negative bacteria. Resistance may develop rapidly unless given in combination with another drug. It is usually bactericidal in action. It inhibits RNA polymerase enzyme thus preventing the production of RNA.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="15-fusidic-acid">15. Fusidic Acid<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#15-fusidic-acid" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Fuisidic acid is active against many Gram positive and Gram negative bacteria but has an outstanding action against Staph. aureus. It can be given orally or intravenously. It inhibits synthesis of bacterial proteins.</p>
<p>Resistance can quickly develop by mutation. Therefore, it should always be given in combination with other drugs.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="16-antifungal-agents">16. Antifungal Agents<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#16-antifungal-agents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Amphotericin B This is an antifungal agent that can be used as a systemic antibiotic. It provides an effective therapy for fungal infections such as cryptococcosis, blastomycosis and histoplasmosis. Amphotericin B is fungal-static in action.</p>
<p>Nystatin Nystatin is an effective antifungal agent in the topical treatment of candida infections. It is fungal-static in action.</p>
<p>Griseofulvin Griseofulvin is fungal-static in action. It is highly active against infections caused by the dermatophyte fungi.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="bacterial-resistance-to-antimicrobial-agents">BACTERIAL RESISTANCE TO ANTIMICROBIAL AGENTS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bacterial-resistance-to-antimicrobial-agents" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Bacterial resistance to antimicrobial agents has made it difficult to treat successfully some infectious diseases. Most of the resistance is genetic in origin, and it can be transferred between strains, species and genera of bacteria. Resistance is mainly as a result of over use and misuse, that is, abuse of antimicrobial agents.</p>
<p>Pre-disposing factors for the development of bacterial resistance to antimicrobial agents include:</p>
<ol>
<li>Inappropriate use of antimicrobials: This is usually as a result of these drugs being freely procured without medical authorisation or supervision. Under such conditions, the drugs are taken in wrong dosages and for an insufficient length of time.</li>
<li>Wrong selection of drugs: This is usually due to lack of guidelines regarding the correct selection of drugs for those prescribing the drugs. It may also be due to lack of knowledge regarding a drug resistance by the prescribing official. In addition, lack of facility for antibiotic sensitivity testing may result in the wrong choice of drugs.</li>
<li>Inadequate control measures: Inadequate control and management measures in the use of chemotherapeutic agents in hospitals inadvertently give rise to the development of resistance to various drugs by bacteria.</li>
<li>Prophylactic use of antimicrobials: The practice of frequent prophylactic use of antibiotics may also enhance the development of bacterial</li>
</ol>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>796 Bacteriology</p>
<p>drug resistance. This is not right especially for the broad spectrum antibiotics.</p>
<p>Drug resistance is of two types—natural and acquired.</p>
<p><strong>Natural drug resistance</strong> Natural drug resistance is an innate property of the bacterium, and is unrelated to previous exposure to the drug. An entire bacterial species may be resistant to an antibiotic even before the introduction of the drug. For example, <em>Strep. pyogenes</em> is resistant to gentamicin, <em>Staph. aureus</em> is resistant to polymixins, <em>Proteus mirabilis</em> is resistant to colistin and <em>Pseudomonas aeruginosa</em> is resistant to cloxacillin. The reasons for this natural resistance include lack of penetration of the drug through the cell wall, lack of suitable cell wall or other target receptors, naturally produced enzymes that may have existed before the introduction of the drug which may be lethal to the drug.</p>
<p><strong>Acquired drug resistance</strong> Resistance to some drugs can be acquired by bacteria in two ways:</p>
<p><strong>Mutation</strong> Bacterial resistance may develop as a result of spontaneous mutation. This method is not very common. Resistance of <em>Mycobacterium tuberculosis</em> to streptomycin develops by mutation.</p>
<p><strong>Gene Transfer</strong> Transfer of genetic material from one organism to another is a major cause of bacterial resistance. This resistance is not only transferred from one bacterium to another of the same species, but also between different species, and sometimes, even between related genera.</p>
<p>Most of the acquired drug resistance of <em>Staph. aureus</em> and Gram negative bacilli are 'R' factor or Plasmid mediated. Plasmids are extrachromosomal strands of DNA which are capable of self-replication, and which may code for antibiotic resistance. The plasmids can be transferred from an antibiotic resistant strain to an antibiotic sensitive strain, thus making a sensitive strain resistant to the antibiotic. This is achieved by 'conjugation'. By the process of conjugation, it is possible to transfer multiple antibiotic resistance between different strains, species and genera of Gram negative bacteria.</p>
<p>Plasmid mediated antibiotic resistance in <em>Staph. aureus</em> is achieved by transduction (by bacteriophages), and not by conjugation. Secondly, the plasmids in <em>Staph. aureus</em> usually code for resistance to one, two or more antibiotics at a time (e.g. penicillin and/or tetracycline).</p>
<p>Incidence of drug resistance is usually higher in countries where antibiotics are openly available to the general population. Due to indiscriminate use of antibiotics, the resistance plasmids in the normal human bowel flora may be transferred to some intestinal pathogens such as <em>Salmonella</em> and <em>Shigella</em>. In this way, a plasmid for chloramphenicol resistance is transferred to different strains of <em>Salmonella typhi</em>, thus making it difficult to treat outbreaks of typhoid fever with chloramphenicol. Enzymes which inactivate aminoglycosides are also plasmid-mediated. However, methicillin resistance of <em>Staph. aureus</em> strains due to an altered penicillin binding protein in the cell wall is chromosome rather than plasmid mediated.</p>
<p>Genetic transfer of antimicrobial resistance can also take place through transposons. These are small pieces of DNA which, unlike plasmids, cannot replicate themselves, but can 'jump' between different plasmids, and between plasmids and chromosomes. An example of an important gene carried by an antibiotic resistant transposon is known as TEM 1. It controls the production of beta-lactamase and is incorporated into plasmids which then mediate resistance to β-lactam antibiotics in some strains of <em>E. coli</em>, <em>Klebsiella</em>, <em>Haemophilus influenzae</em> and <em>Neisseria gonorrhoeae</em>. The resistance transposon can be transferred from one strain to another.</p>
<p><strong>Cross resistance</strong> If a bacterium is resistant to one drug, it may also express resistance to another chemically related drug. For example, bacteria resistant to one tetracycline or sulphonamide may exhibit resistance to all the tetracyclines or all the sulphonamides.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="mechanisms-of-antimicrobial-resistance">MECHANISMS OF ANTIMICROBIAL RESISTANCE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#mechanisms-of-antimicrobial-resistance" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>There are three main mechanisms of drug resistance. (Table 23.4).</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>797</p>
<p>Table 23.4 Mechanisms of bacterial resistance to antimicrobials</p>
<table><thead><tr><th></th><th>Type of defect</th><th>Example</th><th>Mechanism</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Permeability</td><td>Inadequate entry into bacterial cell</td><td>Aminoglycoside and Pseudomonas species</td><td>Poorly understood defects in "permeases" or other transport mechanisms, especially in Gram-negative bacteria.</td></tr><tr><td>Modification</td><td>i. Alteration of penicillin binding proteins (PBP)</td><td>β-lactam antibiotics and Gram-positive bacteria</td><td>Intact PBPs are necessary for the activity of β-lactam drugs. Changes in these proteins cause the multiple resistance in Streptococcus pneumoniae and probably methicillin resistance in Staph.aureus.</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>ii. Alteration of ribosomes</td><td>Erythromycin and Staph. aureus</td><td>Plasmid-mediated methylation of the 30S ribosome blocks attachment of the drug to the ribosome</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>iii. Synthesis of resistant biochemical pathways</td><td>Trimethoprim and Gram-negative bacteria</td><td>Plasmid-coded metabolic enzymes that are more resistant to drug action: dihydropteroate synthetase for sulphonamides and dihydrofolate reductase for trimethoprim.</td></tr><tr><td>Inactivation</td><td>Enzymatic inactivation of antibiotic</td><td>β-lactamases and various bacteria</td><td>Chromosomal and/or plasmid-coded enzymes with varying specificities for penicillins and cephalosporins (eg. Staphylococcus aureus, Haemophilus influenzae, and Neisseria gonorrhoeae).</td></tr><tr><td></td><td></td><td>Aminoglycosides and Gram-negative bacteria</td><td>Several enzymes affecting acetylation, phosphorylation, and adenylylation. Aminoglycosides vary in susceptibility to the enzymes.</td></tr><tr><td></td><td></td><td>Chloramphenicol and Staph. aureus or Gram-negative bacteria</td><td>Plasmid-coded acetyltransferases are responsible for most resistance to this drug. The enzyme is constitutive in Gram-negatives but induced by the antibiotic in Staph.aureus.</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>798 Bacteriology</p>
<p>(i) Permeability Bacteria alter the permeability of their cell membrane, possibly by modification of proteins in the outer membrane, so that it is difficult for an antimicrobial to enter the bacterial cell. This is a common mechanism for resistance in <em>Ps. aeruginosa</em>.</p>
<p>(ii) Modification of the site of action By genetic mutation, bacteria change the proteins and other components which are used by antimicrobials as binding sites. Sometimes bacteria divert the biochemical pathway to avoid the action of antibiotic. This type of resistance is usually plasmid-coded, e.g., Resistance to erythromycin, sulphonamides and aminoglycosides. Another example is methicillin resistance of <em>Staph. aureus</em> by alteration in the penicillin binding protein in the cell wall. This resistance, however, is not plasmid mediated.</p>
<p>(iii) Inactivation of the antimicrobial This is a very common form of resistance. Bacteria produce enzymes which inactivate the drug. The genes which code for the production of such enzymes are carried on plasmids, e.g., <em>Staphylococcus aureus</em> and <em>Haemophilus influenzae</em> producing β-lactamase to destroy penicillin. This resistance can be transferred from one genus or species of bacterium to another.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="selection-of-antimicrobial-agents-for-in-vitro-testing">SELECTION OF ANTIMICROBIAL AGENTS FOR <em>IN VITRO</em> TESTING<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#selection-of-antimicrobial-agents-for-in-vitro-testing" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>It is impractical and unnecessary to test every antimicrobial agent available against each clinically significant isolate. Each laboratory must determine which antimicrobial agents are appropriate in its own particular set up, considering factors such as the resistance pattern of local pathogens, local habits of prescribing drugs with relevance to the cost, toxicity and spectrum of activity. Ideally, there should be panels of drugs for each species or category of bacteria. A panel may consist of:</p>
<p>(i) Drugs that should be routinely tested and reported (First line drugs)
(ii) Drugs that should be routinely tested but reported selectively (Second-line or ‘Extended Panel’ drugs)
(iii) Drugs that should be tested only in selected conditions
(iv) Drugs that can be considered only for isolates from the lower urinary tract.</p>
<p>Generally, there should be separate panels of drugs for Gram positive bacteria, enterobacteria, <em>Pseudomonas</em> and urinary tract pathogens. It is recommended that <em>Haemophilus</em> species, <em>Neisseria</em> species and enterococci should also have separate panels of drugs.</p>
<p>Table 23.5 shows commonly used antibiotics and susceptible bacteria.</p>
<p>Table 23.6 (a and b) lists suggested groupings of antimicrobials for <em>in vitro</em> testing.</p>
<p>Clinical isolates need not be tested against drugs which are not useful in the treatment for any reason. For example:</p>
<p>(i) Gram positive bacteria should not be tested against polymixins because they have no activity against Gram positive bacteria.
(ii) For the same reason, Gram negative bacteria should not be tested against vancomycin, <em>Proteus</em> species should not be tested against tetracycline, nitrofurantoin or polymyxins, or <em>H. influenzae</em> against first generation cephalosporins.
(iii) Nalidixic acid and nitrofurantoin should be tested only against isolates from the urinary tract.
(iv) Methicillin and fusidic acid should be tested only against staphylococci.
(v) Chloramphenicol should be tested only for serious infections with <em>H. influenzae</em>, <em>Salmonella</em> species, Gram negative anaerobes and anaerobic streptococci.
(vi) From a group of closely related drugs showing cross-resistance, only a representative drug should be tested, e.g., one tetracycline represents all tetracyclines – colistin can be substituted for polymixin B, benzyl penicillin represents all penicillinase – susceptible penicillins; such as ampicillin, amoxycillin, carbenicillin, pipercillin etc.
(vii) Staphylococci exhibiting resistance to methicillin or cloxacillin should be reported as resistant to cephalosporins, carbapenems and β-lactamase inhibitor combinations even if they are sensitive to these agents <em>in vitro</em>.</p>
