<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-2da143ba.jpeg" alt="img-114.jpeg">
Fig. 23.9 Stoke's method using rotating turntable</p>
<p>(ii) Resistant No zone of inhibition.
(iii) Intermediate Zone size is more than 3 mm smaller than the control strain (e.g. Zone radius of control strain is 8 mm; that of test strain is 4 mm). Intermediate susceptibility result indicates that the therapy with the drug can be successful only if it is administered in larger doses or when the drug is concentrated at a site such as urinary tract.</p>
<p>Note
Many workers prefer to report only sensitive and resistant actions, whereby the so called intermediate result is regarded as resistant.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="ditch-plate-method">DITCH PLATE METHOD<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ditch-plate-method" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>This method consists of removing a strip of agar from a plate and filling the gutter thus formed with agar containing the antibiotic required to be tested. The plate is allowed to set and several organisms can then be streaked at right angles to the ditch.</p>
<p>The ditch plate method is suitable when a large number of organisms are to be tested against one antibiotic. The big disadvantage of this method is that the plate must be prepared fresh everyday. The method is no longer used in clinical laboratories.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="heatley-cup-or-punched-hole-diffusion-method">HEATLEY CUP OR PUNCHED HOLE DIFFUSION METHOD<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#heatley-cup-or-punched-hole-diffusion-method" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The use of Heatley cup or punched hole methods for antibiotic susceptibility testing has become obsolete. The method consisted of filling several punched holes made in an agar plate; or the special</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>812 Bacteriology</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-26a919a3.jpeg" alt="img-115.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 23.10 Interpretation of sensitivity tests (Stoke's method)</p>
<p>Interpretation</p>
<p>(a) Sensitive: The zone radius of the test strain is larger than that of the control
(b) Sensitive: The zone radius of the test strain is equal to that of the control
(c) Resistant: The zone radius of the test strain is smaller by &gt; 3 mm than that of the control.</p>
<p>cups (open at both ends) placed on the agar plate, which is already seeded with test organism. The holes or cups are filled with varying concentrations of the antibiotic being tested. The method is considered too laborious.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="special-considerations-in-susceptibility-testing">SPECIAL CONSIDERATIONS IN SUSCEPTIBILITY TESTING<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#special-considerations-in-susceptibility-testing" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Penicillin resistance and β-lactamases β-lactamases are heterogeneous bacterial enzymes which cleave the β-lactam ring of the penicillins and cephalosporins to inactivate the drug. Many bacterial species are known to produce them. Clinically the most important β-lactamase producers are Staphylococcus aureus, Haemophilus species and Neisseria gonorrhoeae. The enzymes may be located on the chromosome, but more often are on plasmids which are transferable from one bacterium to another. The β-lactamase in some bacteria is constitutive, i.e., present even in the absence of the antibiotic; or inducible i.e. produced only in the presence of the antibiotic. Some β-lactamases affect many antibiotics, others act either on penicillins or cephalosporins.</p>
<p>Tests for the detection of β-lactamase There are three types of tests in use for the detection of β-lactamase: acid formation method, iodometric method and nitrocefin test. The test for the detection of β-lactamase is described in Chapter 13 of this Section.</p>
<p>Staphylococcus species Staphylococci produce β-lactamases only when exposed to penicillins. The resistance to penicillin G and related compounds by staphylococci is due to these β-lactamases. However, these enzymes are not active against the penillinase-resistant penicillins such as methicillin, and against cephalosporins.</p>
<p>Penicillin resistant staphylococci may produce a zone of inhibition if the small quantity of penicillinase produced by these staphylococci is not sufficient to inactivate the high level of penicillin near the disc. This zone shows a characteristic heaped up clearly defined edge without any gradually fading growth, as can be seen in sensitive strains. All the strains which show such a heaped up edge should therefore, be regarded as resistant to penicillin.</p>
<p>Haemophilus influenzae Twenty to forty per cent of type b Haemophilus influenzae produce β-lactamase, and are resistant to penicillin and ampicillin. Treatment with a combination of amoxycillin and clavulanic acid (augmentin) is effective. Clavulanic acid is an inhibitor of many β-lactamases. It is recommended that Haemophilus influenzae isolated from any severe infection should be tested for β-lactamase production.</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Antimicrobial Susceptibility Tests 813</p>
<p>A few strains of <em>H. influenzae</em> are resistant to ampicillin by mechanisms other than β-lactamase activity. Therefore, a β-lactamase negative strain should also be tested against ampicillin before using the drug for therapy. With a 2 μg ampicillin disc, a zone of 20 mm or more is considered susceptible and a lesser zone resistant.</p>
<p><strong>Neisseria gonorrhoeae</strong> Prior to 1975, penicillin was considered the drug of choice for the treatment of uncomplicated gonococcal infections. However, most <em>N. gonorrhoeae</em> have acquired resistance to penicillin by plasmid mediated penicillinase production. These penicillinase producing <em>N. gonorrhoeae</em> (PPNG) can be detected by the β-lactamase test. Ceftriaxone is effective against PPNG.</p>
<p><strong>Methicillin resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA)</strong> Some strains of <em>Staph. aureus</em> (and <em>Staph. epidermidis</em>) are resistant to penicillinase resistant penicillins such as methicillin, cloxacillin and naficillin. The resistance is chromosomally mediated, and is expressed only in a small fraction of bacteria in a culture. This is called hetero-resistance. These resistant organisms grow more slowly than the susceptible ones and are likely to be overgrown, unless incubated at a lower temperature below 35 °C, preferably at 30°C.</p>
<p>Detection of methicillin resistance is enhanced by the addition of 4% sodium chloride to the agar medium. If the strain is sensitive, the zone of inhibition is clear and well-defined. If the strain is methicillin resistant, a feathering effect is seen in the inhibition zone, i.e., there is a gradually decreasing growth right up to the disc.</p>
<p>Some strains of staphylococci show methicillin resistance by hyperproduction of β-lactamases. These strains can be detected if they are tested with a combination of amoxycillin and clavulanic acid (augmentin), to which they are sensitive. For clinical purposes, these strains are also considered as methicillin resistant.</p>
<p>If a strain of methicillin-resistant <em>Staphylococcus</em> is sensitive to cephalosporins <em>in vitro</em>, it may be found to be resistant to cephalosporins <em>in vivo</em> and does not respond to cephalosporin therapy. Therefore, all methicillin resistant strains should also be reported as resistant to cephalosporins.</p>
<p>The MRSAs are usually sensitive to rifampicin and always sensitive to vancomycin.</p>
<p><strong>Streptococcus pneumoniae</strong> Penicillin has been the standard treatment for pneumococcal infections for many years. However, strains with multiple drug resistance including penicillin have emerged in the last few years; and are β-lactamase negative. The simplest test for the detection of this resistance is to test the isolate against a 1 μg oxacillin disc or 5 μg methicillin disc. Inhibition zone of 19 mm or less should be considered resistant to penicillin and should be confirmed by MIC determination.</p>
<p><strong>Other streptococci</strong> Most streptococci are sensitive to penicillin, while some may be resistant to erythromycin. However, penicillin resistance is emerging in Viridans streptococci; aminoglycosides may be used in combination to treat Viridans endocarditis. Enterococci are resistant to penicillin due to β-lactamase production. The strains also show a high level aminoglycoside resistance, especially to gentamicin and streptomycin.</p>
<p><strong>Sulphonamides</strong> An organism should be reported as sensitive to cotrimoxazole only when sensitivity is shown to both sulphamethoxazole and trimethoprim. It is recommended that separate discs for these drugs should be used. In practice a single disc of cotrimoxazole is used for sensitivity tests.</p>
<p>While reading results of susceptibility, a slight growth in the inhibition zone around a sulphonamide disc should be disregarded and the organism should be considered as sensitive.</p>
<p><strong>Swarming of Proteus species</strong> Swarming of <em>Proteus</em> species is not inhibited by all antimicrobials and they often swarm into the area of inhibition. This film of swarming should be ignored while reading results.</p>
<p><strong>Polymixins and Vancomycin</strong> Polymixins such as colistin and polymixin B, and vancomycin produce small zones of inhibition because they diffuse</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>814 Bacteriology</p>
<p>into the agar medium very slowly due to their large molecular size. These antibiotics should therefore be properly controlled in sensitivity testing.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="direct-sensitivity-tests">DIRECT SENSITIVITY TESTS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#direct-sensitivity-tests" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>These sensitivity tests are those tests performed directly with clinical specimens. In all other respects, the technique is the same as that used for indirect sensitivity (on the isolated pathogen). It is usually performed on specimens where the Gram stain shows large number of one type of organism and pus cells.</p>
<p>Direct sensitivity test has some advantages and disadvantages:</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="advantages">Advantages<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#advantages" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>(i) Susceptibility results are available within one day after receiving the specimen.
(ii) In mixed cultures, it may help to separate bacterial species with different sensitivities.
(iii) It helps in the identification of bacteria which have constant sensitivity patterns.
(iv) It is easier to detect the presence of a small number of resistant variants, which may otherwise be lost in the parent sensitive strain.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="disadvantages">Disadvantages<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#disadvantages" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>(i) The density of the bacterial inoculum cannot be controlled. It may be too light or too heavy, in which case the effort of the direct sensitivity test is wasted.
(ii) It is difficult to select an appropriate control strain because the exact identity of the isolate is not known.
(iii) For the same reason as above, it is difficult to select the appropriate panel of antimicrobials.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="indications-for-direct-sensitivity-test">Indications for direct sensitivity test<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#indications-for-direct-sensitivity-test" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>These tests are particularly useful in specimens such as urine samples, pus and other specimens from sites which are not likely to have a heavy mixed flora. It is most useful in positive blood cultures and CSF.</p>
<p>The results obtained with the direct sensitivity test are considered as presumptive until the identity of the isolate is known and confirmed. The results of direct tests should not be reported if the inoculum density is not satisfactory.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="antibiotic-combinations">ANTIBIOTIC COMBINATIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#antibiotic-combinations" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Antimicrobial therapy with a combination of two or more antibiotics is sometimes necessary in the following conditions:</p>
<p>(i) To cover a wide range of possible infecting pathogens before the causative one is known.
(ii) To treat mixed infections where all the causative agents are not susceptible to a common antibiotic.
(iii) To prevent development of bacterial resistance to a single antibiotic
(iv) To reduce drug related toxicity of one antibiotic by administering non-toxic doses of two antibiotics
(v) To achieve synergistic effect by two drugs.</p>
<p>When two drugs are administered together, they may interact with each other in four different ways:</p>
<p>(i) Autonomous When the result with two drugs is equal to the result with the most effective drug between the two.
(ii) Indifference When the action of each drug in the presence of the other is neither greater nor less than its action alone.
(iii) Antagonistic When the result with two drugs is significantly less than the result of each drug used separately.
(iv) Additive When the action of two drugs is equal to the combined action of each drug used separately.
(v) Synergistic When the action of two drugs is significantly greater than the action of either drug alone.</p>
<p>Figures 23.11 A, B, and C show the effects of autonomy, antagonism and synergism between two drugs.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="examples-of-synergism">Examples of synergism<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#examples-of-synergism" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Synergistic therapy is useful in the treatment of enterococcal endocarditis</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Antimicrobial Susceptibility Tests 815</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-3234daa7.jpeg" alt="img-116.jpeg">
Fig. 23.11 A, B, C Interpretation of the effects of combination therapy by disc diffusion</p>
<p>with a penicillin and an aminoglycoside. Penicillin facilitates the entry of aminoglycoside into the bacterial cell, thus making it more effective.</p>
<p>Trimethoprim and sulphonamides act synergistically by exerting individual antibacterial action at sequential points in the metabolism of folic acid synthesis.</p>
<p>Another example of synergism is the use of a <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>β</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\beta</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05278em;">β</span></span></span></span></span>-lactamase inhibitor such as clavulanic acid with a <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>β</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\beta</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05278em;">β</span></span></span></span></span>-lactam antibiotic such as amoxycillin for bacteria which produce <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>β</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\beta</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05278em;">β</span></span></span></span></span>-lactamases.</p>
<p>Checkerboard assay The effect of combination of two drugs on a bacterium can be tested by a checkerboard assay in a microtitre plate. One drug is diluted in all the wells horizontally in twofold dilutions, and the other is diluted in the same way vertically, resulting in various combinations of two drugs. After inoculation with the test organism and appropriate incubation, the result of the combination can be studied by comparing with the MIC of each individual drug. This is not a routine test.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="b-tests-for-the-assessment-of-patient-s-response-to-antimicrobial-therapy-antibiotic-assays">B. TESTS FOR THE ASSESSMENT OF PATIENT'S RESPONSE TO ANTIMICROBIAL THERAPY (ANTIBIOTIC ASSAYS)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#b-tests-for-the-assessment-of-patient-s-response-to-antimicrobial-therapy-antibiotic-assays" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The effectiveness of antimicrobial therapy needs to be assessed for two reasons:</p>
<p>(i) To determine that adequate levels of the antimicrobial drugs are being achieved in patient's</p>
<p>body fluids. This assay also detects the presence of undesirably high (toxic) levels which may harm the patient.</p>
<p>(ii) To assess the bacterial activity of patient's serum against the causative agent.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="determination-of-serum-antimicrobial-levels-antibiotic-assays">Determination of Serum Antimicrobial Levels (Antibiotic Assays)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#determination-of-serum-antimicrobial-levels-antibiotic-assays" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>In situations where the toxic level of a drug is close to its optimum therapeutic level, it is necessary to closely monitor the concentration of the drug in the serum. For example, MIC of gentamicin for <em>Pseudomonas aeruginosa</em> is <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>4</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>8</mn><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi>μ</mi><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">4 - 8\ \mu\mathrm{g/ml}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">4</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">8</span><span class="mspace">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathnormal">μ</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">g/ml</span></span></span></span></span></span>, and the antibiotic at <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>10</mn><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi>μ</mi><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">10\ \mu\mathrm{g/ml}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">10</span><span class="mspace">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathnormal">μ</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">g/ml</span></span></span></span></span></span> is considered to be toxic. Therefore, it needs to be very closely monitored, especially in cases of renal failure.</p>
<p>Specimens Serum is the body fluid which is most frequently used. The blood sample is preferably collected twice:</p>
<p>(a) At the trough level, i.e., immediately before the administration of a dose when the level is lowest.
(b) At the peak level, i.e., 30 minutes after an intravenous dose, 60 minutes after an intramuscular dose or 60-120 minutes after an oral dose has been given. This is when the level is highest.</p>
<p>(i) Microbiological assay This is the method generally employed in the microbiology laboratory. It is cheap and can be accurate in experienced hands. This technique is a modification of the disc diffusion test. Blank paper discs are impregnated</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>816 Bacteriology</p>
<p>with a series of concentrations of the antimicrobial drug under test.</p>
<p>Each concentration (disc) is tested against a lawn culture of an indicator bacterial strain in the same way as for the disc diffusion test.</p>
<p>A paper disc impregnated with serum sample is also tested against the same bacterial strain.</p>
<p>A standard curve is constructed from the inhibition zone diameters produced by various known concentrations.</p>
<p>The diameter of the inhibition zone produced by the body fluid can be used to approximate the concentration of the antimicrobial agent in the body fluid.</p>
<p>(ii) Immunoassay Immunoassay is based on the competition between the drug in the serum specimen and a labelled compound for a specific antibody. This is a fairly accurate method though expensive. It is used for the assay of aminoglycosides such as amikacin and gentamicin; and for vancomycin.</p>
<p>Automated equipments are available for this purpose. A popular equipment is the Abbot TDX and AxSym systems. These machines have the advantages of speed (results are ready in 20–30 minutes), specificity and accuracy (not affected by the presence of other drugs). They are convenient in a busy laboratory. The method is expensive.</p>
<p>(iii) Enzymatic assay Enzymatic assay is performed by the use of enzymes which act on the drug, for example, β-lactamases for β-lactam antibiotics. The reaction can be detected by the development of a coloured product or by the use of radioactive labels. It is also expensive as special equipments are required.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="determination-of-serum-antimicrobial-activity-bactericidal-levels-schlichter-test">Determination of Serum Antimicrobial Activity (Bactericidal Levels): Schlichter Test<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#determination-of-serum-antimicrobial-activity-bactericidal-levels-schlichter-test" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>This test determines the ability of a patient's serum to kill the organism isolated from the patient. The activity of the drug in the patient's serum can be tested under conditions which more closely resemble the 'in vivo' environment, than most other 'in vitro' tests. For example, some antimicrobials get easily bound to proteins, thereby greatly reducing their antibacterial activity. This factor may not be taken into consideration in other in vitro tests. In Schlichter test, however, patient's serum which contains the drug is used and only that fraction which is free for biological activity (after binding to proteins) is measured. Although the antibacterial activity mainly comes from the antibiotic in the serum; other factors such as antibody and complement may also exert bactericidal effects against the causative agent.</p>
<p>The technique used for the serum bactericidal activity is a modification of the tube dilution technique for the determination of MIC. Instead of the dilution of the antibacterial agent, patient's serum is serially diluted. An inhibitory level showing no growth is inoculated onto an agar medium to determine the dilution where complete killing of the causative agent occurs. A non-serum containing control is inoculated in addition to a tube of broth which is not inoculated.</p>
<p>Specimen Two specimens at the trough and peak levels should be collected.</p>
<p>Preparation of inoculum The inoculum should be prepared from the organism isolated from the patient, usually from the blood culture, in the same manner as for the MIC tube dilution technique. The working inoculum should contain about <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>10</mn><mn>5</mn></msup><mo>−</mo><msup><mn>10</mn><mn>6</mn></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">10^{5} - 10^{6}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8974em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">0</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">5</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">0</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">6</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> organisms per ml</p>
<p>Technique The patient's serum samples can be diluted either in Mueller-Hinton broth, Todd-Hewitt broth or in pooled human serum inactivated at <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>56</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∘</mo></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">56^{\circ}\mathrm{C}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">5</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">6</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6741em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∘</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm">C</span></span></span></span></span> for one hour. The use of pooled serum is more advantageous because some antibiotics are highly protein-bound; and the test is more likely to resemble 'in vivo' conditions.</p>
<p>(i) Set up 12 tubes for each serum sample
(ii) Pipette <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>0.5</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">0.5\mathrm{ml}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord">0.5</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">ml</span></span></span></span></span></span> of the diluent (broth or heat-inactivated pooled serum) in tubes 1–9, tube 10 (inoculum control), tube 12 (serum control); and add <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>1.0</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1.0\mathrm{ml}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord">1.0</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">ml</span></span></span></span></span></span> to tube 11 (diluent control).</p>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Antimicrobial Susceptibility Tests 817</p>
<p>(iii) Pipette 0.5 ml of patient's serum into tubes 1 and 12.
(iv) Make two-fold dilutions in 0.5 ml amounts starting from tube 1-9. Discard 0.5 ml from tube 9.
(v) Add 0.5 ml of the working inoculum into tubes 1-10.
(vi) Centrifuge all the tubes.
(vii) Prepare 1:100 dilution of the working inoculum and plate 0.001 ml of this dilution onto a blood agar plate for a colony count.
(viii) Incubate the tubes and the blood agar plate for 18-24 hours at 37°C.</p>
<p><strong>Results</strong> Check the control tubes as shown in Table 23.10.</p>
<p>The minimum inhibitory titre is the first dilution showing no visible growth.</p>
<p>To determine the bactericidal titre, subculture 0.01 ml from each dilution of the tube showing no visible growth onto blood agar plates.</p>
<p>Incubate the plates for 18-24 hours at 37°C.</p>
<p>The serum antibactericidal dilution that shows 99.9% killing of bacteria (less than 5 colonies) in the initial inoculum is the bactericidal titre.</p>
<p>The antibiotic dosage which gives serum bactericidal dilution of 1:8 or 1:16 is considered as adequate therapy.</p>
<p>Table 23.10 Interpretation table for serum bactericidal titre</p>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="bacteriological-examination-of-water-milk-food-and-air">Bacteriological Examination of Water, Milk, Food and Air<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bacteriological-examination-of-water-milk-food-and-air" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="bacteriological-examination-of-water">BACTERIOLOGICAL EXAMINATION OF WATER<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bacteriological-examination-of-water" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Drinking water must be free from harmful microorganisms that can cause serious ill health. Supplies of drinking water may be contaminated with sewage being allowed to seep into wells or boreholes, or faecal matter from man and animals being passed into rivers, streams or pools. Such contaminations may cause diseases like typhoid fever, cholera, bacterial dysentery, amoebiasis and helmenthiasis.</p>
<p>The aim of bacteriological examination of water is to detect whether contamination with pathogenic bacteria has occurred or not. It is impracticable to directly attempt detection of the presence of numerous water-borne pathogens, some of which may only be present intermittently. The bacteriologist, instead, tests for the presence of indicator bacteria which are the common intestinal commensals such as Coliforms, particularly <em>Escherichia coli</em>; <em>Streptococcus faecalis</em> (<em>Enterococcus faecalis</em>), and <em>Clostridium perfringens</em>. These organisms are excreted in large numbers by man and animals.</p>
<p>Their presence in water indicates that:</p>
<p>(i) faecal matter has entered the water supply
(ii) the faecal organisms have not been killed or removed during purification and treatment
(iii) there is the possibility of contamination with intestinal pathogens.</p>
<p>It is not enough to detect the presence of the indicator bacteria, they are also enumerated because the greater their number, the greater the danger of infection from the water supply. It should be remembered that some bacteria, viruses and parasites are more resistant to chlorination than some faecal bacteria used as indicators of pollution.</p>
<p>Bacteriological examination of water is generally performed by the following tests:</p>
<ol>
<li>Presumptive coliform count</li>
<li>Tests for faecal streptococci and <em>Clostridium perfringens</em>.</li>
<li>Plate count.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="collection-of-water-samples">COLLECTION OF WATER SAMPLES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#collection-of-water-samples" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Water samples for bacteriological examination should be collected in sterile containers. Accidental contamination during collection and transportation to the laboratory should be avoided. Methods of collecting water samples vary according to the source of the water. It is recommended to use sterilised glass bottles with ground glass stoppers or screw-caps for sampling.</p>
<p>The following precautions should be observed for collection of water samples:</p>
<ol>
<li>The sample should be an adequate representation of the water to be examined.</li>
<li>To avoid contamination during collection of samples, flame the mouths of taps and hydrants and</li>
</ol>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>Bacteriological Examination of Water, Milk, Food and Air 819</p>
<p>allow water to run for 3–5 minutes to waste before being collected into the bottle. When collecting samples from rivers or lakes, open the bottle and push the neck downwards about 30 cm below the water surface with its mouth facing the current and ensure that water entering the bottle has not been in contact with the hand. It is better to hold the bottle at the base. The stopper should not be laid down or allowed to touch anything.</p>
<p>Where there is no current, push the bottle forward horizontally until it is filled. Well water should be sampled with weighted bottle.</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>
<p>Stopper the bottle and label with full details of the source of water, date and time of collection. Deliver the sample to the laboratory as quickly as possible. The water should be tested within six hours of collection. If more than three hours delay is envisaged, the sample should be packed in ice for transport to the laboratory.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>When sampling chlorinated water, 0.1 ml of 1.8% (w/v) aqueous solution of sodium thiosulphate should be added to the sample bottle before collecting the water. That amount of sodium thiosulphate is enough to neutralise any chlorine present in 100 ml of water.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="frequency-of-sampling">Frequency of Sampling<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#frequency-of-sampling" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The frequency of bacteriological examination of water depends on the source of supply and location of sampling points. Bacteriological testing of treated water should be routinely done on daily basis at each stage of treatment.</p>
<p>For example, large supplies of chlorinated water serving populations greater than 100,000 should be sampled daily for bacteriological examination with continuous chlorine residual checks. With small supplies serving a population of 10,000 or less, it is impracticable to carry out a daily sampling. It is important in such cases to determine and control the free and combined residual chlorine in water leaving the treatment plant daily and carry out bacteriological analysis once a week.</p>
<p>Table 24.1 shows the WHO guidelines on the maximum interval between successive samples for bacteriological analysis of unchlorinated water supplies before distribution. For water in distribution pipes, at least one sample per month is adequate for a population of 5000. It is however beneficial to establish a routine of random sampling procedure.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="eda530a9">♦ PRESUMPTIVE COLIFORM COUNT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#eda530a9" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>There are two methods used to detect and count bacteria in water:</p>
<ol>
<li>Multiple tube method</li>
<li>Membrane filtration method</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="multiple-tube-method-for-faecal-coliforms">Multiple tube Method for Faecal Coliforms<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#multiple-tube-method-for-faecal-coliforms" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><strong>Principle</strong> Measured volumes of neat and diluted water are added to a series of tubes containing a liquid indicator growth medium. A characteristic colour change in any tube indicates the presence of indicator bacteria in the sample. The most probable number (MPN) of indicator organisms in the sample depends on the number and distribution of positive and negative reactions.</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Population size</th><th>Interval</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>50,000–100,000</td><td>4 days</td></tr><tr><td>20,000–50,000</td><td>15 days</td></tr><tr><td>Less than 20,000</td><td>30 days</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Scanned by CamScanner</p>
<p>820 Bacteriology</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="required">Required<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#required" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>(i) Sample of water
(ii) Sterile test tubes
(iii) Ringer solution (Quarter strength)
(iv) 1 ml, 10 ml and 50 ml pipettes
(v) MacConkey broth containing bromocresol purple indicator (double strength), with inverted Durham tube
(vi) MacConkey broth containing bromocresol purple indicator (single strength), with inverted Durham tube.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="method">Method<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#method" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Mix the sample of water thoroughly by inverting the bottle 25–30 times.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Aseptically inoculate the tubes as follows: (refer to the guidelines below)
1 × 50 ml of broth + 50 ml of water
5 × 10 ml of broth + 10 ml of water
5 × 5 ml of broth + 1 ml of water (in case of untreated water).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Mix the contents of each tube.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Incubate all the tubes at 37°C for 18–24 hours with tubes loosely capped.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>All tubes showing acid (colour change to yellow) and gas (bubble in the Durham's tube) are regarded as ‘presumptive positive’. Reincubate ‘negatives’ for a further 24 hours.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Using probability tables, the most probable number of presumptive coliform bacilli per 100 ml or 105 ml of the sampled water is determined. Table 24.2 shows the probability table for counting the MPN of coliforms.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="confirmed-e-coli-count">Confirmed E.coli count<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#confirmed-e-coli-count" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The presence of <em>E. coli</em> in water is indicative of intestinal pollution which is not necessarily the case if other coliforms are present. The presence of other coliforms may be suggestive of pollution that has taken place sometime ago because these non-<em>E. coli</em> coliforms survive for long in polluted soil, water and vegetation.</p>
<p><em>E. coli</em> produces acid and gas when grown in a lactose bile salt medium (e.g. MacConkey purple broth) and is positive for indole at 44°C. The presence of coliform is confirmed by gas production from lactose at 37°C while the presence of <em>E. coli</em> is confirmed by the production of gas from lactose; and indole from tryptophan at 44°C.</p>
<p>The <em>E. coli</em> count test is done by incubating subcultures from presumptive positives at 44°C and 37°C in a lactose bile salt medium and in tryptone water at 44°C.</p>
<p>From the combination of positive and negative results of gas and indole production at 44°C, read off the most probable number of <em>E. coli</em> in 100 ml or 105 ml of sampled water.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="guidelines-for-the-use-of-media-for-multiple-tube-method">Guidelines for the use of media for multiple tube method<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#guidelines-for-the-use-of-media-for-multiple-tube-method" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
